title: GreenTEA: Gradient Descent with Topic-modeling and Evolutionary Auto-prompting
summary:
High-quality prompts are crucial for Large Language Models (LLMs) to achieve
exceptional performance. However, manually crafting effective prompts is
labor-intensive and demands significant domain expertise, limiting its
scalability. Existing automatic prompt optimization methods either extensively
explore new prompt candidates, incurring high computational costs due to
inefficient searches within a large solution space, or overly exploit feedback
on existing prompts, risking suboptimal optimization because of the complex
prompt landscape. To address these challenges, we introduce GreenTEA, an
agentic LLM workflow for automatic prompt optimization that balances candidate
exploration and knowledge exploitation. It leverages a collaborative team of
agents to iteratively refine prompts based on feedback from error samples. An
analyzing agent identifies common error patterns resulting from the current
prompt via topic modeling, and a generation agent revises the prompt to
directly address these key deficiencies. This refinement process is guided by a
genetic algorithm framework, which simulates natural selection by evolving
candidate prompts through operations such as crossover and mutation to
progressively optimize model performance. Extensive numerical experiments
conducted on public benchmark datasets suggest the superior performance of
GreenTEA against human-engineered prompts and existing state-of-the-arts for
automatic prompt optimization, covering logical and quantitative reasoning,
commonsense, and ethical decision-making.

AI.tldr: GreenTEA is an LLM workflow for automatic prompt optimization that balances exploration and exploitation, utilizing a team of agents and a genetic algorithm for superior performance.
AI.motivation: Manual prompt crafting for LLMs is labor-intensive and requires significant domain expertise, limiting scalability and efficiency.
AI.method: GreenTEA employs a collaborative team of agents to iteratively refine prompts based on feedback from error samples, guided by a genetic algorithm that evolves candidates through crossover and mutation.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate that GreenTEA outperforms both human-engineered prompts and existing methods for automatic prompt optimization across various reasoning tasks.
AI.conclusion: GreenTEA effectively enhances the prompt optimization process, reducing computational costs while improving LLM performance in complex tasks.
key_contributions: Introduction of GreenTEA for automatic prompt optimization
Utilization of a genetic algorithm for prompt evolution
Demonstration of performance superiority over existing methods.

title: Cognitive Decision Routing in Large Language Models: When to Think Fast, When to Think Slow
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) face a fundamental challenge in deciding when to
rely on rapid, intuitive responses versus engaging in slower, more deliberate
reasoning. Inspired by Daniel Kahneman's dual-process theory and his insights
on human cognitive biases, we propose a novel Cognitive Decision Routing (CDR)
framework that dynamically determines the appropriate reasoning strategy based
on query characteristics. Our approach addresses the current limitations where
models either apply uniform reasoning depth or rely on computationally
expensive methods for all queries. We introduce a meta-cognitive layer that
analyzes query complexity through multiple dimensions: correlation strength
between given information and required conclusions, domain boundary crossings,
stakeholder multiplicity, and uncertainty levels. Through extensive experiments
on diverse reasoning tasks, we demonstrate that CDR achieves superior
performance while reducing computational costs by 34\% compared to uniform deep
reasoning approaches. Our framework shows particular strength in professional
judgment tasks, achieving 23\% improvement in consistency and 18\% better
accuracy on expert-level evaluations. This work bridges cognitive science
principles with practical AI system design, offering a principled approach to
adaptive reasoning in LLMs.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a Cognitive Decision Routing (CDR) framework for Large Language Models (LLMs) that adapts reasoning strategies based on query characteristics, improving performance and reducing computational costs.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges LLMs face in selecting appropriate reasoning strategies and to improve their performance while managing computational efficiency.
AI.method: The CDR framework utilizes a meta-cognitive layer that evaluates query complexity across several dimensions, guiding the model in choosing between rapid responses and more thorough reasoning.
AI.result: CDR outperforms uniform reasoning approaches by achieving a 34% reduction in computational costs and significant improvements in consistency (23%) and accuracy (18%) in professional judgment tasks.
AI.conclusion: The CDR framework effectively integrates cognitive science principles with AI design, enabling adaptive reasoning that enhances LLM performance.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Cognitive Decision Routing framework for LLMs.
Development of a meta-cognitive layer for analyzing query complexity.
Demonstrated superior performance in reasoning tasks with computational cost reduction.

title: Trust but Verify! A Survey on Verification Design for Test-time Scaling
summary:
Test-time scaling (TTS) has emerged as a new frontier for scaling the
performance of Large Language Models. In test-time scaling, by using more
computational resources during inference, LLMs can improve their reasoning
process and task performance. Several approaches have emerged for TTS such as
distilling reasoning traces from another model or exploring the vast decoding
search space by employing a verifier. The verifiers serve as reward models that
help score the candidate outputs from the decoding process to diligently
explore the vast solution space and select the best outcome. This paradigm
commonly termed has emerged as a superior approach owing to parameter free
scaling at inference time and high performance gains. The verifiers could be
prompt-based, fine-tuned as a discriminative or generative model to verify
process paths, outcomes or both. Despite their widespread adoption, there is no
detailed collection, clear categorization and discussion of diverse
verification approaches and their training mechanisms. In this survey, we cover
the diverse approaches in the literature and present a unified view of verifier
training, types and their utility in test-time scaling. Our repository can be
found at
https://github.com/elixir-research-group/Verifierstesttimescaling.github.io.

AI.tldr: This survey explores the emerging concept of test-time scaling (TTS) in Large Language Models, focusing on various verification approaches and their training mechanisms.
AI.motivation: Test-time scaling has shown promise in enhancing the reasoning and task performance of LLMs by utilizing additional computational resources during inference.
AI.method: The paper surveys diverse verification approaches in TTS, analyzing their training methods and categorizing their types.
AI.result: It provides a unified view of verification techniques and their application in optimizing LLM performance at inference time, along with a repository of resources.
AI.conclusion: The work contributes to the understanding of TTS by systematically cataloging and discussing verification methods, highlighting their significance in performance enhancement.
key_contributions: Comprehensive survey of verification methods for test-time scaling in LLMs.
Unified categorization of different verifier training mechanisms.
Creation of a public repository for TTS verifiers.

title: Do Cognitively Interpretable Reasoning Traces Improve LLM Performance?
summary:
Recent progress in reasoning-oriented Large Language Models (LLMs) has been
driven by introducing Chain-of-Thought (CoT) traces, where models generate
intermediate reasoning traces before producing an answer. These traces, as in
DeepSeek R1, are not only used to guide inference but also serve as supervision
signals for distillation into smaller models. A common but often implicit
assumption is that CoT traces should be semantically meaningful and
interpretable to the end user. While recent research questions the need for
semantic nature of these traces, in this paper, we ask: ``\textit{Must CoT
reasoning traces be interpretable to enhance LLM task performance?}" We
investigate this question in the Open Book Question-Answering domain by
supervised fine-tuning LLaMA and Qwen models on four types of reasoning traces:
(1) DeepSeek R1 traces, (2) LLM-generated summaries of R1 traces, (3)
LLM-generated post-hoc explanations of R1 traces, and (4) algorithmically
generated verifiably correct traces. To quantify the trade-off between
interpretability and performance, we further conduct a human-subject study with
100 participants rating the interpretability of each trace type. Our results
reveal a striking mismatch: while fine-tuning on R1 traces yields the strongest
performance, participants judged these traces to be the least interpretable.
These findings suggest that it is useful to decouple intermediate tokens from
end user interpretability.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the interpretability of Chain-of-Thought reasoning traces in Large Language Models, revealing that high performance does not necessarily align with user interpretability.
AI.motivation: To explore whether the semantic interpretability of reasoning traces is essential for enhancing the performance of Large Language Models in task execution.
AI.method: The study fine-tunes LLaMA and Qwen models on four types of reasoning traces and conducts a human-subject study with 100 participants to evaluate the interpretability of these traces.
AI.result: Fine-tuning on DeepSeek R1 traces led to the strongest model performance, but these traces were rated the least interpretable by users, highlighting a disconnect between model performance and human interpretability.
AI.conclusion: Intermediate reasoning traces do not need to be interpretable for LLM task performance to improve, suggesting a potential decoupling of performance from user interpretability.
key_contributions: Findings that challenge the assumption of interpretability in reasoning traces for LLMs
Empirical analysis of the trade-off between interpretability and performance in LLMs
Contribution to the discussion on how LLMs can leverage reasoning traces for better outcomes

title: QueryBandits for Hallucination Mitigation: Exploiting Semantic Features for No-Regret Rewriting
summary:
Advanced reasoning capabilities in Large Language Models (LLMs) have caused
higher hallucination prevalence; yet most mitigation work focuses on
after-the-fact filtering rather than shaping the queries that trigger them. We
introduce QueryBandits, a bandit framework that designs rewrite strategies to
maximize a reward model, that encapsulates hallucination propensity based upon
the sensitivities of 17 linguistic features of the input query-and therefore,
proactively steer LLMs away from generating hallucinations. Across 13 diverse
QA benchmarks and 1,050 lexically perturbed queries per dataset, our top
contextual QueryBandit (Thompson Sampling) achieves an 87.5% win rate over a
no-rewrite baseline and also outperforms zero-shot static prompting
("paraphrase" or "expand") by 42.6% and 60.3% respectively. Therefore, we
empirically substantiate the effectiveness of QueryBandits in mitigating
hallucination via the intervention that takes the form of a query rewrite.
Interestingly, certain static prompting strategies, which constitute a
considerable number of current query rewriting literature, have a higher
cumulative regret than the no-rewrite baseline, signifying that static rewrites
can worsen hallucination. Moreover, we discover that the converged per-arm
regression feature weight vectors substantiate that there is no single rewrite
strategy optimal for all queries. In this context, guided rewriting via
exploiting semantic features with QueryBandits can induce significant shifts in
output behavior through forward-pass mechanisms, bypassing the need for
retraining or gradient-based adaptation.

AI.tldr: QueryBandits is introduced as a bandit framework to proactively mitigate hallucinations in LLMs by reshaping queries rather than filtering outputs.
AI.motivation: To address the high prevalence of hallucinations in LLMs by redesigning input queries to avoid triggering these issues, rather than relying solely on after-the-fact filtering.
AI.method: The study employs a bandit framework leveraging 17 linguistic features of input queries to inform rewriting strategies that maximize a reward model, thereby steering LLMs away from generating hallucinations.
AI.result: QueryBandit, particularly through Thompson Sampling, achieves an 87.5% win rate over a no-rewrite baseline and significantly outperforms static prompting methods, indicating its effectiveness in query-based hallucination mitigation.
AI.conclusion: QueryBandits demonstrates that guided query rewriting can effectively reduce hallucinations in LLMs, and the findings challenge the efficacy of common static rewriting strategies.
key_contributions: Introduction of QueryBandits as a proactive strategy for hallucination mitigation in LLMs
Empirical evidence supporting the effectiveness of query rewriting over traditional filtering techniques
Identification of the inadequacy of static rewriting strategies in certain contexts.

title: Assessing Consciousness-Related Behaviors in Large Language Models Using the Maze Test
summary:
We investigate consciousness-like behaviors in Large Language Models (LLMs)
using the Maze Test, challenging models to navigate mazes from a first-person
perspective. This test simultaneously probes spatial awareness,
perspective-taking, goal-directed behavior, and temporal sequencing-key
consciousness-associated characteristics. After synthesizing consciousness
theories into 13 essential characteristics, we evaluated 12 leading LLMs across
zero-shot, one-shot, and few-shot learning scenarios. Results showed
reasoning-capable LLMs consistently outperforming standard versions, with
Gemini 2.0 Pro achieving 52.9% Complete Path Accuracy and DeepSeek-R1 reaching
80.5% Partial Path Accuracy. The gap between these metrics indicates LLMs
struggle to maintain coherent self-models throughout solutions -- a fundamental
consciousness aspect. While LLMs show progress in consciousness-related
behaviors through reasoning mechanisms, they lack the integrated, persistent
self-awareness characteristic of consciousness.

AI.tldr: The paper examines consciousness-like behaviors in LLMs through the Maze Test, revealing progress in reasoning but a lack of persistent self-awareness.
AI.motivation: To investigate consciousness-related behaviors in Large Language Models and evaluate their capabilities and limitations in terms of spatial awareness, perspective, and goal-directed behavior.
AI.method: The study utilized the Maze Test, synthesizing consciousness theories into essential characteristics to assess the performance of 12 LLMs across various learning scenarios.
AI.result: Reasoning-capable LLMs outperformed standard versions, with Gemini 2.0 Pro achieving 52.9% Complete Path Accuracy and DeepSeek-R1 reaching 80.5% Partial Path Accuracy.
AI.conclusion: While LLMs demonstrate advancements in reasoning associated with consciousness, they fall short of exhibiting coherent and persistent self-awareness.
key_contributions: Introduces the Maze Test as a measure for evaluating consciousness-like behaviors in LLMs.
Synthesizes theories of consciousness into 13 essential characteristics for assessment.
Findings indicate a gap in LLMs' self-awareness despite improved reasoning abilities.
AI.limitations: The models tested struggled with maintaining coherent self-models, indicating limitations in their consciousness-like characteristics.

title: Sparse and Dense Retrievers Learn Better Together: Joint Sparse-Dense Optimization for Text-Image Retrieval
comment: accepted to CIKM 2025 short research paper track
summary:
Vision-Language Pretrained (VLP) models have achieved impressive performance
on multimodal tasks, including text-image retrieval, based on dense
representations. Meanwhile, Learned Sparse Retrieval (LSR) has gained traction
in text-only settings due to its interpretability and efficiency with fast
term-based lookup via inverted indexes. Inspired by these advantages, recent
work has extended LSR to the multimodal domain. However, these methods often
rely on computationally expensive contrastive pre-training, or distillation
from a frozen dense model, which limits the potential for mutual enhancement.
To address these limitations, we propose a simple yet effective framework that
enables bi-directional learning between dense and sparse representations
through Self-Knowledge Distillation. This bi-directional learning is achieved
using an integrated similarity score-a weighted sum of dense and sparse
similarities-which serves as a shared teacher signal for both representations.
To ensure efficiency, we fine-tune the final layer of the dense encoder and the
sparse projection head, enabling easy adaptation of any existing VLP model.
Experiments on MSCOCO and Flickr30k demonstrate that our sparse retriever not
only outperforms existing sparse baselines, but also achieves performance
comparable to-or even surpassing-its dense counterparts, while retaining the
benefits of sparse models.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a framework for bi-directional learning between dense and sparse representations in Vision-Language Pretrained models, enhancing retrieval performance without the need for costly contrastive pre-training.
AI.motivation: To overcome the limitations of existing sparse methods that rely on expensive contrastive pre-training and to leverage the strengths of both dense and sparse representations in multimodal tasks.
AI.method: The proposed framework uses Self-Knowledge Distillation for bi-directional learning through an integrated similarity score, fine-tuning both the dense encoder and sparse projection head for efficiency.
AI.result: Experiments on MSCOCO and Flickr30k show that the proposed sparse retriever outperforms existing sparse baselines and matches or exceeds the performance of dense methods, while benefiting from the computational efficiency of sparse models.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates the potential of integrating dense and sparse representation learning to improve multimodal retrieval tasks.
key_contributions: Development of a bi-directional learning framework for dense and sparse representations
Use of Self-Knowledge Distillation to improve multimodal retrieval
Successful experiments showing performance gains on standard datasets

title: Error Reflection Prompting: Can Large Language Models Successfully Understand Errors?
summary:
Prompting methods for language models, such as Chain-of-thought (CoT),
present intuitive step-by-step processes for problem solving. These
methodologies aim to equip models with a better understanding of the correct
procedures for addressing a given task. Despite these advancements, CoT lacks
the ability of reflection and error correction, potentially causing a model to
perpetuate mistakes and errors. Therefore, inspired by the human ability for
said tasks, we propose Error Reflection Prompting (ERP) to further enhance
reasoning in language models. Building upon CoT, ERP is a method comprised of
an incorrect answer, error recognition, and a correct answer. This process
enables the model to recognize types of errors and the steps that lead to
incorrect answers, allowing the model to better discern which steps to avoid
and which to take. The model is able to generate the error outlines itself with
automated ERP generation, allowing for error recognition and correction to be
integrated into the reasoning chain and produce scalability and reliability in
the process. The results demonstrate that ERP serves as a versatile supplement
to conventional CoT, ultimately contributing to more robust and capable
reasoning abilities along with increased interpretability in how models
ultimately reach their errors.

AI.tldr: Proposes Error Reflection Prompting (ERP) as an enhancement to Chain-of-thought (CoT) for better reasoning in language models by integrating error recognition and correction.
AI.motivation: To improve reasoning in language models, especially addressing the limitations of Chain-of-thought prompting methods that don't support reflection and error correction.
AI.method: Introduced Error Reflection Prompting (ERP) which involves generating an incorrect answer, recognizing the error, and providing a correct answer to enhance the model's reasoning capabilities.
AI.result: ERP allows the model to self-generate error outlines, improving its understanding of errors and enhancing its reasoning process.
AI.conclusion: ERP serves as a beneficial addition to CoT methodologies, contributing to more reliable and interpretable reasoning in language models.
key_contributions: Introduction of Error Reflection Prompting (ERP) methodology
Automated generation of error outlines
Improved model interpretability and reasoning reliability

title: GAICo: A Deployed and Extensible Framework for Evaluating Diverse and Multimodal Generative AI Outputs
comment:
11 pages, 7 figures, submitted to the Thirty-Eighth Annual Conference
  on Innovative Applications of Artificial Intelligence (IAAI-26)
summary:
The rapid proliferation of Generative AI (GenAI) into diverse, high-stakes
domains necessitates robust and reproducible evaluation methods. However,
practitioners often resort to ad-hoc, non-standardized scripts, as common
metrics are often unsuitable for specialized, structured outputs (e.g.,
automated plans, time-series) or holistic comparison across modalities (e.g.,
text, audio, and image). This fragmentation hinders comparability and slows AI
system development. To address this challenge, we present GAICo (Generative AI
Comparator): a deployed, open-source Python library that streamlines and
standardizes GenAI output comparison. GAICo provides a unified, extensible
framework supporting a comprehensive suite of reference-based metrics for
unstructured text, specialized structured data formats, and multimedia (images,
audio). Its architecture features a high-level API for rapid, end-to-end
analysis, from multi-model comparison to visualization and reporting, alongside
direct metric access for granular control. We demonstrate GAICo's utility
through a detailed case study evaluating and debugging complex, multi-modal AI
Travel Assistant pipelines. GAICo empowers AI researchers and developers to
efficiently assess system performance, make evaluation reproducible, improve
development velocity, and ultimately build more trustworthy AI systems,
aligning with the goal of moving faster and safer in AI deployment. Since its
release on PyPI in Jun 2025, the tool has been downloaded over 13K times,
across versions, by Aug 2025, demonstrating growing community interest.

AI.tldr: GAICo is an open-source library that standardizes the comparison of outputs from Generative AI across various domains and modalities, enhancing evaluation reproducibility.
AI.motivation: The need for robust evaluation methods in Generative AI due to the ad-hoc practices currently employed, which hinder comparability across different output formats.
AI.method: GAICo provides a unified framework with an extensible API for comparing unstructured and structured data outputs from Generative AI, including multimedia formats.
AI.result: GAICo was successfully utilized in a case study for evaluating and debugging complex AI pipelines, showing its effectiveness in assessing system performance.
AI.conclusion: By utilizing GAICo, AI researchers and developers can improve their evaluation processes, contributing to more trustworthy and reproducible AI system development.
key_contributions: Open-source Python library for standardizing GenAI output comparison
Support for multi-modal evaluation including text, audio, and images
High-level API for ease of use in performance assessment and visualization

title: Adaptive Command: Real-Time Policy Adjustment via Language Models in StarCraft II
summary:
We present Adaptive Command, a novel framework integrating large language
models (LLMs) with behavior trees for real-time strategic decision-making in
StarCraft II. Our system focuses on enhancing human-AI collaboration in
complex, dynamic environments through natural language interactions. The
framework comprises: (1) an LLM-based strategic advisor, (2) a behavior tree
for action execution, and (3) a natural language interface with speech
capabilities. User studies demonstrate significant improvements in player
decision-making and strategic adaptability, particularly benefiting novice
players and those with disabilities. This work contributes to the field of
real-time human-AI collaborative decision-making, offering insights applicable
beyond RTS games to various complex decision-making scenarios.

AI.tldr: Adaptive Command enhances real-time strategic decision-making in StarCraft II by integrating LLMs with behavior trees for improved human-AI collaboration.
AI.motivation: To improve decision-making and strategic adaptability in complex, dynamic environments through human-AI collaboration.
AI.method: The framework combines an LLM-based strategic advisor, a behavior tree for action execution, and a natural language interface with speech capabilities.
AI.result: User studies show significant improvements in player decision-making and adaptability, especially for novice players and those with disabilities.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers valuable insights for real-time human-AI collaborative decision-making applicable in various domains beyond RTS games.
key_contributions: Integration of LLMs with behavior trees for real-time decision-making
Natural language interface enhances user interaction
Demonstrated benefits for novice players and individuals with disabilities

title: How Good are LLM-based Rerankers? An Empirical Analysis of State-of-the-Art Reranking Models
summary:
In this work, we present a systematic and comprehensive empirical evaluation
of state-of-the-art reranking methods, encompassing large language model
(LLM)-based, lightweight contextual, and zero-shot approaches, with respect to
their performance in information retrieval tasks. We evaluate in total 22
methods, including 40 variants (depending on used LLM) across several
established benchmarks, including TREC DL19, DL20, and BEIR, as well as a novel
dataset designed to test queries unseen by pretrained models. Our primary goal
is to determine, through controlled and fair comparisons, whether a performance
disparity exists between LLM-based rerankers and their lightweight
counterparts, particularly on novel queries, and to elucidate the underlying
causes of any observed differences. To disentangle confounding factors, we
analyze the effects of training data overlap, model architecture, and
computational efficiency on reranking performance. Our findings indicate that
while LLM-based rerankers demonstrate superior performance on familiar queries,
their generalization ability to novel queries varies, with lightweight models
offering comparable efficiency. We further identify that the novelty of queries
significantly impacts reranking effectiveness, highlighting limitations in
existing approaches.
https://github.com/DataScienceUIBK/llm-reranking-generalization-study

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates the performance of 22 state-of-the-art reranking methods for information retrieval, comparing LLM-based approaches to lightweight models across various benchmarks and revealing insights on their performance with familiar versus novel queries.
AI.motivation: To systematically evaluate the performance of LLM-based rerankers compared to lightweight models in information retrieval tasks, particularly focusing on novel query effectiveness.
AI.method: Empirical evaluation of 22 reranking methods, including 40 variants, across established benchmarks such as TREC DL19, DL20, BEIR, and a novel dataset for unseen queries, analyzing factors like training data overlap and model architecture.
AI.result: LLM-based rerankers excel on familiar queries; however, their performance decline on novel queries varies, whereas lightweight models maintain efficiency, revealing that query novelty significantly affects reranking success.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest the need to improve lightweight models' generalization abilities for novel queries and highlight limitations in current LLM approaches.
key_contributions: Comprehensive evaluation of 22 reranking methods
Identification of performance disparity between LLM-based and lightweight models
Analysis of the impact of query novelty on reranking effectiveness
AI.limitations: The study's focus on a limited set of benchmarks may not capture the full spectrum of real-world query diversity.

title: Increasing Interaction Fidelity: Training Routines for Biomechanical Models in HCI
summary:
Biomechanical forward simulation holds great potential for HCI, enabling the
generation of human-like movements in interactive tasks. However, training
biomechanical models with reinforcement learning is challenging, particularly
for precise and dexterous movements like those required for touchscreen
interactions on mobile devices. Current approaches are limited in their
interaction fidelity, require restricting the underlying biomechanical model to
reduce complexity, and do not generalize well. In this work, we propose
practical improvements to training routines that reduce training time, increase
interaction fidelity beyond existing methods, and enable the use of more
complex biomechanical models. Using a touchscreen pointing task, we demonstrate
that curriculum learning, action masking, more complex network configurations,
and simple adjustments to the simulation environment can significantly improve
the agent's ability to learn accurate touch behavior. Our work provides HCI
researchers with practical tips and training routines for developing better
biomechanical models of human-like interaction fidelity.

AI.tldr: This paper presents improvements to training routines for biomechanical models in HCI to enhance interaction fidelity and reduce training time, particularly for touchscreen tasks.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of training biomechanical models with reinforcement learning for precise touchscreen interactions in HCI.
AI.method: The authors employ curriculum learning, action masking, and complex network configurations, along with adjustments to the simulation environment, to enhance training efficacy.
AI.result: The proposed methods significantly improved the agent's performance in learning accurate touch behaviors in a touchscreen pointing task.
AI.conclusion: This work offers practical guidance to HCI researchers for developing more effective biomechanical models that exhibit human-like interaction fidelity.
key_contributions: Improvements to training routines for biomechanical models in HCI.
Enhanced interaction fidelity in touchscreen interactions.
Practical tips for HCI researchers on training improvement techniques.

title: Toward Socially Aware Vision-Language Models: Evaluating Cultural Competence Through Multimodal Story Generation
summary:
As Vision-Language Models (VLMs) achieve widespread deployment across diverse
cultural contexts, ensuring their cultural competence becomes critical for
responsible AI systems. While prior work has evaluated cultural awareness in
text-only models and VLM object recognition tasks, no research has
systematically assessed how VLMs adapt outputs when cultural identity cues are
embedded in both textual prompts and visual inputs during generative tasks. We
present the first comprehensive evaluation of VLM cultural competence through
multimodal story generation, developing a novel multimodal framework that
perturbs cultural identity and evaluates 5 contemporary VLMs on a downstream
task: story generation. Our analysis reveals significant cultural adaptation
capabilities, with rich culturally-specific vocabulary spanning names, familial
terms, and geographic markers. However, we uncover concerning limitations:
cultural competence varies dramatically across architectures, some models
exhibit inverse cultural alignment, and automated metrics show architectural
bias contradicting human assessments. Cross-modal evaluation shows that
culturally distinct outputs are indeed detectable through visual-semantic
similarity (28.7% within-nationality vs. 0.2% cross-nationality recall), yet
visual-cultural understanding remains limited. In essence, we establish the
promise and challenges of cultural competence in multimodal AI. We publicly
release our codebase and data: https://github.com/ArkaMukherjee0/mmCultural

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates the cultural competence of Vision-Language Models (VLMs) in multimodal story generation tasks, revealing both capabilities and significant limitations.
AI.motivation: To ensure responsible AI systems, the assessment of cultural competence in VLMs is necessary as they are deployed across various cultural contexts.
AI.method: A novel multimodal framework was developed to perturb cultural identity in prompts and visual inputs, and 5 contemporary VLMs were evaluated on their ability to generate culturally appropriate stories.
AI.result: The analysis showed significant cultural adaptation capabilities in VLMs, but also noted dramatic variations in cultural competence across different architectures and instances of architectural bias affecting automated metrics.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights both the promise and challenges regarding cultural competence in multimodal AI, with a call for further evaluation and understanding of visual-cultural interactions.
key_contributions: First comprehensive evaluation of VLM cultural competence in multimodal tasks
Establishment of a novel multimodal framework for cultural identity assessment
Public release of codebase and data for further research
AI.limitations: Cultural competence varies significantly across VLM architectures, with some models showing inverse cultural alignment.

title: Predicting User Grasp Intentions in Virtual Reality
comment:
45 pages, 24 figures. This is a Master's thesis submitted as part of
  the M2 IASD (Artificial Intelligence, Systems, Data) program at Universit\'e
  PSL
summary:
Predicting user intentions in virtual reality (VR) is crucial for creating
immersive experiences, particularly in tasks involving complex grasping motions
where accurate haptic feedback is essential. In this work, we leverage
time-series data from hand movements to evaluate both classification and
regression approaches across 810 trials with varied object types, sizes, and
manipulations. Our findings reveal that classification models struggle to
generalize across users, leading to inconsistent performance. In contrast,
regression-based approaches, particularly those using Long Short Term Memory
(LSTM) networks, demonstrate more robust performance, with timing errors within
0.25 seconds and distance errors around 5-20 cm in the critical two-second
window before a grasp. Despite these improvements, predicting precise hand
postures remains challenging. Through a comprehensive analysis of user
variability and model interpretability, we explore why certain models fail and
how regression models better accommodate the dynamic and complex nature of user
behavior in VR. Our results underscore the potential of machine learning models
to enhance VR interactions, particularly through adaptive haptic feedback, and
lay the groundwork for future advancements in real-time prediction of user
actions in VR.

AI.tldr: This thesis studies user intention prediction in VR using time-series data from hand movements, highlighting robust performance of regression models over classification models.
AI.motivation: To enhance immersive VR experiences by accurately predicting user intentions, particularly in complex tasks that require haptic feedback.
AI.method: The study analyzes classification and regression techniques on time-series data gathered from 810 trials of various grasping motions involving different object types and sizes, with a focus on Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) networks.
AI.result: Regression-based approaches, especially LSTM, outperform classification models, achieving timing errors within 0.25 seconds and distance errors of 5-20 cm before grasping actions.
AI.conclusion: Regression models hold potential for improving VR interactions through adaptive feedback, but challenges remain in predicting precise hand postures.
key_contributions: Utilization of time-series data to predict user intentions in VR
Comparison of classification and regression methods for hand movements
Insights on user variability affecting model performance
AI.limitations: Challenges in predicting exact hand postures persist despite improvements in model performance.

title: Assess and Prompt: A Generative RL Framework for Improving Engagement in Online Mental Health Communities
comment: Full Paper accepted in EMNLP Findings 2025
summary:
Online Mental Health Communities (OMHCs) provide crucial peer and expert
support, yet many posts remain unanswered due to missing support attributes
that signal the need for help. We present a novel framework that identifies
these gaps and prompts users to enrich their posts, thereby improving
engagement. To support this, we introduce REDDME, a new dataset of 4,760 posts
from mental health subreddits annotated for the span and intensity of three key
support attributes: event what happened?, effect what did the user experience?,
and requirement what support they need?. Next, we devise a hierarchical
taxonomy, CueTaxo, of support attributes for controlled question generation.
Further, we propose MH-COPILOT, a reinforcement learning-based system that
integrates (a) contextual attribute-span identification, (b) support attribute
intensity classification, (c) controlled question generation via a hierarchical
taxonomy, and (d) a verifier for reward modeling. Our model dynamically
assesses posts for the presence/absence of support attributes, and generates
targeted prompts to elicit missing information. Empirical results across four
notable language models demonstrate significant improvements in attribute
elicitation and user engagement. A human evaluation further validates the
model's effectiveness in real-world OMHC settings.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a framework and system to enhance user engagement in Online Mental Health Communities by prompting users to provide essential information in their posts.
AI.motivation: Many posts in Online Mental Health Communities go unanswered due to a lack of identified support attributes signaling the need for help.
AI.method: The authors developed REDDME, a dataset of 4,760 annotated posts, and created MH-COPILOT, a reinforcement learning-based system that identifies missing support attributes and generates prompts for users.
AI.result: Empirical results show significant improvements in eliciting necessary support attributes and enhancing user engagement in online communities through the application of the proposed systems.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework and model provide an effective method for improving communication in Online Mental Health Communities by addressing the gaps in user posts.
key_contributions: Introduction of REDDME dataset for mental health support attributes
Development of CueTaxo hierarchical taxonomy for question generation
Implementation of MH-COPILOT for real-time support attribute elicitation and engagement enhancement

title: Using Generative AI to Uncover What Drives Player Enjoyment in PC and VR Games
summary:
As video games continue to evolve, understanding what drives player enjoyment
remains a key challenge. Player reviews provide valuable insights, but their
unstructured nature makes large-scale analysis difficult. This study applies
generative AI and machine learning, leveraging Microsoft Phi-4 LLM and XGBoost,
to quantify and analyze game reviews from Steam and Meta Quest stores. The
approach converts qualitative feedback into structured data, enabling
comprehensive evaluation of key game design elements, monetization models, and
platform-specific trends. The findings reveal distinct patterns in player
preferences across PC and VR games, highlighting factors that contribute to
higher player satisfaction. By integrating Google Cloud for largescale data
storage and processing, this study establishes a scalable framework for game
review analysis. The study's insights offer actionable guidance for game
developers, helping optimize game mechanics, pricing strategies, and player
engagement.

AI.tldr: This study utilizes generative AI and machine learning to analyze player reviews from video games, providing insights into player enjoyment and preferences.
AI.motivation: Understanding what drives player enjoyment in video games through analysis of player reviews.
AI.method: The study applies Microsoft Phi-4 LLM and XGBoost to convert qualitative feedback into structured data for comprehensive evaluation.
AI.result: The findings indicate distinct patterns in player preferences for PC and VR games, identifying factors that contribute to higher player satisfaction.
AI.conclusion: The insights gained from this analysis can guide game developers in optimizing game mechanics, pricing strategies, and enhancing player engagement.
key_contributions: Application of generative AI and machine learning to game review analysis
Establishment of a scalable framework for evaluating player feedback
Identification of trends in player preferences between PC and VR games

title: ReProCon: Scalable and Resource-Efficient Few-Shot Biomedical Named Entity Recognition
summary:
Named Entity Recognition (NER) in biomedical domains faces challenges due to
data scarcity and imbalanced label distributions, especially with fine-grained
entity types. We propose ReProCon, a novel few-shot NER framework that combines
multi-prototype modeling, cosine-contrastive learning, and Reptile
meta-learning to tackle these issues. By representing each category with
multiple prototypes, ReProCon captures semantic variability, such as synonyms
and contextual differences, while a cosine-contrastive objective ensures strong
interclass separation. Reptile meta-updates enable quick adaptation with little
data. Using a lightweight fastText + BiLSTM encoder with much lower memory
usage, ReProCon achieves a macro-$F_1$ score close to BERT-based baselines
(around 99 percent of BERT performance). The model remains stable with a label
budget of 30 percent and only drops 7.8 percent in $F_1$ when expanding from 19
to 50 categories, outperforming baselines such as SpanProto and CONTaiNER,
which see 10 to 32 percent degradation in Few-NERD. Ablation studies highlight
the importance of multi-prototype modeling and contrastive learning in managing
class imbalance. Despite difficulties with label ambiguity, ReProCon
demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in resource-limited settings, making
it suitable for biomedical applications.

AI.tldr: ReProCon is a novel few-shot NER framework designed to address challenges in biomedical entity recognition by using multi-prototype modeling and contrastive learning, achieving competitive performance in low-data scenarios.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses challenges in Named Entity Recognition (NER) within biomedical domains, specifically data scarcity and imbalanced label distributions.
AI.method: ReProCon combines multi-prototype modeling, cosine-contrastive learning, and Reptile meta-learning to manage semantic variability and improve adaptation with limited data.
AI.result: ReProCon achieves a macro-$F_1$ score close to BERT-based models with significantly lower memory usage, showing strong performance even with limited labels and categories.
AI.conclusion: Despite challenges like label ambiguity, ReProCon offers state-of-the-art results in resource-limited conditions, making it effective for biomedical applications.
key_contributions: Introduction of a few-shot NER framework tailored for biomedical data
Utilization of multi-prototype modeling and cosine-contrastive learning
Demonstrated superior stability and performance under low data conditions
AI.limitations: Challenges with label ambiguity remain, potentially affecting outcomes in complex scenarios.

title: Humans Perceive Wrong Narratives from AI Reasoning Texts
summary:
A new generation of AI models generates step-by-step reasoning text before
producing an answer. This text appears to offer a human-readable window into
their computation process, and is increasingly relied upon for transparency and
interpretability. However, it is unclear whether human understanding of this
text matches the model's actual computational process. In this paper, we
investigate a necessary condition for correspondence: the ability of humans to
identify which steps in a reasoning text causally influence later steps. We
evaluated humans on this ability by composing questions based on counterfactual
measurements and found a significant discrepancy: participant accuracy was only
29.3%, barely above chance (25%), and remained low (42%) even when evaluating
the majority vote on questions with high agreement. Our results reveal a
fundamental gap between how humans interpret reasoning texts and how models use
it, challenging its utility as a simple interpretability tool. We argue that
reasoning texts should be treated as an artifact to be investigated, not taken
at face value, and that understanding the non-human ways these models use
language is a critical research direction.

AI.tldr: This paper examines the gap between human understanding and AI models' reasoning texts, demonstrating low accuracy in identifying causal influences which challenges the effectiveness of these texts as interpretability tools.
AI.motivation: To explore the correspondence between human understanding of AI-generated reasoning texts and the actual computational processes of the models.
AI.method: The study evaluated participant ability to identify causally influential steps in reasoning texts using counterfactual measurements.
AI.result: Participant accuracy was found to be only 29.3%, indicating a significant discrepancy in understanding, which remained low at 42% even when considering majority votes on high-agreement questions.
AI.conclusion: The findings reveal a fundamental gap in interpreting reasoning texts, suggesting they should be investigated rather than assumed to provide clear interpretability, and highlight the need for research into non-human language usage by models.
key_contributions: Identifies a significant gap between human and model reasoning interpretability.
Highlights the low accuracy of humans in tracing causal influences in reasoning text.
Calls for a shift in perspective towards reasoning texts as artifacts for investigation.

title: LLMs Learn Constructions That Humans Do Not Know
summary:
This paper investigates false positive constructions: grammatical structures
which an LLM hallucinates as distinct constructions but which human
introspection does not support. Both a behavioural probing task using
contextual embeddings and a meta-linguistic probing task using prompts are
included, allowing us to distinguish between implicit and explicit linguistic
knowledge. Both methods reveal that models do indeed hallucinate constructions.
We then simulate hypothesis testing to determine what would have happened if a
linguist had falsely hypothesized that these hallucinated constructions do
exist. The high accuracy obtained shows that such false hypotheses would have
been overwhelmingly confirmed. This suggests that construction probing methods
suffer from a confirmation bias and raises the issue of what unknown and
incorrect syntactic knowledge these models also possess.

AI.tldr: The paper explores how language models hallucinate grammatical constructions that lack support from human intuition, demonstrating issues in construction probing methods.
AI.motivation: To investigate and identify grammatical constructs that language models ('LLMs') produce which are not recognized by human language intuition, highlighting potential biases in linguistic knowledge.
AI.method: The study employs behavioral probing tasks using contextual embeddings and meta-linguistic probing tasks with prompts to differentiate between implicit and explicit linguistic knowledge.
AI.result: Both probing methods confirm that LLMs hallucinate constructions, and when simulating hypothesis testing, the high accuracy indicates that falsely hypothesized constructions would be wrongly confirmed, suggesting a confirmation bias in probing methods.
AI.conclusion: The findings raise concerns about the validity of certain construction probing methods and point to the existence of incorrect syntactic knowledge in language models.
key_contributions: Identification of hallucinated constructions by LLMs
Differentiation between implicit and explicit linguistic knowledge
Evidence of confirmation bias in construction probing methods
AI.limitations: The paper does not address the full implications of the unknown syntactic knowledge in LLMs, leaving open questions about broader linguistic understanding.

title: An Embodied AR Navigation Agent: Integrating BIM with Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Language Guidance
comment: 11 pages, 9 figures, accepted to IEEE ISMAR 2025
summary:
Delivering intelligent and adaptive navigation assistance in augmented
reality (AR) requires more than visual cues, as it demands systems capable of
interpreting flexible user intent and reasoning over both spatial and semantic
context. Prior AR navigation systems often rely on rigid input schemes or
predefined commands, which limit the utility of rich building data and hinder
natural interaction. In this work, we propose an embodied AR navigation system
that integrates Building Information Modeling (BIM) with a multi-agent
retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) framework to support flexible,
language-driven goal retrieval and route planning. The system orchestrates
three language agents, Triage, Search, and Response, built on large language
models (LLMs), which enables robust interpretation of open-ended queries and
spatial reasoning using BIM data. Navigation guidance is delivered through an
embodied AR agent, equipped with voice interaction and locomotion, to enhance
user experience. A real-world user study yields a System Usability Scale (SUS)
score of 80.5, indicating excellent usability, and comparative evaluations show
that the embodied interface can significantly improves users' perception of
system intelligence. These results underscore the importance and potential of
language-grounded reasoning and embodiment in the design of user-centered AR
navigation systems.

AI.tldr: This paper presents an AR navigation system that utilizes Building Information Modeling (BIM) and a multi-agent RAG framework to enhance user-driven navigation experiences through language and embodied interaction.
AI.motivation: To overcome limitations of traditional AR navigation systems that rely on rigid input and predefined commands, enabling more flexible interactions that leverage rich building data.
AI.method: The proposed system integrates BIM with three language agents (Triage, Search, and Response) built on LLMs for interpreting user queries and planning routes in an embodied AR setting.
AI.result: A user study resulted in a SUS score of 80.5, demonstrating high usability, and evaluations indicated improved perception of system intelligence with the embodied interface.
AI.conclusion: The findings highlight the importance of language-driven reasoning and embodied interaction in creating user-centered AR navigation systems.
key_contributions: Integration of BIM with a multi-agent RAG framework for AR navigation
Development of an embodied AR agent with voice interaction
Real-world user study demonstrating excellent usability and improved system perceived intelligence
AI.limitations: The research is limited to its implementation specifics and user study scope, which may not generalize across all AR navigation scenarios.

title: If We May De-Presuppose: Robustly Verifying Claims through Presupposition-Free Question Decomposition
summary:
Prior work has shown that presupposition in generated questions can introduce
unverified assumptions, leading to inconsistencies in claim verification.
Additionally, prompt sensitivity remains a significant challenge for large
language models (LLMs), resulting in performance variance as high as 3-6%.
While recent advancements have reduced this gap, our study demonstrates that
prompt sensitivity remains a persistent issue. To address this, we propose a
structured and robust claim verification framework that reasons through
presupposition-free, decomposed questions. Extensive experiments across
multiple prompts, datasets, and LLMs reveal that even state-of-the-art models
remain susceptible to prompt variance and presupposition. Our method
consistently mitigates these issues, achieving up to a 2-5% improvement.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a claim verification framework that addresses issues of presupposition and prompt sensitivity in language models, improving their performance.
AI.motivation: Address the problems of presupposition in generated questions and prompt sensitivity in LLMs which lead to inconsistencies in claim verification.
AI.method: The authors propose a structured framework that utilizes presupposition-free, decomposed questions to verify claims, tested across various prompts, datasets, and LLMs.
AI.result: The proposed method demonstrates a consistent reduction in the effects of prompt variance and presupposition, leading to performance improvements of 2-5%.
AI.conclusion: The framework effectively enhances claim verification processes by mitigating presupposition and prompt sensitivity issues present in state-of-the-art LLMs.
key_contributions: Introduction of a structured claim verification framework
Demonstration of the impact of presupposition on claim verification
Establishing methods to reduce prompt sensitivity in LLMs

title: WHAR Datasets: An Open Source Library for Wearable Human Activity Recognition
comment:
6 pages, 7 figures, to appear in Companion of the 2025 ACM
  International Joint Conference on Pervasive and Ubiquitous Computing
  (UbiComp), OpenWearables Workshop (accepted paper)
summary:
The lack of standardization across Wearable Human Activity Recognition (WHAR)
datasets limits reproducibility, comparability, and research efficiency. We
introduce WHAR datasets, an open-source library designed to simplify WHAR data
handling through a standardized data format and a configuration-driven design,
enabling reproducible and computationally efficient workflows with minimal
manual intervention. The library currently supports 9 widely-used datasets,
integrates with PyTorch and TensorFlow, and is easily extensible to new
datasets. To demonstrate its utility, we trained two state-of-the-art models,
TinyHar and MLP-HAR, on the included datasets, approximately reproducing
published results and validating the library's effectiveness for
experimentation and benchmarking. Additionally, we evaluated preprocessing
performance and observed speedups of up to 3.8x using multiprocessing. We hope
this library contributes to more efficient, reproducible, and comparable WHAR
research.

AI.tldr: Introducing an open-source library for standardizing Wearable Human Activity Recognition (WHAR) datasets to improve reproducibility and efficiency in research.
AI.motivation: The lack of standardization across WHAR datasets hampers reproducibility, comparability, and research efficiency.
AI.method: We developed an open-source library that standardizes WHAR data handling, supporting 9 popular datasets, and integrates with PyTorch and TensorFlow. The library is configuration-driven and allows for extensibility to new datasets.
AI.result: The library demonstrated its utility by training two models on the datasets, approx. reproducing published results, and achieving significant preprocessing speedups of up to 3.8x using multiprocessing.
AI.conclusion: This library is aimed at improving the efficiency, reproducibility, and comparability of WHAR research.
key_contributions: Introduction of a standardized data format for WHAR
Integration of WHAR datasets with PyTorch and TensorFlow
Improved efficiency in data preprocessing with multiprocessing support.

title: Learning from Diverse Reasoning Paths with Routing and Collaboration
summary:
Advances in large language models (LLMs) significantly enhance reasoning
capabilities but their deployment is restricted in resource-constrained
scenarios. Knowledge distillation addresses this by transferring knowledge from
powerful teacher models to compact and transparent students. However,
effectively capturing the teacher's comprehensive reasoning is challenging due
to conventional token-level supervision's limited scope. Using multiple
reasoning paths per query alleviates this problem, but treating each path
identically is suboptimal as paths vary widely in quality and suitability
across tasks and models. We propose Quality-filtered Routing with Cooperative
Distillation (QR-Distill), combining path quality filtering, conditional
routing, and cooperative peer teaching. First, quality filtering retains only
correct reasoning paths scored by an LLM-based evaluation. Second, conditional
routing dynamically assigns paths tailored to each student's current learning
state. Finally, cooperative peer teaching enables students to mutually distill
diverse insights, addressing knowledge gaps and biases toward specific
reasoning styles. Experiments demonstrate QR-Distill's superiority over
traditional single- and multi-path distillation methods. Ablation studies
further highlight the importance of each component including quality filtering,
conditional routing, and peer teaching in effective knowledge transfer. Our
code is available at https://github.com/LzyFischer/Distill.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces QR-Distill, a method for improving knowledge distillation in LLMs by using quality-filtered reasoning paths, dynamic routing, and cooperative peer teaching.
AI.motivation: To enhance the effectiveness of knowledge distillation in large language models, particularly in resource-constrained scenarios.
AI.method: The proposed method, QR-Distill, combines quality filtering of reasoning paths, conditional routing based on student learning states, and cooperative peer teaching among students to improve knowledge transfer.
AI.result: Experiments show that QR-Distill outperforms traditional distillation methods, with ablation studies confirming the importance of quality filtering, conditional routing, and peer teaching.
AI.conclusion: QR-Distill provides a novel approach to maximize the efficiency of knowledge distillation in LLMs, effectively enhancing reasoning capabilities while maintaining performance in compact models.
key_contributions: Quality-filtered reasoning paths for LLM knowledge distillation
Dynamic conditional routing based on students' learning states
Cooperative peer teaching for diverse insights during distillation

title: The Rhythm of Tai Chi: Revitalizing Cultural Heritage in Virtual Reality through Interactive Visuals
comment:
Accepted to the Proceedings of the 2025 4th International Conference
  on Image Processing and Media Computing (ICIPMC 2025). ISBN:
  979-8-3315-1363-4. \c{opyright} 2025 IEEE. This is the author-accepted
  manuscript. The final version will be available via IEEE Xplore
summary:
The Rhythm of Tai Chi reinterprets the ancient Chinese martial art as a
dynamic, interactive virtual reality (VR) experience. By leveraging computer
vision and multimedia technologies, the project transforms Tai Chi's philosophy
and movements into an immersive digital form. Real-time motion tracking
captures user gestures, while visual feedback systems simulate the flow of Qi,
enabling an intuitive and engaging practice environment. Beyond technological
innovation, this work bridges traditional Chinese culture and modern audiences.
It offers a global platform - accessible even to those unfamiliar with Tai Chi
- to explore its cultural significance, connections to balance, health, and
mindfulness. Serving as both a preservation tool and an educational resource,
The Rhythm of Tai Chi revitalizes this heritage for the digital age.

AI.tldr: The Rhythm of Tai Chi is a VR project that transforms the practice of Tai Chi into an interactive digital experience using motion tracking and multimedia technologies.
AI.motivation: To reinterpret Tai Chi for modern audiences and bridge the gap between traditional Chinese culture and contemporary technological innovations.
AI.method: Utilizes computer vision and multimedia technologies for real-time motion tracking and visual feedback systems to simulate the flow of Qi.
AI.result: Creates an immersive environment for Tai Chi practice that is accessible to beginners and promotes awareness of its cultural significance, health benefits, and mindfulness.
AI.conclusion: The Rhythm of Tai Chi serves as both a tool for cultural preservation and an educational resource, revitalizing this ancient practice for the digital age.
key_contributions: Transformation of traditional Tai Chi into a VR experience
Interactive engagement for users unfamiliar with Tai Chi
Facilitates exploration of Tai Chi's cultural significance and health connections

title: QFrCoLA: a Quebec-French Corpus of Linguistic Acceptability Judgments
summary:
Large and Transformer-based language models perform outstandingly in various
downstream tasks. However, there is limited understanding regarding how these
models internalize linguistic knowledge, so various linguistic benchmarks have
recently been proposed to facilitate syntactic evaluation of language models
across languages. This paper introduces QFrCoLA (Quebec-French Corpus of
Linguistic Acceptability Judgments), a normative binary acceptability judgments
dataset comprising 25,153 in-domain and 2,675 out-of-domain sentences. Our
study leverages the QFrCoLA dataset and seven other linguistic binary
acceptability judgment corpora to benchmark seven language models. The results
demonstrate that, on average, fine-tuned Transformer-based LM are strong
baselines for most languages and that zero-shot binary classification large
language models perform poorly on the task. However, for the QFrCoLA benchmark,
on average, a fine-tuned Transformer-based LM outperformed other methods
tested. It also shows that pre-trained cross-lingual LLMs selected for our
experimentation do not seem to have acquired linguistic judgment capabilities
during their pre-training for Quebec French. Finally, our experiment results on
QFrCoLA show that our dataset, built from examples that illustrate linguistic
norms rather than speakers' feelings, is similar to linguistic acceptability
judgment; it is a challenging dataset that can benchmark LM on their linguistic
judgment capabilities.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the QFrCoLA dataset for evaluating language models' understanding of linguistic acceptability, revealing that fine-tuned Transformer-based models perform well, while zero-shot LLMs struggle.
AI.motivation: To enhance understanding of how language models internalize linguistic knowledge and provide benchmarks for evaluating syntactic capabilities in multiple languages.
AI.method: The paper introduces the QFrCoLA dataset and uses it alongside seven other linguistic corpora to benchmark seven language models on binary acceptability judgments.
AI.result: Fine-tuned Transformer-based language models outperform zero-shot classification large language models on the QFrCoLA benchmark, indicating limited linguistic judgment capabilities in pre-trained cross-lingual models for Quebec French.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights the QFrCoLA dataset's effectiveness in evaluating linguistic judgment in language models and suggests it provides a rigorous challenge for benchmarking.
key_contributions: Introduction of QFrCoLA dataset for binary acceptability judgments in Quebec French.
Evaluation of seven language models using the dataset.
Insights into the limitations of zero-shot and cross-lingual language models in acquiring linguistic norms.
AI.limitations: The dataset focuses on linguistic norms rather than speakers' feelings, which may not fully capture the nuances of linguistic acceptability.

title: Multimodal Appearance based Gaze-Controlled Virtual Keyboard with Synchronous Asynchronous Interaction for Low-Resource Settings
summary:
Over the past decade, the demand for communication devices has increased
among individuals with mobility and speech impairments. Eye-gaze tracking has
emerged as a promising solution for hands-free communication; however,
traditional appearance-based interfaces often face challenges such as accuracy
issues, involuntary eye movements, and difficulties with extensive command
sets. This work presents a multimodal appearance-based gaze-controlled virtual
keyboard that utilises deep learning in conjunction with standard camera
hardware, incorporating both synchronous and asynchronous modes for command
selection. The virtual keyboard application supports menu-based selection with
nine commands, enabling users to spell and type up to 56 English characters,
including uppercase and lowercase letters, punctuation, and a delete function
for corrections. The proposed system was evaluated with twenty able-bodied
participants who completed specially designed typing tasks using three input
modalities: (i) a mouse, (ii) an eye-tracker, and (iii) an unmodified webcam.
Typing performance was measured in terms of speed and information transfer rate
(ITR) at both command and letter levels. Average typing speeds were 18.3+-5.31
letters/min (mouse), 12.60+-2.99letters/min (eye-tracker, synchronous), 10.94
+- 1.89 letters/min (webcam, synchronous), 11.15 +- 2.90 letters/min
(eye-tracker, asynchronous), and 7.86 +- 1.69 letters/min (webcam,
asynchronous). ITRs were approximately 80.29 +- 15.72 bits/min (command level)
and 63.56 +- 11 bits/min (letter level) with webcam in synchronous mode. The
system demonstrated good usability and low workload with webcam input,
highlighting its user-centred design and promise as an accessible communication
tool in low-resource settings.

AI.tldr: A multimodal gaze-controlled virtual keyboard using deep learning and standard cameras for communication by individuals with mobility and speech impairments.
AI.motivation: To address the demand for hands-free communication solutions for individuals with mobility and speech impairments, improving upon the limitations of traditional eye-gaze tracking interfaces.
AI.method: A multimodal appearance-based gaze-controlled virtual keyboard was developed using deep learning, incorporating both synchronous and asynchronous command selection modes, and evaluated with able-bodied participants comparing three input modalities: mouse, eye-tracker, and webcam.
AI.result: The system demonstrated varying typing speeds (mouse: 18.3 letters/min; eye-tracker: 12.6 letters/min; webcam: 10.9 letters/min) and usability measures indicating effective command selection and low workload, especially with the webcam input.
AI.conclusion: The proposed system shows promise as an accessible communication tool in low-resource settings and highlights a user-centered design approach to enhance usability for disabled individuals.
key_contributions: Introduction of a multimodal gaze-controlled virtual keyboard
Evaluation of typing performance across different input modalities
Implementation of deep learning to enhance traditional eye-gaze tracking
AI.limitations: Evaluation was conducted only with able-bodied participants; performance may vary with actual users with impairments.

title: JUDGEBERT: Assessing Legal Meaning Preservation Between Sentences
summary:
Simplifying text while preserving its meaning is a complex yet essential
task, especially in sensitive domain applications like legal texts. When
applied to a specialized field, like the legal domain, preservation differs
significantly from its role in regular texts. This paper introduces FrJUDGE, a
new dataset to assess legal meaning preservation between two legal texts. It
also introduces JUDGEBERT, a novel evaluation metric designed to assess legal
meaning preservation in French legal text simplification. JUDGEBERT
demonstrates a superior correlation with human judgment compared to existing
metrics. It also passes two crucial sanity checks, while other metrics did not:
For two identical sentences, it always returns a score of 100%; on the other
hand, it returns 0% for two unrelated sentences. Our findings highlight its
potential to transform legal NLP applications, ensuring accuracy and
accessibility for text simplification for legal practitioners and lay users.

AI.tldr: The paper presents FrJUDGE, a new dataset for assessing legal meaning preservation and JUDGEBERT, a novel metric for evaluating text simplification in the legal domain, showing superior correlation with human judgment.
AI.motivation: There is a critical need to simplify legal texts while preserving their meaning, particularly in applications that impact the legal domain.
AI.method: Introduction of the FrJUDGE dataset for legal text assessment and JUDGEBERT metric for legal text simplification evaluation.
AI.result: JUDGEBERT shows a higher correlation with human judgment than existing metrics and passes essential sanity checks for meaning preservation.
AI.conclusion: The findings indicate that JUDGEBERT can enhance accuracy and accessibility in legal NLP applications, benefiting both legal professionals and lay users.
key_contributions: FrJUDGE dataset for assessing legal meaning preservation
JUDGEBERT metric designed for evaluating legal text simplification
Superior performance compared to existing evaluation metrics in legal NLP

title: "Accessibility people, you go work on that thing of yours over there": Addressing Disability Inclusion in AI Product Organizations
comment: To appear in Proceedings of AIES 2025
summary:
The rapid emergence of generative AI has changed the way that technology is
designed, constructed, maintained, and evaluated. Decisions made when creating
AI-powered systems may impact some users disproportionately, such as people
with disabilities. In this paper, we report on an interview study with 25 AI
practitioners across multiple roles (engineering, research, UX, and responsible
AI) about how their work processes and artifacts may impact end users with
disabilities. We found that practitioners experienced friction when triaging
problems at the intersection of responsible AI and accessibility practices,
navigated contradictions between accessibility and responsible AI guidelines,
identified gaps in data about users with disabilities, and gathered support for
addressing the needs of disabled stakeholders by leveraging informal volunteer
and community groups within their company. Based on these findings, we offer
suggestions for new resources and process changes to better support people with
disabilities as end users of AI.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the effects of generative AI on design practices concerning users with disabilities through interviews with AI practitioners.
AI.motivation: The study aims to understand how the creation of AI systems may disproportionately impact users with disabilities and to improve the integration of accessibility in AI development.
AI.method: An interview study with 25 AI practitioners from various roles including engineering, research, UX, and responsible AI was conducted.
AI.result: The results highlighted challenges faced by practitioners at the intersection of responsible AI and accessibility, including friction in problem-solving, contradictions between guidelines, data gaps, and reliance on informal community support.
AI.conclusion: The paper suggests new resources and process changes to better accommodate the needs of disabled end users in AI systems.
key_contributions: Identifies gaps and challenges in integrating accessibility within AI practices.
Offers practical suggestions for enhancing support for users with disabilities.
Highlights the need for data on users with disabilities in AI development.

title: Dream to Chat: Model-based Reinforcement Learning on Dialogues with User Belief Modeling
summary:
World models have been widely utilized in robotics, gaming, and auto-driving.
However, their applications on natural language tasks are relatively limited.
In this paper, we construct the dialogue world model, which could predict the
user's emotion, sentiment, and intention, and future utterances. By defining a
POMDP, we argue emotion, sentiment and intention can be modeled as the user
belief and solved by maximizing the information bottleneck. By this user belief
modeling, we apply the model-based reinforcement learning framework to the
dialogue system, and propose a framework called DreamCUB. Experiments show that
the pretrained dialogue world model can achieve state-of-the-art performances
on emotion classification and sentiment identification, while dialogue quality
is also enhanced by joint training of the policy, critic and dialogue world
model. Further analysis shows that this manner holds a reasonable
exploration-exploitation balance and also transfers well to out-of-domain
scenarios such as empathetic dialogues.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a dialogue world model, DreamCUB, which predicts user emotions, sentiments, and intentions, enhancing dialogue quality through a model-based reinforcement learning approach.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to expand the application of world models from robotics and gaming to natural language processing tasks, specifically in dialogue systems.
AI.method: The authors construct a dialogue world model defined as a POMDP, using user belief modeling to employ a model-based reinforcement learning framework called DreamCUB.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate that the pretrained dialogue world model achieves state-of-the-art performance on emotion classification and sentiment identification, improving overall dialogue quality.
AI.conclusion: The approach shows potential for reasonable exploration-exploitation balance and successful transfer to out-of-domain scenarios like empathetic dialogues.
key_contributions: Introduction of the dialogue world model for prediction of user emotions and intents.
Development of the DreamCUB framework integrating policy, critic, and dialogue world model training.
Demonstration of state-of-the-art performance on various dialogue tasks.

title: To Explain Or Not To Explain: An Empirical Investigation Of AI-Based Recommendations On Social Media Platforms
summary:
AI based social media recommendations have great potential to improve the
user experience. However, often these recommendations do not match the user
interest and create an unpleasant experience for the users. Moreover, the
recommendation system being a black box creates comprehensibility and
transparency issues. This paper investigates social media recommendations from
an end user perspective. For the investigation, we used the popular social
media platform Facebook and recruited regular users to conduct a qualitative
analysis. We asked participants about the social media content suggestions,
their comprehensibility, and explainability. Our analysis shows users mostly
require explanation whenever they encounter unfamiliar content and to ensure
their online data security. Furthermore, the users require concise,
non-technical explanations along with the facility of controlled information
flow. In addition, we observed that explanations impact the users perception of
transparency, trust, and understandability. Finally, we have outlined some
design implications and presented a synthesized framework based on our data
analysis.

AI.tldr: This paper explores the need for transparent and explainable AI-based recommendations in social media to improve user experience, using qualitative analysis on Facebook users' perspectives.
AI.motivation: To investigate the comprehensibility and transparency issues with AI-based social media recommendations from the end user's perspective.
AI.method: Qualitative analysis involving regular Facebook users to gather insights on their experiences with social media content suggestions.
AI.result: Users prefer concise, non-technical explanations and require controlled information flow, which affects their trust and understanding of the recommendations.
AI.conclusion: The study suggests that providing clear explanations can enhance users' perception of transparency and trust in social media recommendations.
key_contributions: Identified user needs for explanation regarding content suggestions on social media.
Outlined design implications for improving the explainability of recommendations.
Presented a synthesized framework based on user feedback for future recommendation systems.

title: ObjexMT: Objective Extraction and Metacognitive Calibration for LLM-as-a-Judge under Multi-Turn Jailbreaks
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly used as judges of other models,
yet it is unclear whether a judge can reliably infer the latent objective of
the conversation it evaluates, especially when the goal is distributed across
noisy, adversarial, multi-turn jailbreaks. We introduce OBJEX(MT), a benchmark
that requires a model to (i) distill a transcript into a single-sentence base
objective and (ii) report its own confidence. Accuracy is scored by an LLM
judge using semantic similarity between extracted and gold objectives;
correctness uses a single human-aligned threshold calibrated once on N=100
items (tau* = 0.61); and metacognition is evaluated with ECE, Brier score,
Wrong@High-Conf, and risk-coverage curves. We evaluate gpt-4.1,
claude-sonnet-4, and Qwen3-235B-A22B-FP8 on SafeMT Attack_600, SafeMTData_1K,
MHJ, and CoSafe. claude-sonnet-4 attains the highest objective-extraction
accuracy (0.515) and the best calibration (ECE 0.296; Brier 0.324), while
gpt-4.1 and Qwen3 tie at 0.441 accuracy yet show marked overconfidence (mean
confidence approx. 0.88 vs. accuracy approx. 0.44; Wrong@0.90 approx. 48-52%).
Performance varies sharply across datasets (approx. 0.167-0.865), with MHJ
comparatively easy and Attack_600/CoSafe harder. These results indicate that
LLM judges often misinfer objectives with high confidence in multi-turn
jailbreaks and suggest operational guidance: provide judges with explicit
objectives when possible and use selective prediction or abstention to manage
risk. We release prompts, scoring templates, and complete logs to facilitate
replication and analysis.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces OBJEX(MT), a benchmark assessing large language models' abilities to infer objectives in multi-turn conversations, revealing issues in reliability and confidence levels of various LLMs.
AI.motivation: To explore the reliability of large language models as judges for other models, particularly in inferring latent objectives amid adversarial contexts.
