AI.method: The study involves collecting real-time trust votes and comfort ratings from participants in a driving simulator, along with their physiological signals and environmental data. Machine learning models were evaluated for trust classification and comfort regression.
AI.result: Tree-based models like Random Forest and XGBoost demonstrated the best performance for trust classification, while non-linear models such as KNN and MLP regressor excelled in comfort regression. SHAP analysis led to the identification of key features impacting these estimations.
AI.conclusion: The dataset supports the development of adaptive autonomous vehicle systems that can respond to driver trust and comfort levels, thereby enhancing safety and user experience.
key_contributions: Introduction of the TRUCE-AV dataset for real-time trust and comfort measurement in AVs
Demonstration of effective machine learning models for trust and comfort estimation
Identification of key physiological and environmental features influencing user trust and comfort

title: The Power of Framing: How News Headlines Guide Search Behavior
summary:
Search engines play a central role in how people gather information, but
subtle cues like headline framing may influence not only what users believe but
also how they search. While framing effects on judgment are well documented,
their impact on subsequent search behavior is less understood. We conducted a
controlled experiment where participants issued queries and selected from
headlines filtered by specific linguistic frames. Headline framing
significantly shaped follow-up queries: conflict and strategy frames disrupted
alignment with prior selections, while episodic frames led to more concrete
queries than thematic ones. We also observed modest short-term frame
persistence that declined over time. These results suggest that even brief
exposure to framing can meaningfully alter the direction of users
information-seeking behavior.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates how headline framing influences users' information-seeking behavior in search engines.
AI.motivation: To understand the impact of subtle cues like headline framing on users' search behavior, particularly in how they issue queries and make selections.
AI.method: Conducted a controlled experiment where participants issued queries and selected from headlines shaped by specific linguistic frames, analyzing the effects on follow-up queries.
AI.result: Headline framing significantly influenced follow-up queries; conflict and strategy frames caused misalignment with prior selections, while episodic frames led to more concrete queries.
AI.conclusion: Even brief exposure to different headline frames can notably influence users' information-seeking behavior, indicating this effect's potential relevance in search engine design.
key_contributions: Demonstrated the impact of headline framing on search behavior
Highlighted the effects of different linguistic frames on user query formulation
Provided insights into short-term frame persistence on information-seeking behavior
AI.limitations: Limited examination of long-term effects of framing on search behavior and potential impact on diverse user demographics.

title: "Nobody should control the end user": Exploring Privacy Perspectives of Indian Internet Users in Light of DPDPA
summary:
With the rapid increase in online interactions, concerns over data privacy
and transparency of data processing practices have become more pronounced.
While regulations like the GDPR have driven the widespread adoption of cookie
banners in the EU, India's Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDPA)
promises similar changes domestically, aiming to introduce a framework for data
protection. However, certain clauses within the DPDPA raise concerns about
potential infringements on user privacy, given the exemptions for government
accountability and user consent requirements. In this study, for the first
time, we explore Indian Internet users' awareness and perceptions of cookie
banners, online privacy, and privacy regulations, especially in light of the
newly passed DPDPA. We conducted an online anonymous survey with 428 Indian
participants, which addressed: (1) users' perspectives on cookie banners, (2)
their attitudes towards online privacy and privacy regulations, and (3) their
acceptance of 10 contentious DPDPA clauses that favor state authorities and may
enable surveillance. Our findings reveal that privacy-conscious users often
lack consistent awareness of privacy mechanisms, and their concerns do not
always lead to protective actions. Our thematic analysis of 143 open ended
responses shows that users' privacy and data protection concerns are rooted in
skepticism towards the government, shaping their perceptions of the DPDPA and
fueling demands for policy revisions. Our study highlights the need for clearer
communication regarding the DPDPA, user-centric consent mechanisms, and policy
refinements to enhance data privacy practices in India.

AI.tldr: This study examines Indian Internet users' awareness and perceptions of cookie banners and privacy regulations, focusing on the Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDPA).
AI.motivation: To investigate the awareness and perceptions of Indian Internet users regarding data privacy, cookie banners, and the newly introduced DPDPA.
AI.method: An online anonymous survey was conducted with 428 participants to assess their perspectives on cookie banners, attitudes towards online privacy, and acceptance of contentious DPDPA clauses.
AI.result: Privacy-conscious users displayed inconsistent awareness of privacy mechanisms, and concerns about privacy do not always translate into protective actions. Thematic analysis of open-ended responses indicated skepticism towards government accountability influences perceptions of the DPDPA.
AI.conclusion: The study emphasizes the necessity for clearer communication about the DPDPA, user-centric consent mechanisms, and policy refinements to improve data privacy practices in India.
key_contributions: First exploration of Indian users' awareness of cookie banners and DPDPA
Identification of skepticism towards the government affecting privacy perceptions
Insights into user demands for policy revisions regarding data privacy

title: Geolocation-Aware Robust Spoken Language Identification
comment:
Accepted to IEEE ASRU 2025. \c{opyright} 2025 IEEE. Personal use

  reprinting/republishing, advertising, resale, redistribution, reuse, or
  creating collective works
summary:
While Self-supervised Learning (SSL) has significantly improved Spoken
Language Identification (LID), existing models often struggle to consistently
classify dialects and accents of the same language as a unified class. To
address this challenge, we propose geolocation-aware LID, a novel approach that
incorporates language-level geolocation information into the SSL-based LID
model. Specifically, we introduce geolocation prediction as an auxiliary task
and inject the predicted vectors into intermediate representations as
conditioning signals. This explicit conditioning encourages the model to learn
more unified representations for dialectal and accented variations. Experiments
across six multilingual datasets demonstrate that our approach improves
robustness to intra-language variations and unseen domains, achieving new
state-of-the-art accuracy on FLEURS (97.7%) and 9.7% relative improvement on
ML-SUPERB 2.0 dialect set.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a geolocation-aware approach to Spoken Language Identification that improves classification of dialects and accents by integrating geolocation information into self-supervised learning models.
AI.motivation: The current models in Spoken Language Identification struggle with accurately classifying dialects and accents, which is critical for effective language processing in multilingual contexts.
AI.method: The authors introduce geolocation prediction as an auxiliary task and incorporate the predicted vectors into intermediate model representations, providing explicit conditioning to enhance learning of unified representations for variants of the same language.
AI.result: Experiments on six multilingual datasets show that the proposed method improves accuracy and robustness, achieving a new state-of-the-art performance on the FLEURS dataset (97.7%) and a 9.7% relative improvement on the ML-SUPERB 2.0 dialect set.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating geolocation information in SSL-based Spoken Language Identification models leads to significant improvements in handling dialectal variations and can enhance the model's performance in unseen domains.
key_contributions: Introduction of geolocation prediction as an auxiliary task for SSL models in LID
Improvements in accuracy for dialect and accent classification
Demonstration of state-of-the-art results on multiple multilingual datasets

title: An Introduction to Silent Paralinguistics
summary:
The ability to speak is an inherent part of human nature and fundamental to
our existence as a social species. Unfortunately, this ability can be
restricted in certain situations, such as for individuals who have lost their
voice or in environments where speaking aloud is unsuitable. Additionally, some
people may prefer not to speak audibly due to privacy concerns. For such cases,
silent speech interfaces have been proposed, which focus on processing
biosignals corresponding to silently produced speech. These interfaces enable
synthesis of audible speech from biosignals that are produced when speaking
silently and recognition aka decoding of biosignals into text that corresponds
to the silently produced speech. While recognition and synthesis of silent
speech has been a prominent focus in many research studies, there is a
significant gap in deriving paralinguistic information such as affective states
from silent speech. To fill this gap, we propose Silent Paralinguistics, aiming
to predict paralinguistic information from silent speech and ultimately
integrate it into the reconstructed audible voice for natural communication.
This survey provides a comprehensive look at methods, research strategies, and
objectives within the emerging field of silent paralinguistics.

AI.tldr: The paper surveys the emerging field of Silent Paralinguistics, which aims to derive paralinguistic information from silent speech to enhance communication through biosignal processing.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of existing silent speech interfaces that primarily focus on recognition and synthesis without considering paralinguistic information.
AI.method: The paper reviews various methods and research strategies within silent speech research, emphasizing the integration of affective states into speech reconstruction.
AI.result: The study highlights the gap in current research for predicting paralinguistic information from silent speech and proposes a framework for integrating this into audible speech synthesis.
AI.conclusion: Integrating paralinguistic cues into silent speech interfaces can improve the naturalness of synthesized speech and facilitate better communication in constrained environments.
key_contributions: Introduces the concept of Silent Paralinguistics.
Proposes methods to derive affective states from silent speech.
Surveys existing research and gaps in silent speech technologies.
AI.limitations: The paper primarily offers a theoretical framework without extensive experimental validation.

title: Natural Language Satisfiability: Exploring the Problem Distribution and Evaluating Transformer-based Language Models
comment:
The paper was accepted to the 62nd Association for Computational
  Linguistics (ACL 2024), where it won the Best Paper Award
summary:
Efforts to apply transformer-based language models (TLMs) to the problem of
reasoning in natural language have enjoyed ever-increasing success in recent
years. The most fundamental task in this area to which nearly all others can be
reduced is that of determining satisfiability. However, from a logical point of
view, satisfiability problems vary along various dimensions, which may affect
TLMs' ability to learn how to solve them. The problem instances of
satisfiability in natural language can belong to different computational
complexity classes depending on the language fragment in which they are
expressed. Although prior research has explored the problem of natural language
satisfiability, the above-mentioned point has not been discussed adequately.
Hence, we investigate how problem instances from varying computational
complexity classes and having different grammatical constructs impact TLMs'
ability to learn rules of inference. Furthermore, to faithfully evaluate TLMs,
we conduct an empirical study to explore the distribution of satisfiability
problems.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the impact of computational complexity and grammatical constructs on transformer-based language models' ability to solve natural language satisfiability problems, presenting an empirical study on this topic.
AI.motivation: To address the insufficient exploration of how varying computational complexity classes affect transformer-based language models (TLMs) in solving natural language satisfiability problems.
AI.method: The authors conducted a theoretical analysis of the relationship between problem instances' complexity classes and TLM performance, complemented by an empirical study evaluating TLMs on a range of satisfiability problems.
AI.result: The study reveals that TLMs' performance varies significantly based on the complexity classes and grammatical constructs of the problems, highlighting the nuances of learning rules of inference in natural language.
AI.conclusion: Understanding the impact of grammatical constructs and computational complexities on TLMs enables better application of these models to reasoning tasks in natural language.
key_contributions: Introduction of the categorization of satisfiability problems by complexity classes in relation to TLM performance.
Empirical evaluation of TLMs on a diverse set of natural language satisfiability problems.
Insights on how grammatical constructs influence reasoning capabilities of TLMs.
AI.limitations: The study is limited by the specific types of language fragments analyzed and may not encompass all aspects of natural language reasoning.

title: Mirroring Users: Towards Building Preference-aligned User Simulator with User Feedback in Recommendation
summary:
User simulation is increasingly vital to develop and evaluate recommender
systems (RSs). While Large Language Models (LLMs) offer promising avenues to
simulate user behavior, they often struggle with the absence of specific domain
alignment required for RSs and the efficiency demands of large-scale
simulation. A vast yet underutilized resource for enhancing this alignment is
the extensive user feedback inherent in RSs. However, directly leveraging such
feedback presents two significant challenges. First, user feedback in RSs is
often ambiguous and noisy, which negatively impacts effective preference
alignment. Second, the massive volume of feedback largely hinders the
efficiency of preference alignment, necessitating an efficient filtering
mechanism to identify more informative samples. To overcome these hurdles, we
introduce a novel data construction framework that leverages user feedback in
RSs with advanced LLM capabilities to generate high-quality simulation data.
Our framework unfolds in two key phases: (1) employing LLMs to generate
cognitive decision-making processes on constructed simulation samples, reducing
ambiguity in raw user feedback; (2) data distillation based on uncertainty
estimation and behavior sampling to filter challenging yet denoised simulation
samples. Accordingly, we fine-tune lightweight LLMs, as user simulators, using
such high-quality dataset with corresponding decision-making processes.
Extensive experiments verify that our framework significantly boosts the
alignment with human preferences and in-domain reasoning capabilities of
fine-tuned LLMs, and provides more insightful and interpretable signals when
interacting with RSs. We believe our work will advance the RS community and
offer valuable insights for broader human-centric AI research.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a framework that utilizes user feedback in recommender systems (RSs) to enhance user simulations and aligns Large Language Models (LLMs) with human preferences.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of utilizing user feedback in recommender systems for the effective simulation of user behavior and improve the alignment of LLMs with human preferences.
AI.method: The framework employs LLMs to generate cognitive decision-making processes from user feedback, reducing ambiguity and noise, followed by a data distillation process that filters simulation samples based on uncertainty estimation and behavior sampling.
AI.result: Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly improves the alignment of LLMs with human preferences and enhances their reasoning capabilities in the context of RSs.
AI.conclusion: This work aims to contribute to the recommender systems community and provide insights for human-centric AI research by leveraging user feedback effectively.
key_contributions: Proposes a novel data construction framework for user simulations in RSs.
Implements a two-phase process using LLMs to improve user feedback interpretation.
Demonstrates enhanced alignment with human preferences and reasoning capabilities of LLMs through extensive experiments.

title: SPORTSQL: An Interactive System for Real-Time Sports Reasoning and Visualization
summary:
We present a modular, interactive system, SPORTSQL, for natural language
querying and visualization of dynamic sports data, with a focus on the English
Premier League (EPL). The system translates user questions into executable SQL
over a live, temporally indexed database constructed from real-time Fantasy
Premier League (FPL) data. It supports both tabular and visual outputs,
leveraging the symbolic reasoning capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs)
for query parsing, schema linking, and visualization selection. To evaluate
system performance, we introduce the Dynamic Sport Question Answering benchmark
(DSQABENCH), comprising 1,700+ queries annotated with SQL programs, gold
answers, and database snapshots. Our demo highlights how non-expert users can
seamlessly explore evolving sports statistics through a natural, conversational
interface.

AI.tldr: SPORTSQL is an interactive system for querying and visualizing dynamic sports data using natural language, specifically for the English Premier League.
AI.motivation: To allow non-expert users to interactively explore sports statistics through natural language queries.
AI.method: The system translates natural language questions into SQL queries over a live database of Fantasy Premier League data, supporting both tabular and visual outputs.
AI.result: Introduction of a benchmark (DSQABENCH) with over 1,700 annotated queries for system evaluation.
AI.conclusion: SPORTSQL enables users to seamlessly engage with sports data in a conversational manner, enhancing accessibility to complex statistics.
key_contributions: Development of SPORTSQL system for natural language querying of sports data
Creation of DSQABENCH benchmark for evaluating question answering in sports
Integration of Large Language Models for enhanced query processing and visualization.

title: InReAcTable: LLM-Powered Interactive Visual Data Story Construction from Tabular Data
comment: 16 pages, 10 figures, accepted at ACM UIST 2025 (to appear)
summary:
Insights in tabular data capture valuable patterns that help analysts
understand critical information. Organizing related insights into visual data
stories is crucial for in-depth analysis. However, constructing such stories is
challenging because of the complexity of the inherent relations between
extracted insights. Users face difficulty sifting through a vast number of
discrete insights to integrate specific ones into a unified narrative that
meets their analytical goals. Existing methods either heavily rely on user
expertise, making the process inefficient, or employ automated approaches that
cannot fully capture their evolving goals. In this paper, we introduce
InReAcTable, a framework that enhances visual data story construction by
establishing both structural and semantic connections between data insights.
Each user interaction triggers the Acting module, which utilizes an insight
graph for structural filtering to narrow the search space, followed by the
Reasoning module using the retrieval-augmented generation method based on large
language models for semantic filtering, ultimately providing insight
recommendations aligned with the user's analytical intent. Based on the
InReAcTable framework, we develop an interactive prototype system that guides
users to construct visual data stories aligned with their analytical
requirements. We conducted a case study and a user experiment to demonstrate
the utility and effectiveness of the InReAcTable framework and the prototype
system for interactively building visual data stories.

AI.tldr: The paper presents InReAcTable, a framework that facilitates visual data story construction by enhancing the integration of related insights through structural and semantic connections, using user interactions for effective recommendation.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges faced by analysts in constructing coherent visual data stories from discrete insights, amidst the complexity of their relations and the inefficiencies of existing methods.
AI.method: The InReAcTable framework employs an insight graph for structural filtering followed by a reasoning module that uses retrieval-augmented generation with large language models for semantic filtering, guiding users towards relevant insight recommendations.
AI.result: The framework and its prototype were tested through a case study and user experiment, demonstrating significant utility and effectiveness in helping users construct visual data stories aligned with their analytical objectives.
AI.conclusion: InReAcTable offers a structured approach to enhance the traditional methods of constructing visual data stories, making the process more efficient and user-friendly through interactive solutions.
key_contributions: Introduction of the InReAcTable framework for visual data story construction.
Development of a prototype that utilizes the framework to interactively assist users.
Validation of the framework's utility and effectiveness through case studies and user experiments.
AI.limitations: The paper does not address potential scalability issues with larger datasets or the adaptability of the framework to various domains outside the scope of the study.

title: Quantifying Language Disparities in Multilingual Large Language Models
summary:
Results reported in large-scale multilingual evaluations are often fragmented
and confounded by factors such as target languages, differences in experimental
setups, and model choices. We propose a framework that disentangles these
confounding variables and introduces three interpretable metrics--the
performance realisation ratio, its coefficient of variation, and language
potential--enabling a finer-grained and more insightful quantification of
actual performance disparities across both (i) models and (ii) languages.
Through a case study of 13 model variants on 11 multilingual datasets, we
demonstrate that our framework provides a more reliable measurement of model
performance and language disparities, particularly for low-resource languages,
which have so far proven challenging to evaluate. Importantly, our results
reveal that higher overall model performance does not necessarily imply greater
fairness across languages.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a framework that disentangles confounding variables in multilingual evaluation of models, introducing new metrics for better performance assessment across languages.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the fragmentation and confounding factors in large-scale multilingual evaluations, which affect the understanding of model performance and fairness across different languages.
AI.method: The authors introduce a framework with three interpretable metrics: performance realisation ratio, coefficient of variation, and language potential, applying it to 13 model variants on 11 multilingual datasets.
AI.result: The proposed framework enables a more reliable measurement of model performance and highlights disparities particularly for low-resource languages, revealing that better overall performance doesn't guarantee fairness.
AI.conclusion: The findings emphasize the need for careful evaluation of multilingual models and the importance of the new metrics in understanding performance across languages.
key_contributions: Introduces a new framework for disentangling confounding factors in multilingual evaluation.
Develops three novel interpretable metrics for performance assessment.
Demonstrates practical application on multiple models and datasets, revealing insights about low-resource languages.
AI.limitations: The study focuses mainly on 13 models and 11 datasets, which may not encompass all language nuances.

title: Can AI Have a Personality? Prompt Engineering for AI Personality Simulation: A Chatbot Case Study in Gender-Affirming Voice Therapy Training
summary:
This thesis investigates whether large language models (LLMs) can be guided
to simulate a consistent personality through prompt engineering. The study
explores this concept within the context of a chatbot designed for
Speech-Language Pathology (SLP) student training, specifically focused on
gender-affirming voice therapy. The chatbot, named Monae Jackson, was created
to represent a 32-year-old transgender woman and engage in conversations
simulating client-therapist interactions. Findings suggest that with prompt
engineering, the chatbot maintained a recognizable and consistent persona and
had a distinct personality based on the Big Five Personality test. These
results support the idea that prompt engineering can be used to simulate stable
personality characteristics in AI chatbots.

AI.tldr: This thesis explores the use of prompt engineering to create a chatbot with consistent personality traits for Speech-Language Pathology training.
AI.motivation: To determine if large language models can be guided to simulate consistent personalities in an educational context.
AI.method: The study involved prompt engineering techniques applied to a chatbot designed for gender-affirming voice therapy training in SLP.
AI.result: The chatbot demonstrated a recognizable and consistent personality, correlating with the Big Five Personality traits, suggesting effectiveness of prompt engineering in AI personality simulation.
AI.conclusion: Prompt engineering can effectively simulate stable personality characteristics in chatbots for therapeutic training purposes.
key_contributions: Development of a chatbot named Monae Jackson for SLP training
Demonstration of consistent personality simulation using prompt engineering
Insights into the application of AI in gender-affirming voice therapy
AI.limitations: Further research needed to generalize findings and assess long-term interactions.

title: The Impact of Annotator Personas on LLM Behavior Across the Perspectivism Spectrum
summary:
In this work, we explore the capability of Large Language Models (LLMs) to
annotate hate speech and abusiveness while considering predefined annotator
personas within the strong-to-weak data perspectivism spectra. We evaluated
LLM-generated annotations against existing annotator modeling techniques for
perspective modeling. Our findings show that LLMs selectively use demographic
attributes from the personas. We identified prototypical annotators, with
persona features that show varying degrees of alignment with the original human
annotators. Within the data perspectivism paradigm, annotator modeling
techniques that do not explicitly rely on annotator information performed
better under weak data perspectivism compared to both strong data perspectivism
and human annotations, suggesting LLM-generated views tend towards aggregation
despite subjective prompting. However, for more personalized datasets tailored
to strong perspectivism, the performance of LLM annotator modeling approached,
but did not exceed, human annotators.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the ability of Large Language Models to annotate hate speech while incorporating annotator personas, comparing their performance to human annotations.
AI.motivation: To explore how LLMs can effectively annotate hate speech considering predefined annotator personas and the impact of data perspectivism.
AI.method: The study evaluated LLM-generated annotations against traditional annotator modeling methods, examining how demographic attributes influenced the annotation outcomes across different data perspectivism contexts.
AI.result: LLM-generated annotations showed selective use of demographic features, and tended to aggregate perspectives, performing better under weak data perspectivism than human annotators in certain contexts.
AI.conclusion: While LLMs can effectively model annotations, their performance approached but did not surpass human annotators in strong data perspectivism settings, indicating room for improvement.
key_contributions: Investigates LLM annotation of hate speech with annotator personas
Compares LLM performance with human annotations across data perspectivism levels
Identifies prototypical annotators based on LLM outputs
AI.limitations: The study is limited to hate speech annotation and may not generalize to other contexts of LLM application.

title: Caregiver-in-the-Loop AI: A Simulation-Based Feasibility Study for Dementia Task Verification
summary:
Caregivers of people living with dementia (PLwD) experience stress when
verifying whether tasks are truly completed, even with digital reminder
systems. Generative AI, such as GPT-4, may help by automating task verification
through follow-up questioning and decision support.
  This feasibility study evaluates an AI-powered task verification system
integrated with digital reminders for PLwD. It examines (1) GPT-4's ability to
generate effective follow-up questions, (2) the accuracy of an AI-driven
response flagging mechanism, and (3) the role of caregiver feedback in refining
system adaptability. A simulated pipeline was tested on 64 anonymized
reminders. GPT-4 generated follow-up questions with and without contextual
information about PLwD routines. Responses were classified into High, Medium,
or Low concern, and simulated caregiver feedback was used to refine outputs.
  Results show that contextual information and caregiver input improved the
clarity and relevance of AI-generated questions. The flagging system accurately
identified concerns, particularly for safety-critical tasks, though subjective
or non-urgent tasks remained challenging. Findings demonstrate the feasibility
of AI-assisted task verification in dementia care. Context-aware AI prompts and
caregiver feedback can enhance task monitoring, reduce caregiver stress, and
strengthen PLwD support. Future work should focus on real-world validation and
scalability.

AI.tldr: This feasibility study explores an AI-powered task verification system using GPT-4 for caregivers of people living with dementia, aiming to enhance task monitoring and reduce caregiver stress.
AI.motivation: Caregivers of people living with dementia face stress in verifying task completion, even with digital reminders; generative AI, like GPT-4, may alleviate this by automating task verification.
AI.method: The study tests a simulated pipeline with 64 anonymized reminders, assessing GPT-4's ability to generate effective follow-up questions, an AI-driven response flagging mechanism, and caregiver feedback for system adaptability.
AI.result: Contextual information and caregiver input improved AI-generated questions' clarity and relevance. The flagging system accurately identified safety-critical concerns, while subjective tasks posed challenges.
AI.conclusion: The study shows the feasibility of AI-assisted task verification in dementia care, indicating that context-aware prompts and caregiver feedback can enhance monitoring, reduce stress, and improve support for PLwD.
key_contributions: Demonstrated the use of GPT-4 for generating follow-up questions in dementia care.
Validated the effectiveness of an AI flagging mechanism for task concerns.
Highlighted the importance of caregiver feedback in refining AI output.
AI.limitations: Challenges remain for subjective or non-urgent tasks in accurately flagging concerns.

title: Towards Alignment-Centric Paradigm: A Survey of Instruction Tuning in Large Language Models
summary:
Instruction tuning is a pivotal technique for aligning large language models
(LLMs) with human intentions, safety constraints, and domain-specific
requirements. This survey provides a comprehensive overview of the full
pipeline, encompassing (i) data collection methodologies, (ii) full-parameter
and parameter-efficient fine-tuning strategies, and (iii) evaluation protocols.
We categorized data construction into three major paradigms: expert annotation,
distillation from larger models, and self-improvement mechanisms, each offering
distinct trade-offs between quality, scalability, and resource cost.
Fine-tuning techniques range from conventional supervised training to
lightweight approaches, such as low-rank adaptation (LoRA) and prefix tuning,
with a focus on computational efficiency and model reusability. We further
examine the challenges of evaluating faithfulness, utility, and safety across
multilingual and multimodal scenarios, highlighting the emergence of
domain-specific benchmarks in healthcare, legal, and financial applications.
Finally, we discuss promising directions for automated data generation,
adaptive optimization, and robust evaluation frameworks, arguing that a closer
integration of data, algorithms, and human feedback is essential for advancing
instruction-tuned LLMs. This survey aims to serve as a practical reference for
researchers and practitioners seeking to design LLMs that are both effective
and reliably aligned with human intentions.

AI.tldr: This survey reviews instruction tuning for large language models (LLMs), detailing data collection, fine-tuning strategies, and evaluation methods.
AI.motivation: To align LLMs with human intentions, safety, and domain-specific requirements, addressing the need for effective model adaptation and evaluation methods.
AI.method: The paper categorizes data construction methods and fine-tuning techniques, and it discusses evaluation protocols in multilingual and multimodal contexts.
AI.result: It identifies challenges and trade-offs in using different data collection and fine-tuning strategies, particularly in healthcare and other specific domains.
AI.conclusion: Integrating data, algorithms, and human feedback is crucial for enhancing instruction-tuned LLMs and ensuring their alignment with human needs.
key_contributions: Comprehensive categorization of data collection methodologies
Evaluation of fine-tuning strategies regarding efficiency
Discussion on domain-specific benchmarks and challenges in various applications
AI.limitations: The survey primarily focuses on existing methodologies without proposing novel techniques or solutions.

title: Active Domain Knowledge Acquisition with \$100 Budget: Enhancing LLMs via Cost-Efficient, Expert-Involved Interaction in Sensitive Domains
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated an impressive level of general
knowledge. However, they often struggle in highly specialized and
cost-sensitive domains such as drug discovery and rare disease research due to
the lack of expert knowledge. In this paper, we propose a novel framework
(PU-ADKA) designed to efficiently enhance domain-specific LLMs by actively
engaging domain experts within a fixed budget. Unlike traditional fine-tuning
approaches, PU-ADKA selectively identifies and queries the most appropriate
expert from a team, taking into account each expert's availability, knowledge
boundaries, and consultation costs. We train PU-ADKA using simulations on
PubMed data and validate it through both controlled expert interactions and
real-world deployment with a drug development team, demonstrating its
effectiveness in enhancing LLM performance in specialized domains under strict
budget constraints. In addition to outlining our methodological innovations and
experimental results, we introduce a new benchmark dataset, CKAD, for
cost-effective LLM domain knowledge acquisition to foster further research in
this challenging area.

AI.tldr: This paper presents PU-ADKA, a framework for improving domain-specific LLMs by efficiently engaging domain experts within a budget.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of LLMs in specialized fields like drug discovery and rare diseases due to the lack of expert knowledge.
AI.method: PU-ADKA actively queries the most suitable expert considering their availability, expertise, and cost, contrasting traditional fine-tuning methods.
AI.result: The framework was validated using PubMed data through simulations and controlled expert interactions, showing improved LLM performance in specialized domains with budget constraints.
AI.conclusion: PU-ADKA is effective in enhancing LLMs in specialized fields while maintaining cost efficiency, and a new benchmark dataset, CKAD, is introduced for ongoing research.
key_contributions: Development of PU-ADKA framework for expert engagement
Validation through real-world deployment in drug development
Introduction of benchmark dataset CKAD for LLM domain knowledge acquisition
AI.limitations: The focus is on budget constraints, which may limit generalizability to all LLM applications.

title: SSFO: Self-Supervised Faithfulness Optimization for Retrieval-Augmented Generation
summary:
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems require Large Language Models
(LLMs) to generate responses that are faithful to the retrieved context.
However, faithfulness hallucination remains a critical challenge, as existing
methods often require costly supervision and post-training or significant
inference burdens. To overcome these limitations, we introduce Self-Supervised
Faithfulness Optimization (SSFO), the first self-supervised alignment approach
for enhancing RAG faithfulness. SSFO constructs preference data pairs by
contrasting the model's outputs generated with and without the context.
Leveraging Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), SSFO aligns model faithfulness
without incurring labeling costs or additional inference burden. We
theoretically and empirically demonstrate that SSFO leverages a benign form of
\emph{likelihood displacement}, transferring probability mass from
parametric-based tokens to context-aligned tokens. Based on this insight, we
propose a modified DPO loss function to encourage likelihood displacement.
Comprehensive evaluations show that SSFO significantly outperforms existing
methods, achieving state-of-the-art faithfulness on multiple context-based
question-answering datasets. Notably, SSFO exhibits strong generalization,
improving cross-lingual faithfulness and preserving general
instruction-following capabilities. We release our code and model at the
anonymous link: https://github.com/chkwy/SSFO

AI.tldr: This paper introduces Self-Supervised Faithfulness Optimization (SSFO), a method to enhance the faithfulness of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems without costly labeling or additional inference burden.
AI.motivation: To address the critical challenge of faithfulness hallucination in RAG systems while minimizing supervision costs and inference demands.
AI.method: SSFO constructs preference data pairs by contrasting outputs from the model with and without context, using Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) to align model outputs.
AI.result: SSFO significantly outperforms existing methods, achieving state-of-the-art faithfulness across multiple context-based question-answering datasets, with strong generalization capabilities.
AI.conclusion: SSFO shows promise in improving faithfulness in RAG systems, with effective transfer of probability to context-aligned tokens, demonstrating its efficacy without added costs.
key_contributions: Introduction of Self-Supervised Faithfulness Optimization (SSFO) for RAG systems
Development of a modified DPO loss function to encourage likelihood displacement
Demonstration of strong generalization in faithfulness across languages and tasks.

title: ClaimGen-CN: A Large-scale Chinese Dataset for Legal Claim Generation
summary:
Legal claims refer to the plaintiff's demands in a case and are essential to
guiding judicial reasoning and case resolution. While many works have focused
on improving the efficiency of legal professionals, the research on helping
non-professionals (e.g., plaintiffs) remains unexplored. This paper explores
the problem of legal claim generation based on the given case's facts. First,
we construct ClaimGen-CN, the first dataset for Chinese legal claim generation
task, from various real-world legal disputes. Additionally, we design an
evaluation metric tailored for assessing the generated claims, which
encompasses two essential dimensions: factuality and clarity. Building on this,
we conduct a comprehensive zero-shot evaluation of state-of-the-art general and
legal-domain large language models. Our findings highlight the limitations of
the current models in factual precision and expressive clarity, pointing to the
need for more targeted development in this domain. To encourage further
exploration of this important task, we will make the dataset publicly
available.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces ClaimGen-CN, a dataset for generating legal claims and evaluates existing models' performance in this domain.
AI.motivation: To aid non-professionals in the legal domain, focusing on generating legal claims from case facts, an area that has been largely overlooked.
AI.method: Development of ClaimGen-CN dataset from real-world legal disputes and a tailored evaluation metric focusing on factuality and clarity; comprehensive zero-shot evaluation of various LLMs.
AI.result: Current models show limitations in factual precision and clarity in legal claim generation.
AI.conclusion: The findings indicate a need for improved models in legal claim generation and the dataset will be made publicly available to promote further research.
key_contributions: Introduction of ClaimGen-CN dataset for legal claim generation
Development of a nuanced evaluation metric
Zero-shot evaluation showcasing model limitations
AI.limitations: Focus on Chinese legal disputes may limit applicability to other jurisdictions.

title: Routing Distilled Knowledge via Mixture of LoRA Experts for Large Language Model based Bundle Generation
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown potential in automatic bundle
generation but suffer from prohibitive computational costs. Although knowledge
distillation offers a pathway to more efficient student models, our preliminary
study reveals that naively integrating diverse types of distilled knowledge
from teacher LLMs into student LLMs leads to knowledge conflict, negatively
impacting the performance of bundle generation. To address this, we propose
RouteDK, a framework for routing distilled knowledge through a mixture of LoRA
expert architecture. Specifically, we first distill knowledge from the teacher
LLM for bundle generation in two complementary types: high-level knowledge
(generalizable rules) and fine-grained knowledge (session-specific reasoning).
We then train knowledge-specific LoRA experts for each type of knowledge
together with a base LoRA expert. For effective integration, we propose a
dynamic fusion module, featuring an input-aware router, where the router
balances expert contributions by dynamically determining optimal weights based
on input, thereby effectively mitigating knowledge conflicts. To further
improve inference reliability, we design an inference-time enhancement module
to reduce variance and mitigate suboptimal reasoning. Experiments on three
public datasets show that our RouteDK achieves accuracy comparable to or even
better than the teacher LLM, while maintaining strong computational efficiency.
In addition, it outperforms state-of-the-art approaches for bundle generation.

AI.tldr: RouteDK is a framework for efficient bundle generation using distilled knowledge from large language models (LLMs) that mitigates knowledge conflict and improves performance through a dynamic routing mechanism.
AI.motivation: Large Language Models (LLMs) face high computational costs in bundle generation, and integrating diverse distilled knowledge often leads to conflicts that degrade performance.
AI.method: RouteDK utilizes a mixture of LoRA expert architecture to distill high-level and fine-grained knowledge from teacher LLMs and incorporates a dynamic fusion module for optimal knowledge integration.
AI.result: Experiments demonstrate that RouteDK achieves comparable or superior accuracy to the teacher LLM while being computationally efficient, outperforming existing methods for bundle generation.
AI.conclusion: RouteDK effectively reduces knowledge conflict in distilled knowledge integration and enhances bundle generation reliability and efficiency.
key_contributions: Introduction of RouteDK framework for knowledge routing in LLMs
Dynamic fusion module for balancing expert contributions
Improved inference reliability through a dedicated enhancement module

title: Are You Sure You're Positive? Consolidating Chain-of-Thought Agents with Uncertainty Quantification for Aspect-Category Sentiment Analysis
comment:
18 pages, 10 figures, 3 tables, Proceedings of the 1st Workshop for
  Research on Agent Language Models (REALM 2025)
summary:
Aspect-category sentiment analysis provides granular insights by identifying
specific themes within product reviews that are associated with particular
opinions. Supervised learning approaches dominate the field. However, data is
scarce and expensive to annotate for new domains. We argue that leveraging
large language models in a zero-shot setting is beneficial where the time and
resources required for dataset annotation are limited. Furthermore, annotation
bias may lead to strong results using supervised methods but transfer poorly to
new domains in contexts that lack annotations and demand reproducibility. In
our work, we propose novel techniques that combine multiple chain-of-thought
agents by leveraging large language models' token-level uncertainty scores. We
experiment with the 3B and 70B+ parameter size variants of Llama and Qwen
models, demonstrating how these approaches can fulfil practical needs and
opening a discussion on how to gauge accuracy in label-scarce conditions.

AI.tldr: This paper explores enhancing aspect-category sentiment analysis by employing large language models (LLMs) in a zero-shot setting to address issues of data scarcity and annotation bias.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to improve aspect-category sentiment analysis by using LLMs in scenarios where data annotation is limited and costly, and to discuss the reproducibility challenges of supervised methods.
AI.method: The authors propose novel techniques that integrate multiple chain-of-thought agents utilizing token-level uncertainty scores from LLMs, specifically experimenting with Llama and Qwen models.
AI.result: The experiments with Llama and Qwen models demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed techniques in improving sentiment analysis under label-scarce conditions.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest that combining multiple reasoning agents can meet practical needs within sentiment analysis, while also prompting a discussion on the assessment of accuracy in contexts with limited annotations.
key_contributions: Utilization of large language models in a zero-shot setting for sentiment analysis.
Introduction of novel techniques using token-level uncertainty scores.
Empirical evaluation of Llama and Qwen models in sentiment analysis tasks.
AI.limitations: The study may rely on specific model architectures which might not generalize to all sentiment analysis tasks.

title: From Language to Action: A Review of Large Language Models as Autonomous Agents and Tool Users
comment:
40 pages, 6 figures, 10 tables. Submitted to Artificial Intelligence
  Review for peer review
summary:
The pursuit of human-level artificial intelligence (AI) has significantly
advanced the development of autonomous agents and Large Language Models (LLMs).
LLMs are now widely utilized as decision-making agents for their ability to
interpret instructions, manage sequential tasks, and adapt through feedback.
This review examines recent developments in employing LLMs as autonomous agents
and tool users and comprises seven research questions. We only used the papers
published between 2023 and 2025 in conferences of the A* and A rank and Q1
journals. A structured analysis of the LLM agents' architectural design
principles, dividing their applications into single-agent and multi-agent
systems, and strategies for integrating external tools is presented. In
addition, the cognitive mechanisms of LLM, including reasoning, planning, and
memory, and the impact of prompting methods and fine-tuning procedures on agent
performance are also investigated. Furthermore, we evaluated current benchmarks
and assessment protocols and have provided an analysis of 68 publicly available
datasets to assess the performance of LLM-based agents in various tasks. In
conducting this review, we have identified critical findings on verifiable
reasoning of LLMs, the capacity for self-improvement, and the personalization
of LLM-based agents. Finally, we have discussed ten future research directions
to overcome these gaps.

AI.tldr: This review analyzes recent advancements in Large Language Models (LLMs) as autonomous agents, covering their design principles, cognitive mechanisms, performance benchmarks, and future research directions.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to synthesize recent advancements in using LLMs as decision-making agents and examine their performance and design principles.
AI.method: The review analyzes papers published between 2023 and 2025 in top conferences and journals, focusing on LLM agents' architecture, applications, cognitive mechanisms, and benchmarking protocols.
AI.result: Identified critical findings include insights on verifiable reasoning in LLMs, the self-improvement abilities of these agents, and the potential for personalization, based on an analysis of 68 datasets and various benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: The review concludes with ten proposed future research directions to bridge existing gaps in the field of LLM-based agents.
key_contributions: Structured analysis of LLM architectural design principles
Evaluation of cognitive mechanisms in LLMs
Assessment of LLM performance using publicly available datasets
AI.limitations: Focus is limited to papers published between 2023 and 2025; may not encompass the entirety of current knowledge in the field.

title: Handling Students Dropouts in an LLM-driven Interactive Online Course Using Language Models
summary:
Interactive online learning environments, represented by Massive AI-empowered
Courses (MAIC), leverage LLM-driven multi-agent systems to transform passive
MOOCs into dynamic, text-based platforms, enhancing interactivity through LLMs.
This paper conducts an empirical study on a specific MAIC course to explore
three research questions about dropouts in these interactive online courses:
(1) What factors might lead to dropouts? (2) Can we predict dropouts? (3) Can
we reduce dropouts? We analyze interaction logs to define dropouts and identify
contributing factors. Our findings reveal strong links between dropout
behaviors and textual interaction patterns. We then propose a
course-progress-adaptive dropout prediction framework (CPADP) to predict
dropouts with at most 95.4% accuracy. Based on this, we design a personalized
email recall agent to re-engage at-risk students. Applied in the deployed MAIC
system with over 3,000 students, the feasibility and effectiveness of our
approach have been validated on students with diverse backgrounds.

AI.tldr: This paper studies dropout factors in interactive online learning environments and proposes a dropout prediction framework to enhance student retention.
AI.motivation: To understand and mitigate dropout rates in Massive AI-empowered Courses (MAIC) using LLM-driven multi-agent systems.
AI.method: An empirical study analyzing interaction logs to define dropouts, identify contributing factors, and implement a dropout prediction framework (CPADP).
AI.result: The proposed CPADP predicts dropouts with up to 95.4% accuracy and includes a personalized email recall agent for at-risk students.
AI.conclusion: The approach shows feasibility and effectiveness in a MAIC system with over 3,000 students, indicating potential for improving retention in online courses.
key_contributions: Development of a course-progress-adaptive dropout prediction framework (CPADP)
Identification of strong links between dropout behavior and interaction patterns
Implementation of a personalized recall agent for at-risk students

title: CultranAI at PalmX 2025: Data Augmentation for Cultural Knowledge Representation
comment:
LLMs, Native, Arabic LLMs, Augmentation, Multilingual, Language
  Diversity, Contextual Understanding, Minority Languages, Culturally Informed,
  Foundation Models, Large Language Models
summary:
In this paper, we report our participation to the PalmX cultural evaluation
shared task. Our system, CultranAI, focused on data augmentation and LoRA
fine-tuning of large language models (LLMs) for Arabic cultural knowledge
representation. We benchmarked several LLMs to identify the best-performing
model for the task. In addition to utilizing the PalmX dataset, we augmented it
by incorporating the Palm dataset and curated a new dataset of over 22K
culturally grounded multiple-choice questions (MCQs). Our experiments showed
that the Fanar-1-9B-Instruct model achieved the highest performance. We
fine-tuned this model on the combined augmented dataset of 22K+ MCQs. On the
blind test set, our submitted system ranked 5th with an accuracy of 70.50%,
while on the PalmX development set, it achieved an accuracy of 84.1%.

AI.tldr: This paper presents CultranAI, a system focused on data augmentation and fine-tuning LLMs for Arabic cultural knowledge, achieving notable benchmark results with a new dataset of multiple-choice questions.
AI.motivation: The goal of the research is to improve the representation of Arabic cultural knowledge in large language models by creating a robust dataset and identifying the best-performing models for this task.
AI.method: The researchers employed data augmentation techniques and LoRA fine-tuning on various large language models, specifically focusing on creating and utilizing a new dataset of over 22,000 culturally grounded MCQs.
AI.result: The Fanar-1-9B-Instruct model achieved the highest performance among the tested models, with an accuracy of 70.50% on the blind test set and 84.1% on the PalmX development set after fine-tuning with the augmented dataset.
AI.conclusion: CultranAI demonstrates the effectiveness of data augmentation and fine-tuning for enhancing LLM performance in culturally specific contexts, particularly for Arabic language understanding.
key_contributions: Introduction of a new dataset of over 22K culturally grounded MCQs
Benchmarking of multiple LLMs for Arabic cultural knowledge representation
Successful application of LoRA fine-tuning for improved model performance
AI.limitations: Limited to the evaluation of specific LLMs and the focus on Arabic cultural knowledge, which may not generalize to all contexts or languages.

title: The Power of Framing: How News Headlines Guide Search Behavior
summary:
Search engines play a central role in how people gather information, but
subtle cues like headline framing may influence not only what users believe but
also how they search. While framing effects on judgment are well documented,
their impact on subsequent search behavior is less understood. We conducted a
controlled experiment where participants issued queries and selected from
headlines filtered by specific linguistic frames. Headline framing
significantly shaped follow-up queries: conflict and strategy frames disrupted
alignment with prior selections, while episodic frames led to more concrete
queries than thematic ones. We also observed modest short-term frame
persistence that declined over time. These results suggest that even brief
exposure to framing can meaningfully alter the direction of users
information-seeking behavior.

AI.tldr: The study investigates how headline framing influences users' search behavior in a controlled experiment, revealing significant effects on query alignment and query specificity.
AI.motivation: Understanding how subtle cues like headline framing impact users' search behavior and information gathering is crucial for optimizing search engines and information retrieval.
AI.method: Conducted a controlled experiment where participants issued search queries and made selections from headlines framed in specific linguistic ways.
AI.result: Headline framing significantly influenced follow-up queries, with conflict and strategy frames disrupting alignment with prior selections, while episodic frames led to more concrete queries than thematic ones.
AI.conclusion: The findings indicate that even short exposures to framing can alter users' information-seeking behavior, suggesting implications for search engine design and information presentation.
key_contributions: Demonstrated that headline framing impacts search query behavior
Identified specific framing effects (conflict, strategy, episodic) on query alignment and specificity
Provided insights into the persistence of framing effects over time
AI.limitations: Limited to short-term effects; further research needed for long-term implications and real-world applications.

title: Omne-R1: Learning to Reason with Memory for Multi-hop Question Answering
summary:
This paper introduces Omne-R1, a novel approach designed to enhance multi-hop
question answering capabilities on schema-free knowledge graphs by integrating
advanced reasoning models. Our method employs a multi-stage training workflow,
including two reinforcement learning phases and one supervised fine-tuning
phase. We address the challenge of limited suitable knowledge graphs and QA
data by constructing domain-independent knowledge graphs and auto-generating QA
pairs. Experimental results show significant improvements in answering
multi-hop questions, with notable performance gains on more complex 3+ hop
questions. Our proposed training framework demonstrates strong generalization
abilities across diverse knowledge domains.

AI.tldr: Omne-R1 enhances multi-hop question answering on schema-free knowledge graphs through advanced reasoning models and a unique training workflow.
AI.motivation: The need for effective multi-hop question answering capabilities on schema-free knowledge graphs, particularly due to the scarcity of suitable knowledge graphs and question-answering data.
AI.method: The proposed method consists of a multi-stage training workflow involving two phases of reinforcement learning followed by a supervised fine-tuning phase to improve the model's performance in answering multi-hop questions.
AI.result: Experimental results indicate significant improvements in answering multi-hop questions, especially those involving more than three hops, demonstrating strong performance across various knowledge domains.
AI.conclusion: The Omne-R1 training framework showcases the potential for generalization in answering complex questions across different domains.
key_contributions: Introduction of a multi-stage training workflow for QA
Construction of domain-independent knowledge graphs
Auto-generation of QA pairs for training

title: DropLoRA: Sparse Low-Rank Adaptation for Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning
summary:
LoRA-based large model parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) methods use
low-rank de- composition to approximate updates to model parameters. However,
compared to full- parameter fine-tuning, low-rank updates often lead to a
performance gap in downstream tasks. To address this, we introduce DropLoRA, a
novel pruning-based approach that focuses on pruning the rank dimension. Unlike
conven- tional methods that attempt to overcome the low-rank bottleneck,
DropLoRA innovatively integrates a pruning module between the two low-rank
matrices in LoRA to simulate dy- namic subspace learning. This dynamic low-
rank subspace learning allows DropLoRA to overcome the limitations of
traditional LoRA, which operates within a static subspace. By continuously
adapting the learning subspace, DropLoRA significantly boosts performance
without incurring additional training or infer- ence costs. Our experimental
results demon- strate that DropLoRA consistently outperforms LoRA in
fine-tuning the LLaMA series across a wide range of large language model gener-
ation tasks, including commonsense reason- ing, mathematical reasoning, code
generation, and instruction-following. Our code is avail- able at
https://github.com/TayeeChang/DropLoRA.

AI.tldr: DropLoRA enhances parameter-efficient fine-tuning methods for large models by integrating a dynamic pruning mechanism, overcoming limitations of traditional LoRA approaches.
AI.motivation: To bridge the performance gap observed in downstream tasks when using low-rank updates in traditional LoRA-based parameter-efficient fine-tuning methods.
AI.method: DropLoRA introduces a pruning module between the low-rank matrices in LoRA to simulate dynamic subspace learning, allowing for adaptive subspace changes during training.
AI.result: DropLoRA significantly outperforms conventional LoRA in various tasks such as commonsense reasoning, mathematical reasoning, code generation, and instruction-following when fine-tuning the LLaMA model series.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic low-rank subspace learning in DropLoRA leads to improved performance without added computational costs.
key_contributions: Introduction of a pruning module to enhance dynamic learning
Substantial performance improvements over traditional LoRA
Application across a variety of language model tasks

title: Capturing Legal Reasoning Paths from Facts to Law in Court Judgments using Knowledge Graphs
summary:
Court judgments reveal how legal rules have been interpreted and applied to
facts, providing a foundation for understanding structured legal reasoning.
However, existing automated approaches for capturing legal reasoning, including
large language models, often fail to identify the relevant legal context, do
not accurately trace how facts relate to legal norms, and may misrepresent the
layered structure of judicial reasoning. These limitations hinder the ability
to capture how courts apply the law to facts in practice. In this paper, we
address these challenges by constructing a legal knowledge graph from 648
Japanese administrative court decisions. Our method extracts components of
legal reasoning using prompt-based large language models, normalizes references
to legal provisions, and links facts, norms, and legal applications through an
ontology of legal inference. The resulting graph captures the full structure of
legal reasoning as it appears in real court decisions, making implicit
reasoning explicit and machine-readable. We evaluate our system using expert
annotated data, and find that it achieves more accurate retrieval of relevant
legal provisions from facts than large language model baselines and
retrieval-augmented methods.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a method for constructing a legal knowledge graph from Japanese administrative court decisions to improve the automation of legal reasoning.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to improve the automation of legal reasoning by addressing the limitations of existing models in capturing legal context and the relationship between facts and legal norms.
AI.method: The authors construct a legal knowledge graph from 648 Japanese court decisions, using prompt-based large language models to extract legal reasoning components and linking facts, norms, and applications through an ontology.
AI.result: The system demonstrates improved accuracy in retrieving relevant legal provisions from facts compared to existing large language models and retrieval-augmented methods.
AI.conclusion: The legal knowledge graph effectively captures the layered structure of judicial reasoning, making implicit reasoning explicit and machine-readable.
key_contributions: Development of a legal knowledge graph from court decisions
Improved extraction of legal reasoning using LLMs
Mapping of legal norms to facts through ontology

title: The Arabic Generality Score: Another Dimension of Modeling Arabic Dialectness
summary:
Arabic dialects form a diverse continuum, yet NLP models often treat them as
discrete categories. Recent work addresses this issue by modeling dialectness
as a continuous variable, notably through the Arabic Level of Dialectness
(ALDi). However, ALDi reduces complex variation to a single dimension. We
propose a complementary measure: the Arabic Generality Score (AGS), which
quantifies how widely a word is used across dialects. We introduce a pipeline
that combines word alignment, etymology-aware edit distance, and smoothing to
annotate a parallel corpus with word-level AGS. A regression model is then
trained to predict AGS in context. Our approach outperforms strong baselines,
including state-of-the-art dialect ID systems, on a multi-dialect benchmark.
AGS offers a scalable, linguistically grounded way to model lexical generality,
enriching representations of Arabic dialectness.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the Arabic Generality Score (AGS), a metric for quantifying word usage across Arabic dialects, improving upon the existing Arabic Level of Dialectness (ALDi) by providing a multi-dimensional approach to dialect variation.
AI.motivation: To address the inadequacy of existing NLP models that treat Arabic dialects as discrete categories and to provide a more nuanced understanding of lexical variation in Arabic.
AI.method: The paper proposes a new measure called the Arabic Generality Score (AGS) which uses word alignment, etymology-aware edit distance, and smoothing techniques to annotate a parallel corpus. A regression model is trained to predict AGS in context.
AI.result: The proposed AGS method shows superior performance compared to strong baselines and state-of-the-art dialect identification systems on a multi-dialect benchmark.
AI.conclusion: AGS provides a linguistically grounded and scalable method for modeling lexical generality, enriching the understanding of Arabic dialectness.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Arabic Generality Score (AGS) as a new measure for dialect analysis.
Development of a pipeline for annotating a parallel corpus with AGS using advanced techniques.
Demonstrated improved performance on dialect-related tasks compared to existing models.

title: UI-Level Evaluation of ALLaM 34B: Measuring an Arabic-Centric LLM via HUMAIN Chat
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) trained primarily on English corpora often
struggle to capture the linguistic and cultural nuances of Arabic. To address
this gap, the Saudi Data and AI Authority (SDAIA) introduced the $ALLaM$ family
of Arabic-focused models. The most capable of these available to the public,
$ALLaM-34B$, was subsequently adopted by HUMAIN, who developed and deployed
HUMAIN Chat, a closed conversational web service built on this model. This
paper presents an expanded and refined UI-level evaluation of $ALLaM-34B$.
Using a prompt pack spanning modern standard Arabic, five regional dialects,
code-switching, factual knowledge, arithmetic and temporal reasoning, creative
generation, and adversarial safety, we collected 115 outputs (23 prompts times
5 runs) and scored each with three frontier LLM judges (GPT-5, Gemini 2.5 Pro,
Claude Sonnet-4). We compute category-level means with 95\% confidence
intervals, analyze score distributions, and visualize dialect-wise metric heat
maps. The updated analysis reveals consistently high performance on generation
and code-switching tasks (both averaging 4.92/5), alongside strong results in
MSA handling (4.74/5), solid reasoning ability (4.64/5), and improved dialect
fidelity (4.21/5). Safety-related prompts show stable, reliable performance of
(4.54/5). Taken together, these results position $ALLaM-34B$ as a robust and
culturally grounded Arabic LLM, demonstrating both technical strength and
practical readiness for real-world deployment.

AI.tldr: Evaluation of the Arabic LLM ALLaM-34B shows strong performance across multiple tasks, highlighting its readiness for deployment.
AI.motivation: To address performance gaps of large language models (LLMs) in understanding Arabic linguistic and cultural nuances.
AI.method: UI-level evaluation using a diverse prompt pack and assessments from three LLM judges to score outputs in multiple categories.
AI.result: ALLaM-34B demonstrated high performance across tasks, with averages of 4.92/5 in generation and code-switching, and strong scores in MSA handling, reasoning ability, and safety.
AI.conclusion: ALLaM-34B is positioned as a robust and culturally adept Arabic LLM suitable for real-world applications.
key_contributions: Evaluation of ALLaM-34B's capabilities across different Arabic varieties and tasks
Use of multiple judges for scoring to enhance reliability

title: DiscussLLM: Teaching Large Language Models When to Speak
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in
understanding and generating human-like text, yet they largely operate as
reactive agents, responding only when directly prompted. This passivity creates
an "awareness gap," limiting their potential as truly collaborative partners in
dynamic human discussions. We introduce $\textit{DiscussLLM}$, a framework
designed to bridge this gap by training models to proactively decide not just
$\textit{what}$ to say, but critically, $\textit{when}$ to speak. Our primary
contribution is a scalable two-stage data generation pipeline that synthesizes
a large-scale dataset of realistic multi-turn human discussions. Each
discussion is annotated with one of five intervention types (e.g., Factual
Correction, Concept Definition) and contains an explicit conversational trigger
where an AI intervention adds value. By training models to predict a special
silent token when no intervention is needed, they learn to remain quiet until a
helpful contribution can be made. We explore two architectural baselines: an
integrated end-to-end model and a decoupled classifier-generator system
optimized for low-latency inference. We evaluate these models on their ability
to accurately time interventions and generate helpful responses, paving the way
for more situationally aware and proactive conversational AI.

AI.tldr: DiscussLLM is a framework that trains large language models to proactively decide when to join discussions, aiming to create more effective conversational AI by reducing intervention time and enhancing human-like interaction.
AI.motivation: To address the awareness gap in large language models, which limits their effectiveness in collaborative human discussions.
AI.method: The authors introduce DiscussLLM, utilizing a two-stage data generation pipeline to create a large dataset of annotated human discussions, and propose two architectural approaches for model training.
AI.result: Models trained with DiscussLLM can accurately time their interventions, leading to improved helpfulness in responses and greater situational awareness in conversations.
AI.conclusion: The framework opens new possibilities for proactive interaction in conversational AI, enhancing models' ability to contribute meaningfully in dynamic discussions.
key_contributions: Introduction of DiscussLLM framework for proactive LLM interaction
Creation of a large-scale dataset of annotated discussions
Evaluation of various architectural models for timing interventions

title: Agent-Testing Agent: A Meta-Agent for Automated Testing and Evaluation of Conversational AI Agents
summary:
LLM agents are increasingly deployed to plan, retrieve, and write with tools,
yet evaluation still leans on static benchmarks and small human studies. We
present the Agent-Testing Agent (ATA), a meta-agent that combines static code
analysis, designer interrogation, literature mining, and persona-driven
adversarial test generation whose difficulty adapts via judge feedback. Each
dialogue is scored with an LLM-as-a-Judge (LAAJ) rubric and used to steer
subsequent tests toward the agent's weakest capabilities. On a travel planner
and a Wikipedia writer, the ATA surfaces more diverse and severe failures than
expert annotators while matching severity, and finishes in 20--30 minutes
versus ten-annotator rounds that took days. Ablating code analysis and web
search increases variance and miscalibration, underscoring the value of
evidence-grounded test generation. The ATA outputs quantitative metrics and
qualitative bug reports for developers. We release the full methodology and
open-source implementation for reproducible agent testing:
https://github.com/KhalilMrini/Agent-Testing-Agent

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the Agent-Testing Agent (ATA), a meta-agent for evaluating LLM agents through dynamic adversarial testing that utilizes feedback to adapt the test difficulty, outperforming traditional human assessments in efficiency and diversity of failure detection.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of existing evaluation methods for LLM agents, which rely on static benchmarks and limited human studies.
AI.method: The ATA employs static code analysis, designer interrogation, literature mining, and persona-driven adversarial test generation, adapting test difficulty based on judge feedback from an LLM-as-a-Judge (LAAJ) rubric.
AI.result: The ATA demonstrated superior detection of diverse and severe failures compared to expert annotators, achieving results in significantly less time (20-30 minutes) than multiple human assessments that took days.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights the effectiveness of evidence-grounded test generation and offers quantitative metrics along with qualitative bug reports for developers, with an open-source implementation available for reproducibility.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Agent-Testing Agent (ATA) framework
Dynamic feedback-driven adversarial test generation
Open-source implementation for reproducible testing
AI.limitations: The impact of ablation studies indicated increased variance and miscalibration without static analysis and web searches.

title: DashboardQA: Benchmarking Multimodal Agents for Question Answering on Interactive Dashboards
summary:
Dashboards are powerful visualization tools for data-driven decision-making,
integrating multiple interactive views that allow users to explore, filter, and
navigate data. Unlike static charts, dashboards support rich interactivity,
which is essential for uncovering insights in real-world analytical workflows.
However, existing question-answering benchmarks for data visualizations largely
overlook this interactivity, focusing instead on static charts. This limitation
severely constrains their ability to evaluate the capabilities of modern
multimodal agents designed for GUI-based reasoning. To address this gap, we
introduce DashboardQA, the first benchmark explicitly designed to assess how
vision-language GUI agents comprehend and interact with real-world dashboards.
The benchmark includes 112 interactive dashboards from Tableau Public and 405
question-answer pairs with interactive dashboards spanning five categories:
multiple-choice, factoid, hypothetical, multi-dashboard, and conversational. By
assessing a variety of leading closed- and open-source GUI agents, our analysis
reveals their key limitations, particularly in grounding dashboard elements,
planning interaction trajectories, and performing reasoning. Our findings
indicate that interactive dashboard reasoning is a challenging task overall for
all the VLMs evaluated. Even the top-performing agents struggle; for instance,
the best agent based on Gemini-Pro-2.5 achieves only 38.69% accuracy, while the
OpenAI CUA agent reaches just 22.69%, demonstrating the benchmark's significant
difficulty. We release DashboardQA at https://github.com/vis-nlp/DashboardQA

AI.tldr: DashboardQA is a new benchmark for evaluating vision-language GUI agents on interactive dashboards, addressing a gap in existing question-answering benchmarks that focus on static charts.
AI.motivation: Existing question-answering benchmarks for data visualizations fail to capture interactivity, which is essential for modern analytical workflows and multimodal agent evaluation.
AI.method: The benchmark introduces 112 interactive dashboards and 405 question-answer pairs covering multiple question types to analyze various leading GUI agents.
AI.result: Analysis shows significant limitations in grounding dashboard elements and performing interactive reasoning, with top agents only achieving up to 38.69% accuracy.
AI.conclusion: DashboardQA highlights the challenges in interactive dashboard reasoning for VLMs and aims to spur improvements in this area.
key_contributions: Introduction of the first benchmark for interactive dashboard reasoning
Inclusion of diverse question formats
Extensive evaluation of leading vision-language models
AI.limitations: The study shows that even the best models struggle significantly, indicating an overall challenge in the task of interactive dashboard reasoning.

title: Legacy Learning Strategy Based on Few-Shot Font Generation Models for Automatic Text Design in Metaverse Content
summary:
The metaverse consists of hardware, software, and content, among which text
design plays a critical role in enhancing user immersion and usability as a
content element. However, in languages such as Korean and Chinese that require
thousands of unique glyphs, creating new text designs involves high costs and
complexity. To address this, this study proposes a training strategy called
Legacy Learning, which recombines and transforms structures based on existing
text design models. This approach enables the generation of new text designs
and improves quality without manual design processes. To evaluate Legacy
Learning, it was applied to Korean and Chinese text designs. Additionally, we
compared results before and after on seven state of the art text generation
models. As a result, text designs generated using Legacy Learning showed over a
30% difference in Frechet Inception Distance (FID) and Learned Perceptual Image
Patch Similarity (LPIPS) metrics compared to the originals, and also exhibited
meaningful style variations in visual comparisons. Furthermore, the repeated
learning process improved the structural consistency of the generated
characters, and an OCR based evaluation showed increasing recognition accuracy
across iterations, indicating improved legibility of the generated glyphs. In
addition, a System Usability Scale (SUS) survey was conducted to evaluate
