usability among metaverse content designers and general users. The expert group
recorded a score of 95.78 ("Best Imaginable"), while the non expert group
scored 76.42 ("Excellent"), indicating an overall high level of usability.
These results suggest that Legacy Learning can significantly improve both the
production efficiency and quality of text design in the metaverse environment.

AI.tldr: The study introduces Legacy Learning, a training strategy for efficient text design generation in Korean and Chinese, enhancing quality and usability in the metaverse.
AI.motivation: Address the high costs and complexity of creating new text designs in Korean and Chinese, which require numerous unique glyphs.
AI.method: The authors proposed a training strategy called Legacy Learning that recombines and transforms existing text design models to generate new designs without manual processes.
AI.result: The use of Legacy Learning showed over a 30% improvement in FID and LPIPS metrics and increased OCR recognition accuracy, demonstrating better quality and usability.
AI.conclusion: Legacy Learning can significantly enhance efficiency and quality in the production of text designs for metaverse applications.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Legacy Learning training strategy
Demonstrated improvement in text design quality metrics
High usability scores from both experts and general users

title: DS@GT at CheckThat! 2025: A Simple Retrieval-First, LLM-Backed Framework for Claim Normalization
summary:
Claim normalization is an integral part of any automatic fact-check
verification system. It parses the typically noisy claim data, such as social
media posts into normalized claims, which are then fed into downstream veracity
classification tasks. The CheckThat! 2025 Task 2 focuses specifically on claim
normalization and spans 20 languages under monolingual and zero-shot
conditions. Our proposed solution consists of a lightweight
\emph{retrieval-first, LLM-backed} pipeline, in which we either dynamically
prompt a GPT-4o-mini with in-context examples, or retrieve the closest
normalization from the train dataset directly. On the official test set, the
system ranks near the top for most monolingual tracks, achieving first place in
7 out of of the 13 languages. In contrast, the system underperforms in the
zero-shot setting, highlighting the limitation of the proposed solution.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a claim normalization system using a retrieval-first, LLM-backed pipeline for fact-checking across 20 languages.
AI.motivation: To improve automatic fact-check verification systems by normalizing noisy claim data from sources like social media.
AI.method: The system utilizes a lightweight pipeline that either prompts a GPT-4o-mini model with examples or retrieves normalization from the training dataset.
AI.result: The solution ranks highly on the official test set, achieving first place in 7 out of 13 languages for monolingual tracks but underperforming in zero-shot settings.
AI.conclusion: While effective in monolingual cases, the system's limitations in zero-shot scenarios indicate areas for improvement in generalization.
key_contributions: Introduction of a retrieval-first, LLM-backed normalization pipeline.
Achievement of top rankings in multiple languages for monolingual claim normalization.
Demonstration of challenges in zero-shot normalization tasks.
AI.limitations: Underperformance in zero-shot settings.

title: MAVIL: Design of a Multidimensional Assessment of Visual Data Literacy and its Application in a Representative Survey
summary:
The ability to read, interpret, and critique data visualizations has mainly
been assessed using data visualization tasks like value retrieval. Although
evidence on different facets of Visual Data Literacy (VDL) is well established
in visualization research and includes numeracy, graph familiarity, or
aesthetic elements, they have not been sufficiently considered in ability
assessments. Here, VDL is considered a multidimensional ability whose facets
can be partially self-assessed. We introduce an assessment in which VDL is
deconstructed as a process of understanding, in reference to frameworks from
the learning sciences. MAVIL, Multidimensional Assessment of Visual Data
Literacy, is composed of six ability dimensions: General Impression/Abstract
Thinking, Graph Elements/Familiarity, Aesthetic Perception, Visualization
Criticism, Data Reading Tasks and Numeracy/Topic Knowledge. MAVIL was designed
for general audiences and implemented in a survey (n=438), representative of
Austria's age groups (18-74 years) and gender split. The survey mirrors the
population's VDL and shows the perception of two climate data visualizations, a
line and bar chart. We found that 48% of respondents make mistakes with the
simple charts, while 5% believe that they cannot summarize the visualization
content. About a quarter have deficits in comprehending simple data units, and
19-20% are unfamiliar with each displayed chart type.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the Multidimensional Assessment of Visual Data Literacy (MAVIL), assessing various dimensions of visual data literacy through a survey, revealing significant misunderstandings among general audiences.
AI.motivation: The assessment of Visual Data Literacy (VDL) has not adequately addressed its multidimensionality, which encompasses various facets such as numeracy and graph familiarity.
AI.method: A survey was conducted with 438 participants to evaluate their visual data literacy across six dimensions: General Impression/Abstract Thinking, Graph Elements/Familiarity, Aesthetic Perception, Visualization Criticism, Data Reading Tasks, and Numeracy/Topic Knowledge.
AI.result: The survey indicated that 48% of participants made mistakes with simple charts, with significant deficits in understanding basic data units and unfamiliarity with chart types being prevalent.
AI.conclusion: There is a clear need for improved data literacy among the population, indicated by the survey results. The MAVIL framework can help assess and develop visual data literacy over multiple dimensions.
key_contributions: Introduction of MAVIL as a framework for assessing Visual Data Literacy
Identified significant deficits in public understanding of data visualizations
Survey results highlighting areas for educational improvement in VDL
AI.limitations: The study is limited to a specific demographic in Austria, which may affect generalizability.

title: MahaParaphrase: A Marathi Paraphrase Detection Corpus and BERT-based Models
summary:
Paraphrases are a vital tool to assist language understanding tasks such as
question answering, style transfer, semantic parsing, and data augmentation
tasks. Indic languages are complex in natural language processing (NLP) due to
their rich morphological and syntactic variations, diverse scripts, and limited
availability of annotated data. In this work, we present the
L3Cube-MahaParaphrase Dataset, a high-quality paraphrase corpus for Marathi, a
low resource Indic language, consisting of 8,000 sentence pairs, each annotated
by human experts as either Paraphrase (P) or Non-paraphrase (NP). We also
present the results of standard transformer-based BERT models on these
datasets. The dataset and model are publicly shared at
https://github.com/l3cube-pune/MarathiNLP

AI.tldr: The paper presents a high-quality paraphrase corpus for Marathi, aimed at improving NLP tasks in Indic languages.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges faced in NLP tasks for Indic languages like Marathi, which suffer from limited annotated data and complexity in morphology and syntax.
AI.method: Introduction of the L3Cube-MahaParaphrase Dataset composed of 8,000 human-annotated sentence pairs classified as Paraphrase or Non-paraphrase, along with evaluation of standard transformer-based BERT models on this dataset.
AI.result: The BERT models provide insights into performance on the paraphrase detection task using the new dataset.
AI.conclusion: The L3Cube-MahaParaphrase Dataset is a valuable resource for advancing NLP research in low-resource Indic languages, supporting tasks such as question answering and data augmentation.
key_contributions: Introduction of the L3Cube-MahaParaphrase Dataset for Marathi
Human annotation providing high-quality paraphrase labels
Evaluation of BERT model performance on Marathi paraphrase detection

title: Persuasion Dynamics in LLMs: Investigating Robustness and Adaptability in Knowledge and Safety with DuET-PD
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) can struggle to balance gullibility to
misinformation and resistance to valid corrections in persuasive dialogues, a
critical challenge for reliable deployment. We introduce DuET-PD (Dual
Evaluation for Trust in Persuasive Dialogues), a framework evaluating
multi-turn stance-change dynamics across dual dimensions: persuasion type
(corrective/misleading) and domain (knowledge via MMLU-Pro, and safety via
SALAD-Bench). We find that even a state-of-the-art model like GPT-4o achieves
only 27.32% accuracy in MMLU-Pro under sustained misleading persuasions.
Moreover, results reveal a concerning trend of increasing sycophancy in newer
open-source models. To address this, we introduce Holistic DPO, a training
approach balancing positive and negative persuasion examples. Unlike prompting
or resist-only training, Holistic DPO enhances both robustness to
misinformation and receptiveness to corrections, improving
Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct's accuracy under misleading persuasion in safety contexts
from 4.21% to 76.54%. These contributions offer a pathway to developing more
reliable and adaptable LLMs for multi-turn dialogue. Code is available at
https://github.com/Social-AI-Studio/DuET-PD.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces DuET-PD, a framework for evaluating Large Language Models (LLMs) in persuasive dialogues and presents a new training method called Holistic DPO to improve their reliability.
AI.motivation: Improving the reliability of LLMs in handling persuasive dialogues by addressing their issues with gullibility to misinformation and resistance to valid corrections.
AI.method: The authors developed DuET-PD for evaluation of stance-change dynamics based on persuasion type and domain, and introduced Holistic DPO as a training method to enhance model robustness against misinformation and improve receptiveness to corrections.
AI.result: The study found that GPT-4o achieved only 27.32% accuracy in MMLU-Pro under misleading persuasions. The Holistic DPO method increased accuracy for Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct under misleading persuasion from 4.21% to 76.54%.
AI.conclusion: The findings indicate a need for improved training approaches to create more reliable and adaptable LLMs for multi-turn dialogues, as evidenced by the effectiveness of Holistic DPO.
key_contributions: Introduction of DuET-PD framework for evaluating LLMs in persuasive dialogues.
Development of Holistic DPO training method that balances positive and negative persuasion examples.
Significant improvement in Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct's performance in safety contexts.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Verbal Multiword Expressions on Machine Translation
summary:
Verbal multiword expressions (VMWEs) present significant challenges for
natural language processing due to their complex and often non-compositional
nature. While machine translation models have seen significant improvement with
the advent of language models in recent years, accurately translating these
complex linguistic structures remains an open problem. In this study, we
analyze the impact of three VMWE categories -- verbal idioms, verb-particle
constructions, and light verb constructions -- on machine translation quality
from English to multiple languages. Using both established multiword expression
datasets and sentences containing these language phenomena extracted from
machine translation datasets, we evaluate how state-of-the-art translation
systems handle these expressions. Our experimental results consistently show
that VMWEs negatively affect translation quality. We also propose an LLM-based
paraphrasing approach that replaces these expressions with their literal
counterparts, demonstrating significant improvement in translation quality for
verbal idioms and verb-particle constructions.

AI.tldr: This study examines the challenges posed by verbal multiword expressions (VMWEs) in machine translation and proposes an LLM-based paraphrasing method to improve translation quality.
AI.motivation: To address the ongoing challenges in accurately translating verbal multiword expressions (VMWEs) due to their complex, non-compositional nature in natural language processing.
AI.method: The study evaluates the impact of verbal idioms, verb-particle constructions, and light verb constructions on machine translation quality using datasets with these expressions in the context of state-of-the-art translation systems.
AI.result: Experimental results highlight that VMWEs negatively affect translation quality, but an LLM-based approach to paraphrasing these expressions shows significant improvements, particularly for verbal idioms and verb-particle constructions.
AI.conclusion: LLM-based paraphrasing provides a promising solution for enhancing translation quality in the presence of difficult verbal multiword expressions.
key_contributions: Evaluation of three categories of VMWEs in machine translation
Demonstration of negative impact on translation quality
Development of an LLM-based paraphrasing method that improves translation outcomes

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Long Document Classification by Reducing Context Through Sentence Ranking
summary:
Transformer-based models like BERT excel at short text classification but
struggle with long document classification (LDC) due to input length
limitations and computational inefficiencies. In this work, we propose an
efficient, zero-shot approach to LDC that leverages sentence ranking to reduce
input context without altering the model architecture. Our method enables the
adaptation of models trained on short texts, such as headlines, to long-form
documents by selecting the most informative sentences using a TF-IDF-based
ranking strategy. Using the MahaNews dataset of long Marathi news articles, we
evaluate three context reduction strategies that prioritize essential content
while preserving classification accuracy. Our results show that retaining only
the top 50\% ranked sentences maintains performance comparable to full-document
inference while reducing inference time by up to 35\%. This demonstrates that
sentence ranking is a simple yet effective technique for scalable and efficient
zero-shot LDC.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a method for long document classification (LDC) using sentence ranking to efficiently select content while preserving accuracy.
AI.motivation: Transformer models like BERT face challenges in long document classification due to length limitations and computational costs. There's a need for efficient methods to adapt short text models for LDC.
AI.method: The proposed method uses a zero-shot approach to LDC by employing a TF-IDF-based ranking strategy to select the most informative sentences from documents, reducing the input context without changing the model architecture.
AI.result: The evaluation on the MahaNews dataset indicates that retaining the top 50% of ranked sentences keeps classification accuracy similar to using full documents, while reducing inference time by up to 35%.
AI.conclusion: The findings show that sentence ranking is a viable technique for efficient and scalable long document classification without sacrificing performance.
key_contributions: Introduces a zero-shot approach for long document classification using sentence ranking.
Demonstrates the effectiveness of TF-IDF for selecting informative sentences.
Shows significant reduction in inference time while maintaining classification performance.

title: Improving French Synthetic Speech Quality via SSML Prosody Control
comment:
13 pages, 9 figures, 6 tables. Accepted for presentation at ICNLSP
  2025 (Odense, Denmark). Code and demo:
  https://github.com/hi-paris/Prosody-Control-French-TTS. ACM Class: I.2.7;
  H.5.5
summary:
Despite recent advances, synthetic voices often lack expressiveness due to
limited prosody control in commercial text-to-speech (TTS) systems. We
introduce the first end-to-end pipeline that inserts Speech Synthesis Markup
Language (SSML) tags into French text to control pitch, speaking rate, volume,
and pause duration. We employ a cascaded architecture with two QLoRA-fine-tuned
Qwen 2.5-7B models: one predicts phrase-break positions and the other performs
regression on prosodic targets, generating commercial TTS-compatible SSML
markup. Evaluated on a 14-hour French podcast corpus, our method achieves 99.2%
F1 for break placement and reduces mean absolute error on pitch, rate, and
volume by 25-40% compared with prompting-only large language models (LLMs) and
a BiLSTM baseline. In perceptual evaluation involving 18 participants across
over 9 hours of synthesized audio, SSML-enhanced speech generated by our
pipeline significantly improves naturalness, with the mean opinion score
increasing from 3.20 to 3.87 (p < 0.005). Additionally, 15 of 18 listeners
preferred our enhanced synthesis. These results demonstrate substantial
progress in bridging the expressiveness gap between synthetic and natural
French speech. Our code is publicly available at
https://github.com/hi-paris/Prosody-Control-French-TTS.

AI.tldr: This paper presents an end-to-end pipeline that improves expressiveness in synthetic speech by inserting SSML tags for prosody control using fine-tuned large language models.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to enhance synthetic voices which often lack expressiveness due to poor prosody control in existing TTS systems.
AI.method: The authors propose a cascaded architecture employing two QLoRA-fine-tuned Qwen 2.5-7B models for predicting phrase-break positions and for regression on prosodic targets to generate SSML markup compatible with commercial TTS.
AI.result: The method achieved 99.2% F1 for break placement and a 25-40% reduction in mean absolute error for pitch, rate, and volume while demonstrating improved naturalness in perceptual evaluations.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach shows significant advancement in making synthetic French speech more natural and expressive.
key_contributions: Introduction of an end-to-end pipeline for SSML insertion in French text
High performance in predicting prosodic features with QLoRA-fine-tuned models
Significant improvements in the naturalness of synthesized speech as per listener evaluations.

title: Debate or Vote: Which Yields Better Decisions in Multi-Agent Large Language Models?
summary:
Multi-Agent Debate~(MAD) has emerged as a promising paradigm for improving
the performance of large language models through collaborative reasoning.
Despite recent advances, the key factors driving MAD's effectiveness remain
unclear. In this work, we disentangle MAD into two key components--Majority
Voting and inter-agent Debate--and assess their respective contributions.
Through extensive experiments across seven NLP benchmarks, we find that
Majority Voting alone accounts for most of the performance gains typically
attributed to MAD. To explain this, we propose a theoretical framework that
models debate as a stochastic process. We prove that it induces a martingale
over agents' belief trajectories, implying that debate alone does not improve
expected correctness. Guided by these insights, we demonstrate that targeted
interventions, by biasing the belief update toward correction, can meaningfully
enhance debate effectiveness. Overall, our findings suggest that while MAD has
potential, simple ensembling methods remain strong and more reliable
alternatives in many practical settings. Code is released in
https://github.com/deeplearning-wisc/debate-or-vote.

AI.tldr: This paper examines Multi-Agent Debate (MAD) for enhancing large language model performance, highlighting that Majority Voting is the primary driver of gains while debate is less beneficial.
AI.motivation: To clarify the factors contributing to the effectiveness of Multi-Agent Debate in improving large language models.
AI.method: The paper disentangles MAD into Majority Voting and inter-agent Debate, assessing their roles through extensive experiments on seven NLP benchmarks.
AI.result: The study finds that Majority Voting accounts for most performance improvements typically attributed to MAD, while debate alone does not enhance correctness.
AI.conclusion: Targeted interventions can improve debate effectiveness, although simple ensembling methods are often more reliable in practical applications.
key_contributions: Disentangling MAD into Majority Voting and inter-agent Debate
Theoretical framework modeling debate as a stochastic process
Demonstration of targeted interventions to enhance debate effectiveness
AI.limitations: The study focuses primarily on the interactions of voting and debate without exploring other potential contributing factors.

title: Humanizing Machines: Rethinking LLM Anthropomorphism Through a Multi-Level Framework of Design
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) increasingly exhibit \textbf{anthropomorphism}
characteristics -- human-like qualities portrayed across their outlook,
language, behavior, and reasoning functions. Such characteristics enable more
intuitive and engaging human-AI interactions. However, current research on
anthropomorphism remains predominantly risk-focused, emphasizing over-trust and
user deception while offering limited design guidance. We argue that
anthropomorphism should instead be treated as a \emph{concept of design} that
can be intentionally tuned to support user goals. Drawing from multiple
disciplines, we propose that the anthropomorphism of an LLM-based artifact
should reflect the interaction between artifact designers and interpreters.
This interaction is facilitated by cues embedded in the artifact by the
designers and the (cognitive) responses of the interpreters to the cues. Cues
are categorized into four dimensions: \textit{perceptive, linguistic,
behavioral}, and \textit{cognitive}. By analyzing the manifestation and
effectiveness of each cue, we provide a unified taxonomy with actionable levers
for practitioners. Consequently, we advocate for function-oriented evaluations
of anthropomorphic design.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a design-focused approach to anthropomorphism in LLMs, emphasizing user goals and actionable design cues.
AI.motivation: Current research focuses on the risks of anthropomorphism in AI, like over-trust and deception, offering little guidance for design.
AI.method: The authors propose a framework categorizing design cues into perceptive, linguistic, behavioral, and cognitive dimensions, facilitating a user-centered approach to anthropomorphism.
AI.result: They provide a unified taxonomy for anthropomorphic cues and advocate for evaluations based on functionality to enhance user interactions.
AI.conclusion: Treating anthropomorphism as a design concept allows for intentional tuning to better support user goals in human-AI interactions.
key_contributions: Introduction of a design framework for anthropomorphism in LLMs
Development of a taxonomy categorizing cues into four dimensions
Emphasis on function-oriented evaluations for practitioners

title: CausalSent: Interpretable Sentiment Classification with RieszNet
summary:
Despite the overwhelming performance improvements offered by recent natural
language procesing (NLP) models, the decisions made by these models are largely
a black box. Towards closing this gap, the field of causal NLP combines causal
inference literature with modern NLP models to elucidate causal effects of text
features. We replicate and extend Bansal et al's work on regularizing text
classifiers to adhere to estimated effects, focusing instead on model
interpretability. Specifically, we focus on developing a two-headed
RieszNet-based neural network architecture which achieves better treatment
effect estimation accuracy. Our framework, CausalSent, accurately predicts
treatment effects in semi-synthetic IMDB movie reviews, reducing MAE of effect
estimates by 2-3x compared to Bansal et al's MAE on synthetic Civil Comments
data. With an ensemble of validated models, we perform an observational case
study on the causal effect of the word "love" in IMDB movie reviews, finding
that the presence of the word "love" causes a +2.9% increase in the probability
of a positive sentiment.

AI.tldr: The paper presents CausalSent, a two-headed RieszNet-based neural network for interpretability in NLP, improving treatment effect estimation significantly.
AI.motivation: To enhance model interpretability in NLP and address black box issues in decision-making by estimating causal effects of text features.
AI.method: Developed a two-headed RieszNet-based architecture to regularize text classifiers and improve treatment effect estimation accuracy.
AI.result: CausalSent reduces the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of treatment effect estimates by 2-3x compared to previous models, accurately predicting treatment effects in movie reviews.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest significant causal effects of specific words on sentiment predictions, exemplified by the word 'love'.
key_contributions: Introduction of CausalSent for causal NLP
Demonstrated enhanced treatment effect estimation accuracy
Conducted an observational study on causal effects of text features
AI.limitations: Focused primarily on IMDB movie reviews and semi-synthetic data for validation.

title: UQ: Assessing Language Models on Unsolved Questions
comment:
FN, KZL, and NM are project co-leads and contributed equally. Project
  website: https://uq.stanford.edu
summary:
Benchmarks shape progress in AI research. A useful benchmark should be both
difficult and realistic: questions should challenge frontier models while also
reflecting real-world usage. Yet, current paradigms face a difficulty-realism
tension: exam-style benchmarks are often made artificially difficult with
limited real-world value, while benchmarks based on real user interaction often
skew toward easy, high-frequency problems. In this work, we explore a radically
different paradigm: assessing models on unsolved questions. Rather than a
static benchmark scored once, we curate unsolved questions and evaluate models
asynchronously over time with validator-assisted screening and community
verification. We introduce UQ, a testbed of 500 challenging, diverse questions
sourced from Stack Exchange, spanning topics from CS theory and math to sci-fi
and history, probing capabilities including reasoning, factuality, and
browsing. UQ is difficult and realistic by construction: unsolved questions are
often hard and naturally arise when humans seek answers, thus solving them
yields direct real-world value. Our contributions are threefold: (1) UQ-Dataset
and its collection pipeline combining rule-based filters, LLM judges, and human
review to ensure question quality (e.g., well-defined and difficult); (2)
UQ-Validators, compound validation strategies that leverage the
generator-validator gap to provide evaluation signals and pre-screen candidate
solutions for human review; and (3) UQ-Platform, an open platform where experts
collectively verify questions and solutions. The top model passes UQ-validation
on only 15% of questions, and preliminary human verification has already
identified correct answers among those that passed. UQ charts a path for
evaluating frontier models on real-world, open-ended challenges, where success
pushes the frontier of human knowledge. We release UQ at
https://uq.stanford.edu.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces UQ, a benchmark of unsolved questions designed to evaluate AI models more realistically and challenging than current benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Current benchmarks in AI often struggle between being too artificial or too simplistic. This study aims to create a more realistic assessment tool that reflects real-world difficulties.
AI.method: The authors curate a dataset of unsolved questions from various domains including computer science and history, utilizing a combination of rule-based filters, LLM assessments, and human review for quality assurance.
AI.result: Preliminary results show that top AI models are only accurate on 15% of the posed questions, indicating the difficulty of the benchmark.
AI.conclusion: UQ presents a new method for evaluating AI that focuses on real-world tough questions, potentially pushing the boundaries of knowledge and AI capabilities.
key_contributions: Creation of the UQ-Dataset for quality unsolved questions
Development of UQ-Validators for improved evaluation methods
Establishment of the UQ-Platform for collective verification

title: Less Is More? Examining Fairness in Pruned Large Language Models for Summarising Opinions
summary:
Model compression through post-training pruning offers a way to reduce model
size and computational requirements without significantly impacting model
performance. However, the effect of pruning on the fairness of LLM-generated
summaries remains unexplored, particularly for opinion summarisation where
biased outputs could influence public views.In this paper, we present a
comprehensive empirical analysis of opinion summarisation, examining three
state-of-the-art pruning methods and various calibration sets across three
open-source LLMs using four fairness metrics. Our systematic analysis reveals
that pruning methods have a greater impact on fairness than calibration sets.
Building on these insights, we propose High Gradient Low Activation (HGLA)
pruning, which identifies and removes parameters that are redundant for input
processing but influential in output generation. Our experiments demonstrate
that HGLA can better maintain or even improve fairness compared to existing
methods, showing promise across models and tasks where traditional methods have
limitations. Our human evaluation shows HGLA-generated outputs are fairer than
existing state-of-the-art pruning methods. Code is available at:
https://github.com/amberhuang01/HGLA.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes the impact of post-training pruning on the fairness of LLM-generated summaries, particularly in opinion summarisation, and introduces a new pruning method called High Gradient Low Activation (HGLA) that improves fairness in generated outputs.
AI.motivation: The effect of pruning on the fairness of LLM-generated summaries is unexplored, especially for opinion summarisation where bias can influence public views.
AI.method: A comprehensive empirical analysis of opinion summarisation using three state-of-the-art pruning methods and various calibration sets across three open-source LLMs, evaluated against four fairness metrics.
AI.result: Pruning methods significantly impact fairness compared to calibration sets; HGLA pruning maintains or improves fairness compared to traditional methods, verified through human evaluation.
AI.conclusion: HGLA shows promise in creating fairer outputs in LLM-generated summaries, overcoming limitations of existing pruning techniques.
key_contributions: Introduced a new pruning method (HGLA) focused on fairness in LLM outputs.
Conducted systematic analysis revealing the impact of pruning methods on fairness.
Demonstrated HGLA's superiority over existing pruning methods through human evaluation.

title: Steering When Necessary: Flexible Steering Large Language Models with Backtracking
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable performance across many
generation tasks. Nevertheless, effectively aligning them with desired
behaviors remains a significant challenge. Activation steering is an effective
and cost-efficient approach that directly modifies the activations of LLMs
during the inference stage, aligning their responses with the desired behaviors
and avoiding the high cost of fine-tuning. Existing methods typically
indiscriminately intervene to all generations or rely solely on the question to
determine intervention, which limits the accurate assessment of the
intervention strength. To this end, we propose the Flexible Activation Steering
with Backtracking (FASB) framework, which dynamically determines both the
necessity and strength of intervention by tracking the internal states of the
LLMs during generation, considering both the question and the generated
content. Since intervening after detecting a deviation from the desired
behavior is often too late, we further propose the backtracking mechanism to
correct the deviated tokens and steer the LLMs toward the desired behavior.
Extensive experiments on the TruthfulQA dataset and six multiple-choice
datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms baselines. Our code will be
released at https://github.com/gjw185/FASB.

AI.tldr: The FASB framework enhances LLM response alignment by dynamically adjusting intervention strength during inference, allowing for timely corrections to misaligned outputs.
AI.motivation: To improve the alignment of large language models with desired behaviors without the high cost of fine-tuning.
AI.method: The FASB framework uses activation steering and a backtracking mechanism to adjust the intervention strength based on internal states and to correct misaligned tokens.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that FASB outperforms existing methods on the TruthfulQA dataset and multiple-choice datasets.
AI.conclusion: FASB provides a cost-efficient and effective way to align LLMs with desired responses by dynamically steering activations and correcting deviations.
key_contributions: Introduction of the Flexible Activation Steering with Backtracking (FASB) framework.
Dynamic assessment of intervention necessity and strength based on internal LLM states.
Backtracking mechanism for correcting misaligned generation tokens.

title: EMO-Reasoning: Benchmarking Emotional Reasoning Capabilities in Spoken Dialogue Systems
comment:
Accepted at (ASRU 2025) 2025 IEEE Automatic Speech Recognition and
  Understanding Workshop
summary:
Speech emotions play a crucial role in human-computer interaction, shaping
engagement and context-aware communication. Despite recent advances in spoken
dialogue systems, a holistic system for evaluating emotional reasoning is still
lacking. To address this, we introduce EMO-Reasoning, a benchmark for assessing
emotional coherence in dialogue systems. It leverages a curated dataset
generated via text-to-speech to simulate diverse emotional states, overcoming
the scarcity of emotional speech data. We further propose the Cross-turn
Emotion Reasoning Score to assess the emotion transitions in multi-turn
dialogues. Evaluating seven dialogue systems through continuous, categorical,
and perceptual metrics, we show that our framework effectively detects
emotional inconsistencies, providing insights for improving current dialogue
systems. By releasing a systematic evaluation benchmark, we aim to advance
emotion-aware spoken dialogue modeling toward more natural and adaptive
interactions.

AI.tldr: Introduction of EMO-Reasoning, a benchmark for evaluating emotional coherence in dialogue systems, using diverse emotional states from text-to-speech data.
AI.motivation: To provide a holistic evaluation system for emotional reasoning in spoken dialogue systems, which is currently lacking.
AI.method: Development of EMO-Reasoning benchmark and the Cross-turn Emotion Reasoning Score to evaluate emotional transitions in dialogues, using a curated dataset generated through text-to-speech.
AI.result: Evaluated seven dialogue systems using various metrics, demonstrating the framework's effectiveness in detecting emotional inconsistencies.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides insights for improving dialogue systems and aims to advance emotion-aware modeling for natural interactions.
key_contributions: Introduction of EMO-Reasoning benchmark
Proposed Cross-turn Emotion Reasoning Score
Systematic evaluation of dialogue systems for emotional coherence

title: Stop Spinning Wheels: Mitigating LLM Overthinking via Mining Patterns for Early Reasoning Exit
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) enhance complex reasoning tasks by scaling the
individual thinking process. However, prior work shows that overthinking can
degrade overall performance. Motivated by observed patterns in thinking length
and content length, we categorize reasoning into three stages: insufficient
exploration stage, compensatory reasoning stage, and reasoning convergence
stage. Typically, LLMs produce correct answers in the compensatory reasoning
stage, whereas reasoning convergence often triggers overthinking, causing
increased resource usage or even infinite loops. Therefore, mitigating
overthinking hinges on detecting the end of the compensatory reasoning stage,
defined as the Reasoning Completion Point (RCP). RCP typically appears at the
end of the first complete reasoning cycle and can be identified by querying the
LLM sentence by sentence or monitoring the probability of an end-of-thinking
token (e.g., \texttt{</think>}), though these methods lack an efficient and
precise balance. To improve this, we mine more sensitive and consistent RCP
patterns and develop a lightweight thresholding strategy based on heuristic
rules. Experimental evaluations on benchmarks (AIME24, AIME25, GPQA-D)
demonstrate that the proposed method reduces token consumption while preserving
or enhancing reasoning accuracy.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a method to identify the Reasoning Completion Point (RCP) in large language models' reasoning processes to mitigate overthinking.
AI.motivation: To address performance degradation in large language models (LLMs) caused by overthinking during reasoning tasks.
AI.method: The paper categorizes reasoning into three stages and proposes a lightweight thresholding strategy to detect the RCP more effectively.
AI.result: Experimental evaluations show that the proposed method reduces token consumption while maintaining or improving reasoning accuracy on various benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest that timely identification of the RCP can enhance LLM performance by minimizing resource usage associated with overthinking.
key_contributions: Introduction of a three-stage reasoning model for LLMs
Development of a lightweight method to detect the Reasoning Completion Point
Demonstration of reduced token consumption while enhancing reasoning accuracy

title: Weights-Rotated Preference Optimization for Large Language Models
summary:
Despite the efficacy of Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) in aligning
Large Language Models (LLMs), reward hacking remains a pivotal challenge. This
issue emerges when LLMs excessively reduce the probability of rejected
completions to achieve high rewards, without genuinely meeting their intended
goals. As a result, this leads to overly lengthy generation lacking diversity,
as well as catastrophic forgetting of knowledge. We investigate the underlying
reason behind this issue, which is representation redundancy caused by neuron
collapse in the parameter space. Hence, we propose a novel Weights-Rotated
Preference Optimization (RoPO) algorithm, which implicitly constrains the
output layer logits with the KL divergence inherited from DPO and explicitly
constrains the intermediate hidden states by fine-tuning on a multi-granularity
orthogonal matrix. This design prevents the policy model from deviating too far
from the reference model, thereby retaining the knowledge and expressive
capabilities acquired during pre-training and SFT stages. Our RoPO achieves up
to a 3.27-point improvement on AlpacaEval 2, and surpasses the best baseline by
6.2 to 7.5 points on MT-Bench with merely 0.015% of the trainable parameters,
demonstrating its effectiveness in alleviating the reward hacking problem of
DPO.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Weights-Rotated Preference Optimization (RoPO) to address reward hacking in Large Language Models (LLMs) by preventing knowledge loss and promoting diversity in outputs.
AI.motivation: Reward hacking is a significant challenge in aligning LLMs, causing output issues such as excessive length and knowledge forgetting.
AI.method: The RoPO algorithm constrains the output layer using KL divergence and fine-tunes intermediate states with a multi-granularity orthogonal matrix to retain model capabilities during training.
AI.result: RoPO shows a 3.27-point improvement on AlpacaEval 2 and outperforms the best baseline by 6.2 to 7.5 points on MT-Bench with only 0.015% of trainable parameters.
AI.conclusion: RoPO effectively alleviates the reward hacking problem in DPO, maintaining knowledge and diversity in language generation.
key_contributions: Introduction of RoPO algorithm for LLMs
Improved performance metrics on benchmark tests
Methodology prevents knowledge loss and promotes diverse outputs

title: SurveyGen: Quality-Aware Scientific Survey Generation with Large Language Models
summary:
Automatic survey generation has emerged as a key task in scientific document
processing. While large language models (LLMs) have shown promise in generating
survey texts, the lack of standardized evaluation datasets critically hampers
rigorous assessment of their performance against human-written surveys. In this
work, we present SurveyGen, a large-scale dataset comprising over 4,200
human-written surveys across diverse scientific domains, along with 242,143
cited references and extensive quality-related metadata for both the surveys
and the cited papers. Leveraging this resource, we build QUAL-SG, a novel
quality-aware framework for survey generation that enhances the standard
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipeline by incorporating quality-aware
indicators into literature retrieval to assess and select higher-quality source
papers. Using this dataset and framework, we systematically evaluate
state-of-the-art LLMs under varying levels of human involvement - from fully
automatic generation to human-guided writing. Experimental results and human
evaluations show that while semi-automatic pipelines can achieve partially
competitive outcomes, fully automatic survey generation still suffers from low
citation quality and limited critical analysis.

AI.tldr: SurveyGen introduces a dataset for evaluating LLM-generated surveys, leading to the creation of QUAL-SG, a framework for quality-aware survey generation.
AI.motivation: The lack of standardized evaluation datasets for LLM-generated surveys hampers performance assessment against human-written surveys.
AI.method: SurveyGen, a dataset of 4,200 human-written surveys with metadata, is used along with QUAL-SG, a quality-aware framework that enhances the RAG pipeline by incorporating quality indicators into literature retrieval.
AI.result: The evaluation shows semi-automatic generation achieves better outcomes than fully automatic generation, which struggles with citation quality and critical analysis.
AI.conclusion: While improvements can be made in semi-automatic pipelines, fully automatic survey generation currently faces significant challenges.
key_contributions: Introduction of the SurveyGen dataset for survey generation evaluation
Development of QUAL-SG framework for quality-aware survey generation
Systematic evaluation of LLMs with varying human involvement in survey generation
AI.limitations: Fully automatic survey generation still suffers from low citation quality and limited critical analysis.

title: CoCoA: Confidence- and Context-Aware Adaptive Decoding for Resolving Knowledge Conflicts in Large Language Models
comment: Accepted to EMNLP'25, Main. 21 pages, 17 tables, 3 Figures
summary:
Faithful generation in large language models (LLMs) is challenged by
knowledge conflicts between parametric memory and external context. Existing
contrastive decoding methods tuned specifically to handle conflict often lack
adaptability and can degrade performance in low conflict settings. We introduce
CoCoA (Confidence- and Context-Aware Adaptive Decoding), a novel token-level
algorithm for principled conflict resolution and enhanced faithfulness. CoCoA
resolves conflict by utilizing confidence-aware measures (entropy gap and
contextual peakedness) and the generalized divergence between the parametric
and contextual distributions. Crucially, CoCoA maintains strong performance
even in low conflict settings. Extensive experiments across multiple LLMs on
diverse Question Answering (QA), Summarization, and Long-Form Question
Answering (LFQA) benchmarks demonstrate CoCoA's state-of-the-art performance
over strong baselines like AdaCAD. It yields significant gains in QA accuracy,
up to 9.2 points on average compared to the strong baseline AdaCAD, and
improves factuality in summarization and LFQA by up to 2.5 points on average
across key benchmarks. Additionally, it demonstrates superior sensitivity to
conflict variations. CoCoA enables more informed, context-aware, and ultimately
more faithful token generation.

AI.tldr: CoCoA is a new token-level algorithm for improving faithfulness in large language models by resolving knowledge conflicts through confidence-aware measures and maintaining performance in low conflict scenarios.
AI.motivation: Address the challenges of knowledge conflicts in LLMs that affect generation fidelity, particularly in various contextual settings.
AI.method: CoCoA uses confidence-aware measures like entropy gap and contextual peakedness along with generalized divergence to resolve conflicts during generation in LLMs.
AI.result: CoCoA demonstrates state-of-the-art performance, yielding significant improvements in QA accuracy (up to 9.2 points) and factuality in summarization and LFQA tasks (up to 2.5 points) over existing baselines.
AI.conclusion: CoCoA enhances token generation by effectively managing conflict and ensuring faithfulness, even in low conflict scenarios, demonstrating versatility across multiple benchmarks.
key_contributions: Introduction of CoCoA: a novel decoding algorithm for conflict resolution in LLMs
Improved accuracy and factuality in QA, summarization, and LFQA tasks over baseline methods
Adaptability of CoCoA to low conflict contexts without performance degradation.

title: Text Meets Topology: Rethinking Out-of-distribution Detection in Text-Rich Networks
summary:
Out-of-distribution (OOD) detection remains challenging in text-rich
networks, where textual features intertwine with topological structures.
Existing methods primarily address label shifts or rudimentary domain-based
splits, overlooking the intricate textual-structural diversity. For example, in
social networks, where users represent nodes with textual features (name, bio)
while edges indicate friendship status, OOD may stem from the distinct language
patterns between bot and normal users. To address this gap, we introduce the
TextTopoOOD framework for evaluating detection across diverse OOD scenarios:
(1) attribute-level shifts via text augmentations and embedding perturbations;
(2) structural shifts through edge rewiring and semantic connections; (3)
thematically-guided label shifts; and (4) domain-based divisions. Furthermore,
we propose TNT-OOD to model the complex interplay between Text aNd Topology
using: 1) a novel cross-attention module to fuse local structure into
node-level text representations, and 2) a HyperNetwork to generate
node-specific transformation parameters. This aligns topological and semantic
features of ID nodes, enhancing ID/OOD distinction across structural and
textual shifts. Experiments on 11 datasets across four OOD scenarios
demonstrate the nuanced challenge of TextTopoOOD for evaluating OOD detection
in text-rich networks.

AI.tldr: Introducing TextTopoOOD framework for OOD detection in text-rich networks, addressing complex textual-structural diversity.
AI.motivation: Existing OOD detection methods in text-rich networks do not adequately address the complex interplay between textual features and topological structures, leading to challenges in accurately identifying OOD instances.
AI.method: We propose the TextTopoOOD framework, which evaluates detection across diverse OOD scenarios through attribute-level shifts, structural shifts, and thematic label shifts. Additionally, we introduce TNT-OOD, incorporating a cross-attention module and HyperNetwork for improved node-specific parameter generation.
AI.result: Experiments conducted on 11 datasets reveal the unique challenges presented by the TextTopoOOD framework in OOD detection, specifically highlighting differences in language patterns and structural dynamics between bot and normal users.
AI.conclusion: Our work provides a comprehensive evaluation framework that enhances understanding of OOD detection in environments rich with textual information and varying topological structures, improving performance in distinguishing between ID and OOD nodes.
key_contributions: TextTopoOOD framework for OOD detection in text-rich networks
Introduction of TNT-OOD incorporating cross-attention and HyperNetwork
Evaluation across multiple OOD scenarios with varied challenges

title: EMPOWER: Evolutionary Medical Prompt Optimization With Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Prompt engineering significantly influences the reliability and clinical
utility of Large Language Models (LLMs) in medical applications. Current
optimization approaches inadequately address domain-specific medical knowledge
and safety requirements. This paper introduces EMPOWER, a novel evolutionary
framework that enhances medical prompt quality through specialized
representation learning, multi-dimensional evaluation, and structure-preserving
algorithms. Our methodology incorporates: (1) a medical terminology attention
mechanism, (2) a comprehensive assessment architecture evaluating clarity,
specificity, clinical relevance, and factual accuracy, (3) a component-level
evolutionary algorithm preserving clinical reasoning integrity, and (4) a
semantic verification module ensuring adherence to medical knowledge.
Evaluation across diagnostic, therapeutic, and educational tasks demonstrates
significant improvements: 24.7% reduction in factually incorrect content, 19.6%
enhancement in domain specificity, and 15.3% higher clinician preference in
blinded evaluations. The framework addresses critical challenges in developing
clinically appropriate prompts, facilitating more responsible integration of
LLMs into healthcare settings.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces EMPOWER, an evolutionary framework for improving prompt engineering in medical applications of LLMs, focusing on domain-specific knowledge and safety.
AI.motivation: To address the inadequacies of current optimization approaches in medical prompt engineering, especially regarding domain-specific knowledge and safety requirements.
AI.method: The methodology features four key components: a medical terminology attention mechanism, a multi-dimensional evaluation architecture, a component-level evolutionary algorithm, and a semantic verification module.
AI.result: The evaluation of the framework showed a 24.7% reduction in factually incorrect content, a 19.6% increase in domain specificity, and a 15.3% increase in clinician preference in blind evaluations.
AI.conclusion: EMPOWER enhances the reliability and clinical utility of LLMs in healthcare by improving prompt quality and addressing critical challenges in prompt development.
key_contributions: Introduction of EMPOWER framework for prompt engineering in medical applications
Development of a comprehensive evaluation architecture for prompts
Implementation of a semantic verification module for adherence to medical knowledge

title: Layerwise Importance Analysis of Feed-Forward Networks in Transformer-based Language Models
summary:
This study investigates the layerwise importance of feed-forward networks
(FFNs) in Transformer-based language models during pretraining. We introduce an
experimental approach that, while maintaining the total parameter count,
increases the FFN dimensions in some layers and completely removes the FFNs
from other layers. Furthermore, since our focus is on the importance of FFNs
during pretraining, we train models from scratch to examine whether the
importance of FFNs varies depending on their layer positions, rather than using
publicly available pretrained models as is frequently done. Through
comprehensive evaluations of models with varying sizes (285M, 570M, and 1.2B
parameters) and layer counts (12, 24, and 40 layers), we demonstrate that
concentrating FFNs in 70% of the consecutive middle layers consistently
outperforms standard configurations for multiple downstream tasks.

AI.tldr: This study explores the significance of feed-forward networks (FFNs) in Transformer-based language models during pretraining, revealing that concentrating FFNs in middle layers enhances performance on downstream tasks.
AI.motivation: To understand the layerwise importance of feed-forward networks in Transformer models and their impact on pretraining effectiveness.
AI.method: Experimental approach to increase FFN dimensions in some layers while removing them from others, training models from scratch at various sizes and layer counts.
AI.result: Models with 70% of FFNs concentrated in the middle layers consistently outperformed standard configurations across various tasks.
AI.conclusion: Layer positioning of FFNs is crucial; optimizing their concentration in specific layers enhances model performance during pretraining.
key_contributions: Introduces a novel experimental approach to evaluate FFN importance in Transformers.
Demonstrates the effect of layer positioning of FFNs on model performance.
Provides empirical evidence on the benefits of optimizing FFN configurations during pretraining.

title: SMITE: Enhancing Fairness in LLMs through Optimal In-Context Example Selection via Dynamic Validation
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are widely used for downstream tasks such as
tabular classification, where ensuring fairness in their outputs is critical
for inclusivity, equal representation, and responsible AI deployment. This
study introduces a novel approach to enhancing LLM performance and fairness
through the concept of a dynamic validation set, which evolves alongside the
test set, replacing the traditional static validation approach. We also propose
an iterative algorithm, SMITE, to select optimal in-context examples, with each
example set validated against its corresponding dynamic validation set. The
in-context set with the lowest total error is used as the final demonstration
set. Our experiments across four different LLMs show that our proposed
techniques significantly improve both predictive accuracy and fairness compared
to baseline methods. To our knowledge, this is the first study to apply dynamic
validation in the context of in-context learning for LLMs.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a dynamic validation set for enhancing the performance and fairness of Large Language Models (LLMs) in tabular classification tasks, along with a novel algorithm called SMITE for selecting optimal in-context examples.
AI.motivation: Ensuring fairness in the outputs of LLMs is critical for inclusivity and responsible AI deployment, particularly in tasks like tabular classification.
AI.method: The study presents a dynamic validation set that evolves with the test set, replacing static validation, and an iterative algorithm named SMITE to select optimal in-context examples validated against this dynamic set.
AI.result: Experiments show that the proposed techniques significantly improve both predictive accuracy and fairness across four different LLMs compared to baseline methods.
AI.conclusion: This study is the first to apply dynamic validation in the context of in-context learning for LLMs, suggesting a new approach to enhance fairness in AI applications.
key_contributions: Introduction of dynamic validation sets for LLMs
Development of the SMITE algorithm for in-context example selection
First study applying dynamic validation in LLM in-context learning

title: ISACL: Internal State Analyzer for Copyrighted Training Data Leakage
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have revolutionized Natural Language Processing
(NLP) but pose risks of inadvertently exposing copyrighted or proprietary data,
especially when such data is used for training but not intended for
distribution. Traditional methods address these leaks only after content is
generated, which can lead to the exposure of sensitive information. This study
introduces a proactive approach: examining LLMs' internal states before text
generation to detect potential leaks. By using a curated dataset of copyrighted
materials, we trained a neural network classifier to identify risks, allowing
for early intervention by stopping the generation process or altering outputs
to prevent disclosure. Integrated with a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)
system, this framework ensures adherence to copyright and licensing
requirements while enhancing data privacy and ethical standards. Our results
show that analyzing internal states effectively mitigates the risk of
copyrighted data leakage, offering a scalable solution that fits smoothly into
AI workflows, ensuring compliance with copyright regulations while maintaining
high-quality text generation. The implementation is available on
GitHub.\footnote{https://github.com/changhu73/Internal_states_leakage}

AI.tldr: This study presents a proactive approach to detect potential copyright data leaks in Large Language Models (LLMs) by examining internal states before text generation, using a neural network classifier integrated with a Retrieval-Augmented Generation system.
AI.motivation: To address the risks of copyrighted or proprietary data exposure by LLMs during text generation, which traditional methods fail to mitigate effectively.
AI.method: A neural network classifier was trained on a curated dataset of copyrighted materials to identify risks in LLMs' internal states before text generation. This method allows for intervention, stopping the generation process or altering outputs.
AI.result: The framework effectively reduces the risk of copyright data leakage while maintaining adherence to copyright regulations and ensuring high-quality text generation.
AI.conclusion: The proposed proactive approach provides a scalable solution for integrating copyright compliance and data privacy within AI workflows, with implementation available on GitHub.
key_contributions: Introduced a proactive approach for detecting potential copyright leaks by analyzing LLM internal states.
Developed a neural network classifier trained on copyrighted materials to identify risks before text generation.
Integrated this approach with a Retrieval-Augmented Generation system for enhanced adherence to copyright and data privacy.

title: Speculating LLMs' Chinese Training Data Pollution from Their Tokens
summary:
Tokens are basic elements in the datasets for LLM training. It is well-known
that many tokens representing Chinese phrases in the vocabulary of GPT
(4o/4o-mini/o1/o3/4.5/4.1/o4-mini) are indicating contents like pornography or
online gambling. Based on this observation, our goal is to locate Polluted
Chinese (PoC) tokens in LLMs and study the relationship between PoC tokens'
existence and training data. (1) We give a formal definition and taxonomy of
PoC tokens based on the GPT's vocabulary. (2) We build a PoC token detector via
fine-tuning an LLM to label PoC tokens in vocabularies by considering each
token's both semantics and related contents from the search engines. (3) We
study the speculation on the training data pollution via PoC tokens'
appearances (token ID). Experiments on GPT and other 23 LLMs indicate that
tokens widely exist while GPT's vocabulary behaves the worst: more than 23%
long Chinese tokens (i.e., a token with more than two Chinese characters) are
either porn or online gambling. We validate the accuracy of our speculation
method on famous pre-training datasets like C4 and Pile. Then, considering
GPT-4o, we speculate that the ratio of "Yui Hatano" related webpages in
GPT-4o's training data is around 0.5%.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the presence of Polluted Chinese (PoC) tokens in LLMs, focusing on their implications for training data and offering a detection method.
AI.motivation: To identify and understand the impact of harmful content in LLM training datasets, specifically focusing on Chinese language tokens.
AI.method: The authors propose a formal definition and taxonomy for PoC tokens and develop a detector by fine-tuning an LLM to classify these tokens based on semantics and related content.
AI.result: Experiments reveal that over 23% of certain long Chinese tokens in GPT's vocabulary relate to adult or gambling content, indicating significant data pollution during training.
AI.conclusion: The findings suggest substantial contamination in training datasets, especially within the GPT model, raising concerns about token representations and the datasets used for training.
key_contributions: Definition and taxonomy of Polluted Chinese (PoC) tokens.
Development of a PoC token detector using fine-tuned LLM.
Empirical evidence of token pollution in GPT and other LLMs.
AI.limitations: Results are specific to the analyzed LLMs and may not generalize across all language models or token forms.

title: Zero-shot Context Biasing with Trie-based Decoding using Synthetic Multi-Pronunciation
summary:
Contextual automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems allow for recognizing
out-of-vocabulary (OOV) words, such as named entities or rare words. However,
it remains challenging due to limited training data and ambiguous or
inconsistent pronunciations. In this paper, we propose a synthesis-driven
multi-pronunciation contextual biasing method that performs zero-shot
contextual ASR on a pretrained Whisper model. Specifically, we leverage
text-to-speech (TTS) systems to synthesize diverse speech samples containing
each target rare word, and then use the pretrained Whisper model to extract
multiple predicted pronunciation variants. These variant token sequences are
compiled into a prefix-trie, which assigns rewards to beam hypotheses in a
shallow-fusion manner during beam-search decoding. After which, any recognized
variant is mapped back to the original rare word in the final transcription.
The evaluation results on the Librispeech dataset show that our method reduces
biased word error rate (WER) by 42% on test-clean and 43% on test-other while
maintaining unbiased WER essentially unchanged.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a method for recognizing out-of-vocabulary words in speech using a synthesis-driven multi-pronunciation contextual biasing approach with a pretrained Whisper model.
AI.motivation: The challenge of recognizing out-of-vocabulary words in ASR systems due to limited training data and varied pronunciations.
AI.method: A synthesis-driven method using TTS to create diverse speech samples for OOV words, employing a prefix-trie for beam-search decoding to enhance pronunciation recognition.
AI.result: The method achieved a reduction in biased word error rate (WER) by 42% on test-clean and 43% on test-other while keeping unbiased WER unchanged.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method significantly improves contextual ASR for rare words without deteriorating overall recognition accuracy.
key_contributions: Multi-pronunciation contextual biasing method
Integration of TTS for synthesizing rare word pronunciations
Beam-search decoding with prefix-trie for enhanced WER reduction

title: DRQA: Dynamic Reasoning Quota Allocation for Controlling Overthinking in Reasoning Large Language Models
summary:
Reasoning large language models (RLLMs), such as OpenAI-O3 and DeepSeek-R1,
have recently demonstrated remarkable capabilities by performing structured and
multi-step reasoning. However, recent studies reveal that RLLMs often suffer
from overthinking, i.e., producing unnecessarily lengthy reasoning chains even
for simple questions, leading to excessive token consumption and computational
inefficiency. Interestingly, we observe that when processing multiple questions
in batch mode, RLLMs exhibit more resource-efficient behavior by dynamically
compressing reasoning steps for easier problems, due to implicit resource
competition. Inspired by this, we propose Dynamic Reasoning Quota Allocation
(DRQA), a novel method that transfers the benefits of resource competition from
batch processing to single-question inference. Specifically, DRQA leverages
batch-generated preference data and reinforcement learning to train the model
to allocate reasoning resources adaptively. By encouraging the model to
internalize a preference for responses that are both accurate and concise, DRQA
enables it to generate concise answers for simple questions while retaining
sufficient reasoning depth for more challenging ones. Extensive experiments on
a wide range of mathematical and scientific reasoning benchmarks demonstrate
that DRQA significantly reduces token usage while maintaining, and in many
cases improving, answer accuracy. By effectively mitigating the overthinking
problem, DRQA offers a promising direction for more efficient and scalable
deployment of RLLMs, and we hope it inspires further exploration into
fine-grained control of reasoning behaviors.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces DRQA, a method for improving the efficiency of reasoning large language models (RLLMs) by optimizing reasoning resource allocation during single-question inference.
AI.motivation: RLLMs exhibit overthinking behavior, producing unnecessarily lengthy reasoning chains that waste tokens and computing resources.
AI.method: The DRQA method uses reinforcement learning to train RLLMs in allocating reasoning resources dynamically, based on batch-generated preference data.
AI.result: DRQA significantly reduces token usage while maintaining or improving answer accuracy across various mathematical and scientific reasoning tasks.
AI.conclusion: This approach mitigates the overthinking problem in RLLMs, laying the groundwork for more efficient deployments and inspiring further research into reasoning behavior control.
key_contributions: Introduction of Dynamic Reasoning Quota Allocation (DRQA) method
Demonstrated efficiency improvements in RLLMs through reduced token usage
Improved answer accuracy on reasoning tasks without excessive complexity

title: Beyond Demographics: Enhancing Cultural Value Survey Simulation with Multi-Stage Personality-Driven Cognitive Reasoning
comment: 23 pages, 6 figures, accepted to EMNLP 2025 main
summary:
Introducing MARK, the Multi-stAge Reasoning frameworK for cultural value
survey response simulation, designed to enhance the accuracy, steerability, and
interpretability of large language models in this task. The system is inspired
by the type dynamics theory in the MBTI psychological framework for personality
research. It effectively predicts and utilizes human demographic information
for simulation: life-situational stress analysis, group-level personality
prediction, and self-weighted cognitive imitation. Experiments on the World
Values Survey show that MARK outperforms existing baselines by 10% accuracy and
reduces the divergence between model predictions and human preferences. This
highlights the potential of our framework to improve zero-shot personalization
and help social scientists interpret model predictions.

AI.tldr: MARK is a new framework for simulating cultural value survey responses, improving prediction accuracy and interpretability of large language models.
AI.motivation: To enhance the accuracy and interpretability of language models in cultural value surveys.
AI.method: MARK utilizes demographic information, stress analysis, personality prediction, and cognitive imitation for simulation.
AI.result: MARK outperforms existing models by 10% accuracy and reduces divergence from human preferences.
AI.conclusion: The framework shows promise for improving zero-shot personalization and aiding social science interpretations.
key_contributions: Introduction of the MARK framework for cultural value simulations
Utilization of type dynamics theory for personality research
Significant performance improvement over existing methods

title: Speech Discrete Tokens or Continuous Features? A Comparative Analysis for Spoken Language Understanding in SpeechLLMs
summary:
With the rise of Speech Large Language Models (SpeechLLMs), two dominant
approaches have emerged for speech processing: discrete tokens and continuous
features. Each approach has demonstrated strong capabilities in audio-related
processing tasks. However, the performance gap between these two paradigms has
not been thoroughly explored. To address this gap, we present a fair comparison
of self-supervised learning (SSL)-based discrete and continuous features under
the same experimental settings. We evaluate their performance across six spoken
language understanding-related tasks using both small and large-scale LLMs
(Qwen1.5-0.5B and Llama3.1-8B). We further conduct in-depth analyses, including
efficient comparison, SSL layer analysis, LLM layer analysis, and robustness
comparison. Our findings reveal that continuous features generally outperform
discrete tokens in various tasks. Each speech processing method exhibits
distinct characteristics and patterns in how it learns and processes speech
information. We hope our results will provide valuable insights to advance
spoken language understanding in SpeechLLMs.

AI.tldr: This paper conducts a comparative analysis of discrete tokens and continuous features in Speech Large Language Models (SpeechLLMs) performance across spoken language understanding tasks.
AI.motivation: To investigate the performance gap between discrete and continuous feature approaches in speech processing, focusing on their effectiveness in spoken language understanding tasks.
AI.method: The study employs self-supervised learning (SSL) to compare discrete and continuous features, analyzing their performance across six tasks with varying scales of LLMs (Qwen1.5-0.5B and Llama3.1-8B). In-depth analyses include SSL and LLM layer comparisons and robustness assessments.
AI.result: Continuous features generally outperform discrete tokens across various speech processing tasks, revealing distinct learning characteristics of each method.
AI.conclusion: Further research based on these findings could improve spoken language understanding capabilities in SpeechLLMs.
key_contributions: Fair comparison of discrete and continuous features in SpeechLLMs
Insights into performance across varied tasks
In-depth analyses of SSL and LLM layers

title: ILRe: Intermediate Layer Retrieval for Context Compression in Causal Language Models
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated success across many
benchmarks. However, they still exhibit limitations in long-context scenarios,
primarily due to their short effective context length, quadratic computational
complexity, and high memory overhead when processing lengthy inputs. To
mitigate these issues, we introduce a novel context compression pipeline,
called Intermediate Layer Retrieval (ILRe), which determines one intermediate
decoder layer offline, encodes context by streaming chunked prefill only up to
that layer, and recalls tokens by the attention scores between the input query
and full key cache in that specified layer. In particular, we propose a
multi-pooling kernels allocating strategy in the token recalling process to
maintain the completeness of semantics. Our approach not only reduces the
prefilling complexity from $O(L^2)$ to $O(L)$, but also achieves performance
comparable to or better than the full context in the long context scenarios.
Without additional post training or operator development, ILRe can process a
single $1M$ tokens request in less than half a minute (speedup $\approx
180\times$) and scores RULER-$1M$ benchmark of $\approx 79.8$ with model
Llama-3.1-UltraLong-8B-1M-Instruct on a Huawei Ascend 910B NPU.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a novel context compression pipeline, Intermediate Layer Retrieval (ILRe), which efficiently handles long-context scenarios for Large Language Models by reducing computational complexity and maintaining semantic completeness.
AI.motivation: LLMs struggle with long-context scenarios due to short effective context length, high computational complexity, and memory overhead.
AI.method: The ILRe pipeline encodes context by streaming chunked prefill up to a designated intermediate decoder layer, and recalls tokens using attention scores between the input query and a full key cache at that layer.
AI.result: ILRe reduces prefilling complexity from O(L^2) to O(L) and processes a 1M token request in under half a minute, achieving a benchmark score of approximately 79.8.
AI.conclusion: ILRe allows LLMs to perform efficiently and effectively in long context scenarios without additional post-training or operator development.
key_contributions: Introduction of ILRe, a new context compression pipeline for LLMs.
Reduction of computational complexity from O(L^2) to O(L).
Achieving comparable or better performance than full context in long context scenarios.

title: Pandora: Leveraging Code-driven Knowledge Transfer for Unified Structured Knowledge Reasoning
summary:
Unified Structured Knowledge Reasoning (USKR) aims to answer natural language
questions by using structured sources such as tables, databases, and knowledge
graphs in a unified way. Existing USKR methods rely on task-specific strategies
or bespoke representations, which hinder their ability to dismantle barriers
between different SKR tasks, thereby constraining their overall performance in
cross-task scenarios. In this paper, we introduce \textsc{Pandora}, a novel
USKR framework that addresses the limitations of existing methods by leveraging
two key innovations. First, we propose a code-based unified knowledge
representation using \textsc{Python}'s \textsc{Pandas} API, which aligns
seamlessly with the pre-training of LLMs. This representation facilitates a
cohesive approach to handling different structured knowledge sources. Building
on this foundation, we employ knowledge transfer to bolster the unified
reasoning process of LLMs by automatically building cross-task memory. By
adaptively correcting reasoning using feedback from code execution,
\textsc{Pandora} showcases impressive unified reasoning capabilities. Extensive
experiments on six widely used benchmarks across three SKR tasks demonstrate
that \textsc{Pandora} outperforms existing unified reasoning frameworks and
competes effectively with task-specific methods.

AI.tldr: Pandora is a novel Unified Structured Knowledge Reasoning framework that enhances LLM reasoning across various structured knowledge sources.
AI.motivation: Existing USKR methods are limited by task-specific strategies that hinder performance in cross-task scenarios.
AI.method: Pandora introduces a code-based unified knowledge representation using Python's Pandas API and employs knowledge transfer for cross-task memory and adaptive reasoning correction.
AI.result: Pandora demonstrates superior performance on six benchmarks across three SKR tasks, outperforming existing frameworks and competing with task-specific methods.
AI.conclusion: Pandora enhances unified reasoning capabilities for LLMs by integrating structured knowledge seamlessly and correcting reasoning through code execution feedback.
key_contributions: Unified knowledge representation with Python's Pandas
Knowledge transfer for enhanced reasoning
Adaptive correction of reasoning using code feedback

title: Evaluating the Representation of Vowels in Wav2Vec Feature Extractor: A Layer-Wise Analysis Using MFCCs
summary:
Automatic Speech Recognition has advanced with self-supervised learning,
enabling feature extraction directly from raw audio. In Wav2Vec, a CNN first
transforms audio into feature vectors before the transformer processes them.
This study examines CNN-extracted information for monophthong vowels using the
TIMIT corpus. We compare MFCCs, MFCCs with formants, and CNN activations by
training SVM classifiers for front-back vowel identification, assessing their
classification accuracy to evaluate phonetic representation.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the quality of phonetic representation for monophthong vowels using CNN-extracted features from audio, compared to traditional methods.
AI.motivation: To evaluate the effectiveness of CNN feature extraction in automatic speech recognition, particularly for vowel identification.
AI.method: The study utilizes the TIMIT corpus to compare classification accuracies of support vector machines trained on MFCCs, MFCCs with formants, and CNN activations for front-back vowel identification.
AI.result: The comparison reveals differences in classification accuracy between the methods, highlighting the strengths of CNN-extracted features.
AI.conclusion: CNN-extracted features can provide valuable phonetic information, potentially enhancing automatic speech recognition applications.
key_contributions: Investigation of CNN feature extraction for phonetic representation
Evaluation of classification accuracy for different feature types
Comparison of traditional and modern feature extraction methods

title: Information availability in different languages and various technological constraints related to multilinguism on the Internet
summary:
The usage of Internet has grown exponentially over the last two decades. The
number of Internet users has grown from 16 Million to 1650 Million from 1995 to
2010. It has become a major repository of information catering almost every
area. Since the Internet has its origin in USA which is English speaking
country there is huge dominance of English on the World Wide Web. Although
English is a globally acceptable language, still there is a huge population in
the world which is not able to access the Internet due to language constraints.
It has been estimated that only 20-25% of the world population speaks English
as a native language. More and more people are accessing the Internet nowadays
removing the cultural and linguistic barriers and hence there is a high growth
in the number of non-English speaking users over the last few years on the
Internet. Although many solutions have been provided to remove the linguistic
barriers, still there is a huge gap to be filled. This paper attempts to
analyze the need of information availability in different languages and the
various technological constraints related to multi-linguism on the Internet.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes the challenges of multilingualism on the Internet and the barriers that non-English speakers face in accessing information.
AI.motivation: To address the growing disparity in Internet access among non-English speakers and highlight the need for solutions to overcome language constraints.
AI.method: The paper reviews existing literature on linguistic barriers and technological constraints related to multilingualism on the Internet.
AI.result: It identifies significant gaps in information availability for non-English speakers despite existing solutions aimed at reducing linguistic barriers.
AI.conclusion: There remains a critical need for improved tools and technologies to make the Internet more accessible to a wider audience, particularly those who do not speak English.
key_contributions: Analysis of language barriers on the Internet
Identification of technological constraints in multilingual information access
Highlighting the need for further research and solutions in this area
