AI.limitations: The paper may not provide specific technical solutions or implementations.

title: Feature-Refined Unsupervised Model for Loanword Detection
summary:
We propose an unsupervised method for detecting loanwords i.e., words
borrowed from one language into another. While prior work has primarily relied
on language-external information to identify loanwords, such approaches can
introduce circularity and constraints into the historical linguistics workflow.
In contrast, our model relies solely on language-internal information to
process both native and borrowed words in monolingual and multilingual
wordlists. By extracting pertinent linguistic features, scoring them, and
mapping them probabilistically, we iteratively refine initial results by
identifying and generalizing from emerging patterns until convergence. This
hybrid approach leverages both linguistic and statistical cues to guide the
discovery process. We evaluate our method on the task of isolating loanwords in
datasets from six standard Indo-European languages: English, German, French,
Italian, Spanish, and Portuguese. Experimental results demonstrate that our
model outperforms baseline methods, with strong performance gains observed when
scaling to cross-linguistic data.

AI.tldr: This paper presents an unsupervised method for detecting loanwords using only language-internal information, avoiding the pitfalls of previous approaches that relied on external data.
AI.motivation: Prior loanword detection methods often rely on external language information, which can introduce biases and constraints in historical linguistics.
AI.method: The proposed method extracts linguistic features from wordlists of multiple languages, scores them, and uses a probabilistic mapping to iteratively refine the detection of loanwords.
AI.result: The method shows significant performance improvements over baseline techniques, especially when applied to datasets from multiple Indo-European languages.
AI.conclusion: The proposed hybrid approach effectively identifies loanwords by combining linguistic and statistical methods, demonstrating its applicability across various languages with enhanced accuracy.
key_contributions: Development of an unsupervised method for loanword detection based solely on language-internal information.
Demonstration of improved performance on loanword detection across multiple Indo-European languages.
Introduction of a hybrid approach that effectively combines linguistic and statistical cues.

title: AMELIA: A Family of Multi-task End-to-end Language Models for Argumentation
summary:
Argument mining is a subfield of argumentation that aims to automatically
extract argumentative structures and their relations from natural language
texts. This paper investigates how a single large language model can be
leveraged to perform one or several argument mining tasks. Our contributions
are two-fold. First, we construct a multi-task dataset by surveying and
converting 19 well-known argument mining datasets from the literature into a
unified format. Second, we explore various training strategies using Meta AI's
Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct model: (1) fine-tuning on individual tasks, (2)
fine-tuning jointly on multiple tasks, and (3) merging models fine-tuned
separately on individual tasks. Our experiments show that task-specific
fine-tuning significantly improves individual performance across all tasks.
Moreover, multi-task fine-tuning maintains strong performance without
degradation, suggesting effective transfer learning across related tasks.
Finally, we demonstrate that model merging offers a viable compromise: it
yields competitive performance while mitigating the computational costs
associated with full multi-task fine-tuning.

AI.tldr: This paper explores leveraging a large language model for argument mining tasks, constructing a unified dataset, and comparing training approaches.
AI.motivation: Investigate the use of large language models in automating argument mining tasks by extracting structures from natural language texts.
AI.method: Created a multi-task dataset from 19 existing argument mining datasets; examined fine-tuning on individual tasks, jointly on multiple tasks, and merging separate fine-tuned models.
AI.result: Task-specific fine-tuning improves individual task performance; multi-task fine-tuning shows strong performance retention, and model merging balances performance and cost.
AI.conclusion: Model merging provides a competitive alternative to multi-task fine-tuning, maintaining performance while reducing computational demands.
key_contributions: Constructed a unified multi-task dataset from existing argument mining datasets.
Explored effective training strategies for argument mining using a large language model.
Demonstrated the practicality of model merging for performance and resource efficiency.

title: Debiasing Multilingual LLMs in Cross-lingual Latent Space
summary:
Debiasing techniques such as SentDebias aim to reduce bias in large language
models (LLMs). Previous studies have evaluated their cross-lingual
transferability by directly applying these methods to LLM representations,
revealing their limited effectiveness across languages. In this work, we
therefore propose to perform debiasing in a joint latent space rather than
directly on LLM representations. We construct a well-aligned cross-lingual
latent space using an autoencoder trained on parallel TED talk scripts. Our
experiments with Aya-expanse and two debiasing techniques across four languages
(English, French, German, Dutch) demonstrate that a) autoencoders effectively
construct a well-aligned cross-lingual latent space, and b) applying debiasing
techniques in the learned cross-lingual latent space significantly improves
both the overall debiasing performance and cross-lingual transferability.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a novel approach to debiasing large language models by utilizing a jointly learned cross-lingual latent space rather than direct application on model representations.
AI.motivation: To improve the effectiveness of debiasing techniques across languages, as prior methods showed limited success when applied directly to LLM representations.
AI.method: A well-aligned cross-lingual latent space is constructed using an autoencoder trained on parallel TED talk scripts, and debiasing techniques are applied in this learned latent space.
AI.result: Experiments show that autoencoders can successfully construct a cross-lingual latent space, and that applying debiasing techniques within this space notably enhances debiasing performance and cross-lingual transferability.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method effectively enhances the overall efficacy of debiasing techniques for LLMs across multiple languages.
key_contributions: Novel joint latent space debiasing technique
Enhanced cross-lingual transferability
Demonstrated improved debiasing performance across multiple languages

title: Understanding Subword Compositionality of Large Language Models
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) take sequences of subwords as input, requiring
them to effective compose subword representations into meaningful word-level
representations. In this paper, we present a comprehensive set of experiments
to probe how LLMs compose subword information, focusing on three key aspects:
structural similarity, semantic decomposability, and form retention. Our
analysis of the experiments suggests that these five LLM families can be
classified into three distinct groups, likely reflecting difference in their
underlying composition strategies. Specifically, we observe (i) three distinct
patterns in the evolution of structural similarity between subword compositions
and whole-word representations across layers; (ii) great performance when
probing layer by layer their sensitivity to semantic decompositionality; and
(iii) three distinct patterns when probing sensitivity to formal features,
e.g., character sequence length. These findings provide valuable insights into
the compositional dynamics of LLMs and highlight different compositional
pattens in how LLMs encode and integrate subword information.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates how large language models (LLMs) compose subword representations into meaningful words, identifying patterns in their compositional strategies through structured experiments.
AI.motivation: To understand how LLMs effectively compose subword information into word-level representations and classify LLM families based on composition strategies.
AI.method: The authors conducted a series of experiments analyzing structural similarity, semantic decomposability, and form retention across multiple layers of five LLM families.
AI.result: Three distinct patterns in the evolution of structural similarity were found across layers, high sensitivity to semantic decompositionality, and varying sensitivity to formal features among the models examined.
AI.conclusion: The findings offer insights into the compositional dynamics of LLMs, highlighting different strategies in how they encode and integrate subword information.
key_contributions: Identified three distinct structural similarity patterns in LLMs' layer-wise composition.
Demonstrated high sensitivity to semantic decompositionality across LLMs.
Classified LLM families based on their compositional patterns.

title: German4All - A Dataset and Model for Readability-Controlled Paraphrasing in German
summary:
The ability to paraphrase texts across different complexity levels is
essential for creating accessible texts that can be tailored toward diverse
reader groups. Thus, we introduce German4All, the first large-scale German
dataset of aligned readability-controlled, paragraph-level paraphrases. It
spans five readability levels and comprises over 25,000 samples. The dataset is
automatically synthesized using GPT-4 and rigorously evaluated through both
human and LLM-based judgments. Using German4All, we train an open-source,
readability-controlled paraphrasing model that achieves state-of-the-art
performance in German text simplification, enabling more nuanced and
reader-specific adaptations. We opensource both the dataset and the model to
encourage further research on multi-level paraphrasing

AI.tldr: German4All is a dataset for readability-controlled paraphrasing in German, helping to create accessible texts.
AI.motivation: To enhance the accessibility of written content for diverse reader groups by providing text that matches different complexity levels.
AI.method: The dataset is automatically generated using GPT-4 and evaluated through human and LLM judgments, ensuring high quality and readability across five levels.
AI.result: German4All consists of over 25,000 paragraph-level paraphrases with verified readability levels, leading to the development of a state-of-the-art paraphrasing model.
AI.conclusion: The introduction of German4All facilitates research in multi-level paraphrasing and offers tools for customizing text complexity for varied audiences.
key_contributions: First large-scale German dataset for readability-controlled paraphrases
Includes 25,000 samples across five readability levels
Open-source dataset and model for further research

title: A Retail-Corpus for Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis with Large Language Models
summary:
Aspect-based sentiment analysis enhances sentiment detection by associating
it with specific aspects, offering deeper insights than traditional sentiment
analysis. This study introduces a manually annotated dataset of 10,814
multilingual customer reviews covering brick-and-mortar retail stores, labeled
with eight aspect categories and their sentiment. Using this dataset, the
performance of GPT-4 and LLaMA-3 in aspect based sentiment analysis is
evaluated to establish a baseline for the newly introduced data. The results
show both models achieving over 85% accuracy, while GPT-4 outperforms LLaMA-3
overall with regard to all relevant metrics.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a dataset for aspect-based sentiment analysis and evaluates GPT-4 and LLaMA-3 on it.
AI.motivation: To enhance sentiment detection by associating it with specific aspects in customer reviews, providing deeper insights compared to traditional methods.
AI.method: The study introduces a manually annotated dataset containing 10,814 multilingual customer reviews, labeled with aspect categories and sentiments, and evaluates the performance of GPT-4 and LLaMA-3 on this dataset.
AI.result: Both models achieved over 85% accuracy, with GPT-4 outperforming LLaMA-3 across all relevant metrics.
AI.conclusion: The findings establish a baseline for sentiment analysis using the new dataset and highlight the superior performance of GPT-4.
key_contributions: Introduction of a new dataset for aspect-based sentiment analysis.
Evaluation of state-of-the-art models (GPT-4, LLaMA-3) on this dataset.
Establishment of baseline accuracy metrics for future studies.

title: Neither Valid nor Reliable? Investigating the Use of LLMs as Judges
summary:
Evaluating natural language generation (NLG) systems remains a core challenge
of natural language processing (NLP), further complicated by the rise of large
language models (LLMs) that aims to be general-purpose. Recently, large
language models as judges (LLJs) have emerged as a promising alternative to
traditional metrics, but their validity remains underexplored. This position
paper argues that the current enthusiasm around LLJs may be premature, as their
adoption has outpaced rigorous scrutiny of their reliability and validity as
evaluators. Drawing on measurement theory from the social sciences, we identify
and critically assess four core assumptions underlying the use of LLJs: their
ability to act as proxies for human judgment, their capabilities as evaluators,
their scalability, and their cost-effectiveness. We examine how each of these
assumptions may be challenged by the inherent limitations of LLMs, LLJs, or
current practices in NLG evaluation. To ground our analysis, we explore three
applications of LLJs: text summarization, data annotation, and safety
alignment. Finally, we highlight the need for more responsible evaluation
practices in LLJs evaluation, to ensure that their growing role in the field
supports, rather than undermines, progress in NLG.

AI.tldr: The paper critiques the rising use of large language models (LLJs) as evaluators in natural language generation, arguing that their reliability and validity are underexplored.
AI.motivation: There is a growing interest in using large language models (LLJs) for evaluating NLG systems, but the assessment of their efficacy remains inadequate.
AI.method: The paper employs measurement theory from social sciences to analyze the assumptions behind LLJs as evaluators.
AI.result: The authors identify and scrutinize four core assumptions about LLJs: their proxy capability for human judgment, evaluation strengths, scalability, and cost-effectiveness, revealing significant limitations.
AI.conclusion: The paper stresses the necessity for more robust evaluation practices of LLJs to avoid hindering advancements in natural language generation.
key_contributions: Critical analysis of LLJs in NLG evaluation
Identification of assumptions and their challenges
Recommendations for responsible evaluation practices
AI.limitations: The analysis relies on theoretical assumptions and may not encompass all practical scenarios in LLJ evaluation.

title: How Quantization Shapes Bias in Large Language Models
summary:
This work presents a comprehensive evaluation of how quantization affects
model bias, with particular attention to its impact on individual demographic
subgroups. We focus on weight and activation quantization strategies and
examine their effects across a broad range of bias types, including
stereotypes, toxicity, sentiment, and fairness. We employ both probabilistic
and generated text-based metrics across nine benchmarks and evaluate models
varying in architecture family and reasoning ability. Our findings show that
quantization has a nuanced impact on bias: while it can reduce model toxicity
and does not significantly impact sentiment, it tends to slightly increase
stereotypes and unfairness in generative tasks, especially under aggressive
compression. These trends are generally consistent across demographic
categories and model types, although their magnitude depends on the specific
setting. Overall, our results highlight the importance of carefully balancing
efficiency and ethical considerations when applying quantization in practice.

AI.tldr: The paper evaluates the impact of quantization on model bias across demographic subgroups, revealing its complex effects on toxicity, stereotypes, and fairness.
AI.motivation: To understand how quantization strategies affect model bias, particularly for different demographic subgroups.
AI.method: The study employs probabilistic and generated text-based metrics across nine benchmarks, analyzing various model architectures and reasoning capabilities.
AI.result: Quantization reduces model toxicity but slightly increases stereotypes and unfairness in generative tasks, especially with aggressive compression.
AI.conclusion: A balance between efficiency and ethical considerations is essential when applying quantization.
key_contributions: Comprehensive evaluation of quantization on model bias across demographic groups.
Identification of nuanced effects where quantization can reduce toxicity but may increase stereotypes.
Emphasis on the importance of ethical considerations in model efficiency.
AI.limitations: The impact of quantization on bias can vary significantly depending on the model architecture and specific settings used in evaluation.

title: Speech-Based Depressive Mood Detection in the Presence of Multiple Sclerosis: A Cross-Corpus and Cross-Lingual Study
comment:
Accepted at the 8th International Conference on Natural Language and
  Speech Processing (ICNLSP 2025). To be appeared in the corresponding
  Proceedings at ACL Anthology
summary:
Depression commonly co-occurs with neurodegenerative disorders like Multiple
Sclerosis (MS), yet the potential of speech-based Artificial Intelligence for
detecting depression in such contexts remains unexplored. This study examines
the transferability of speech-based depression detection methods to people with
MS (pwMS) through cross-corpus and cross-lingual analysis using English data
from the general population and German data from pwMS. Our approach implements
supervised machine learning models using: 1) conventional speech and language
features commonly used in the field, 2) emotional dimensions derived from a
Speech Emotion Recognition (SER) model, and 3) exploratory speech feature
analysis. Despite limited data, our models detect depressive mood in pwMS with
moderate generalisability, achieving a 66% Unweighted Average Recall (UAR) on a
binary task. Feature selection further improved performance, boosting UAR to
74%. Our findings also highlight the relevant role emotional changes have as an
indicator of depressive mood in both the general population and within PwMS.
This study provides an initial exploration into generalising speech-based
depression detection, even in the presence of co-occurring conditions, such as
neurodegenerative diseases.

AI.tldr: This study explores the use of speech-based AI for detecting depression in individuals with Multiple Sclerosis (MS) by implementing machine learning models on English and German speech data.
AI.motivation: To investigate the effectiveness of speech-based AI methods for identifying depression in neurologically compromised populations, specifically those with MS, where such detection has not been thoroughly studied.
AI.method: The research employs supervised machine learning models that analyze conventional speech and language features, emotional dimensions from a Speech Emotion Recognition model, and conducts exploratory speech feature analysis across different languages and data corpuses.
AI.result: The models achieve a 66% Unweighted Average Recall (UAR) on a binary classification task, with feature selection enhancing performance to a UAR of 74%.
AI.conclusion: The study identifies the importance of emotional changes as indicators of depressive moods in both the general population and in pwMS, suggesting the potential for generalizing depression detection methods across contexts.
key_contributions: Examined the transferability of speech-based depression detection to individuals with MS
Achieved significant performance improvement through feature selection
Demonstrated the role of emotional changes in identifying depressive moods in pwMS
AI.limitations: Limited data availability for robust model training and validation.

title: Agri-Query: A Case Study on RAG vs. Long-Context LLMs for Cross-Lingual Technical Question Answering
summary:
We present a case study evaluating large language models (LLMs) with
128K-token context windows on a technical question answering (QA) task. Our
benchmark is built on a user manual for an agricultural machine, available in
English, French, and German. It simulates a cross-lingual information retrieval
scenario where questions are posed in English against all three language
versions of the manual. The evaluation focuses on realistic
"needle-in-a-haystack" challenges and includes unanswerable questions to test
for hallucinations. We compare nine long-context LLMs using direct prompting
against three Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) strategies (keyword,
semantic, hybrid), with an LLM-as-a-judge for evaluation. Our findings for this
specific manual show that Hybrid RAG consistently outperforms direct
long-context prompting. Models like Gemini 2.5 Flash and the smaller Qwen 2.5
7B achieve high accuracy (over 85%) across all languages with RAG. This paper
contributes a detailed analysis of LLM performance in a specialized industrial
domain and an open framework for similar evaluations, highlighting practical
trade-offs and challenges.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates large language models on a technical QA task using long-context capabilities in a cross-lingual setting, demonstrating the superiority of Hybrid RAG strategies.
AI.motivation: To analyze the performance of large language models in answering technical questions from user manuals across multiple languages, while addressing challenges such as unanswerable questions and hallucinations.
AI.method: The study benchmarks nine long-context LLMs against three Retrieval-Augmented Generation strategies (keyword, semantic, hybrid) in a simulated QA scenario involving an agricultural manual.
AI.result: Hybrid RAG consistently outperforms direct long-context prompting, with models like Gemini 2.5 Flash achieving over 85% accuracy across multiple languages.
AI.conclusion: The findings support the effectiveness of Hybrid RAG strategies in technical QA tasks and provide a framework for evaluating LLMs in specialized domains.
key_contributions: Detailed analysis of LLM performance in an industrial context
Open framework for LLM evaluation in technical environments
Demonstration of Hybrid RAG's superiority in handling cross-lingual QA tasks

title: Detecting and Characterizing Planning in Language Models
summary:
Modern large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated impressive performance
across a wide range of multi-step reasoning tasks. Recent work suggests that
LLMs may perform planning - selecting a future target token in advance and
generating intermediate tokens that lead towards it - rather than merely
improvising one token at a time. However, existing studies assume fixed
planning horizons and often focus on single prompts or narrow domains. To
distinguish planning from improvisation across models and tasks, we present
formal and causally grounded criteria for detecting planning and operationalize
them as a semi-automated annotation pipeline. We apply this pipeline to both
base and instruction-tuned Gemma-2-2B models on the MBPP code generation
benchmark and a poem generation task where Claude 3.5 Haiku was previously
shown to plan. Our findings show that planning is not universal: unlike Haiku,
Gemma-2-2B solves the same poem generation task through improvisation, and on
MBPP it switches between planning and improvisation across similar tasks and
even successive token predictions. We further show that instruction tuning
refines existing planning behaviors in the base model rather than creating them
from scratch. Together, these studies provide a reproducible and scalable
foundation for mechanistic studies of planning in LLMs.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the distinction between planning and improvisation in large language models (LLMs) across various tasks.
AI.motivation: To explore how large language models (LLMs) perform planning in multi-step reasoning tasks and to establish criteria for detecting planning versus improvisation.
AI.method: Formal and causally grounded criteria for detecting planning are developed and operationalized as a semi-automated annotation pipeline, applied to testing various models on specific benchmark tasks.
AI.result: The study finds that planning is not universal among LLMs; different models exhibit varying behaviors in planning and improvisation based on the tasks, with evidence that instruction tuning can refine planning behaviors.
AI.conclusion: The research lays a groundwork for future mechanistic studies of planning in LLMs and suggests that planning behavior can be influenced by model architecture and training methods.
key_contributions: Development of formal criteria for detecting planning in LLMs
Creation of a semi-automated annotation pipeline for evaluation
Empirical findings indicating variability in planning across different LLMs and tasks.

title: SentiMM: A Multimodal Multi-Agent Framework for Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
summary:
With the increasing prevalence of multimodal content on social media,
sentiment analysis faces significant challenges in effectively processing
heterogeneous data and recognizing multi-label emotions. Existing methods often
lack effective cross-modal fusion and external knowledge integration. We
propose SentiMM, a novel multi-agent framework designed to systematically
address these challenges. SentiMM processes text and visual inputs through
specialized agents, fuses multimodal features, enriches context via knowledge
retrieval, and aggregates results for final sentiment classification. We also
introduce SentiMMD, a large-scale multimodal dataset with seven fine-grained
sentiment categories. Extensive experiments demonstrate that SentiMM achieves
superior performance compared to state-of-the-art baselines, validating the
effectiveness of our structured approach.

AI.tldr: SentiMM is a novel multi-agent framework for multimodal sentiment analysis that improves performance through effective cross-modal fusion and external knowledge integration.
AI.motivation: The increasing complexity of multimodal content on social media poses challenges for traditional sentiment analysis methods that struggle with heterogeneous data and multi-label emotions.
AI.method: SentiMM uses specialized agents to process text and visual inputs, fuses multimodal features, integrates external knowledge for context enrichment, and aggregates results for sentiment classification.
AI.result: SentiMM outperforms existing state-of-the-art sentiment analysis methods, demonstrating superior performance in classifying fine-grained sentiments.
AI.conclusion: The structured approach of SentiMM, along with the introduction of the SentiMMD dataset, lays the groundwork for more effective multimodal sentiment analysis.
key_contributions: Introduction of SentiMM framework for multimodal sentiment analysis
Development of SentiMMD, a comprehensive dataset with seven sentiment categories
Enhanced sentiment classification through effective cross-modal fusion and knowledge integration.

title: Toward a Better Localization of Princeton WordNet
summary:
As Princeton WordNet continues to gain significance as a semantic lexicon in
Natural Language Processing, the need for its localization and for ensuring the
quality of this process has become increasingly critical. Existing efforts
remain limited in both scale and rigor, and there is a notable absence of
studies addressing the accuracy of localization or its alignment with the
cultural context of Arabic. This paper proposes a structured framework for the
localization of Princeton WordNet, detailing the stages and procedures required
to achieve high-quality results without compromising cultural authenticity. We
further present our experience in applying this framework, reporting outcomes
from the localization of 10,000 synsets.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a structured framework for the localization of Princeton WordNet into Arabic, focusing on quality and cultural authenticity.
AI.motivation: The localization of Princeton WordNet is crucial as its significance in Natural Language Processing increases, particularly for Arabic, where existing efforts are limited and lack rigor.
AI.method: The paper outlines the structured stages and procedures for localizing Princeton WordNet, ensuring high-quality results aligned with cultural contexts.
AI.result: The application of this framework resulted in the successful localization of 10,000 synsets, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed approach.
AI.conclusion: Implementing this structured framework enhances the quality and cultural relevance of localizing Princeton WordNet for Arabic speakers.
key_contributions: Proposed a structured framework for localizing Princeton WordNet
Detailed stages and procedures for achieving quality localization
Reported outcomes from localizing a significant number of synsets (10,000)
AI.limitations: The study is limited to the localization of Princeton WordNet and may not address other semantic lexicons or languages.

title: S2Sent: Nested Selectivity Aware Sentence Representation Learning
summary:
The combination of Transformer-based encoders with contrastive learning
represents the current mainstream paradigm for sentence representation
learning. This paradigm is typically based on the hidden states of the last
Transformer block of the encoder. However, within Transformer-based encoders,
different blocks exhibit varying degrees of semantic perception ability. From
the perspective of interpretability, the semantic perception potential of
knowledge neurons is modulated by stimuli, thus rational cross-block
representation fusion is a direction worth optimizing. To balance the semantic
redundancy and loss across block fusion, we propose a sentence representation
selection mechanism S\textsuperscript{2}Sent, which integrates a parameterized
nested selector downstream of the Transformer-based encoder. This selector
performs spatial selection (SS) and nested frequency selection (FS) from a
modular perspective. The SS innovatively employs a spatial squeeze based
self-gating mechanism to obtain adaptive weights, which not only achieves
fusion with low information redundancy but also captures the dependencies
between embedding features. The nested FS replaces GAP with different DCT basis
functions to achieve spatial squeeze with low semantic loss. Extensive
experiments have demonstrated that S\textsuperscript{2}Sent achieves
significant improvements over baseline methods with negligible additional
parameters and inference latency, while highlighting high integrability and
scalability.

AI.tldr: The paper presents S^2Sent, a novel sentence representation selection mechanism that enhances the fusion of representations from various Transformer blocks to improve sentence embedding quality while maintaining low redundancy and semantic loss.
AI.motivation: To optimize the sentence representation learning process by addressing the varying semantic perception abilities of different blocks in Transformer-based encoders.
AI.method: Introducing a parameterized nested selector that performs spatial selection and frequency selection for effective representation fusion from the last blocks of the Transformer encoder.
AI.result: S^2Sent significantly improves sentence representation quality over baseline methods, achieving this with minimal additional parameters and low inference latency.
AI.conclusion: The proposed S^2Sent shows high integrability and scalability, making it a valuable advancement in sentence representation techniques.
key_contributions: Development of the S^2Sent mechanism for enhanced representation fusion
Utilization of a spatial squeeze based self-gating mechanism for adaptive weights
Replacement of GAP with DCT basis functions to minimize semantic loss

title: DiscussLLM: Teaching Large Language Models When to Speak
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in
understanding and generating human-like text, yet they largely operate as
reactive agents, responding only when directly prompted. This passivity creates
an "awareness gap," limiting their potential as truly collaborative partners in
dynamic human discussions. We introduce $\textit{DiscussLLM}$, a framework
designed to bridge this gap by training models to proactively decide not just
$\textit{what}$ to say, but critically, $\textit{when}$ to speak. Our primary
contribution is a scalable two-stage data generation pipeline that synthesizes
a large-scale dataset of realistic multi-turn human discussions. Each
discussion is annotated with one of five intervention types (e.g., Factual
Correction, Concept Definition) and contains an explicit conversational trigger
where an AI intervention adds value. By training models to predict a special
silent token when no intervention is needed, they learn to remain quiet until a
helpful contribution can be made. We explore two architectural baselines: an
integrated end-to-end model and a decoupled classifier-generator system
optimized for low-latency inference. We evaluate these models on their ability
to accurately time interventions and generate helpful responses, paving the way
for more situationally aware and proactive conversational AI.

AI.tldr: DiscussLLM is a framework to enhance LLMs by training them to decide when to speak in conversations, addressing their reactive nature.
AI.motivation: To bridge the awareness gap in LLMs, allowing them to function as proactive collaborators in dynamic discussions.
AI.method: A scalable two-stage data generation pipeline that synthesizes multi-turn human discussions annotated with intervention types, training models to predict silent tokens in non-intervention scenarios.
AI.result: Models trained with DiscussLLM can accurately time interventions and generate relevant responses, improving the situational awareness of conversational AI.
AI.conclusion: The framework enhances LLMs‚Äô capabilities, moving them towards more proactive and contextually aware communication.
key_contributions: Introduction of the DiscussLLM framework for proactive dialogue management
Development of a two-stage data generation pipeline for synthesizing realistic discussions
Evaluation of different architectural models for intervention timing and response generation
AI.limitations: The effectiveness of the framework may vary with different types of conversations and contexts not covered in training.

title: Improving End-to-End Training of Retrieval-Augmented Generation Models via Joint Stochastic Approximation
summary:
Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) has become a widely recognized paradigm
to combine parametric memory with non-parametric memories. An RAG model
consists of two serial connecting components (retriever and generator). A major
challenge in end-to-end optimization of the RAG model is that marginalization
over relevant passages (modeled as discrete latent variables) from a knowledge
base is required. Traditional top-K marginalization and variational RAG (VRAG)
suffer from biased or high-variance gradient estimates. In this paper, we
propose and develop joint stochastic approximation (JSA) based end-to-end
training of RAG, which is referred to as JSA-RAG. The JSA algorithm is a
stochastic extension of the EM (expectation-maximization) algorithm and is
particularly powerful in estimating discrete latent variable models. Extensive
experiments are conducted on five datasets for two tasks (open-domain question
answering, knowledge-grounded dialogs) and show that JSA-RAG significantly
outperforms both vanilla RAG and VRAG. Further analysis shows the efficacy of
JSA-RAG from the perspectives of generation, retrieval, and low-variance
gradient estimate.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces JSA-RAG, a novel approach for end-to-end training of retrieval-augmented generation models that addresses the challenges of gradient estimation in parameter optimization.
AI.motivation: The need for effective marginalization and low-variance gradient estimates in the training of retrieval-augmented generation models.
AI.method: The authors propose a joint stochastic approximation (JSA) method based on a stochastic extension of the expectation-maximization algorithm for training RAG models.
AI.result: Extensive experiments demonstrate that JSA-RAG significantly outperforms traditional RAG and VRAG across multiple datasets and tasks.
AI.conclusion: JSA-RAG effectively enhances the end-to-end training of RAG models, providing more reliable gradient estimates and better performance on generation and retrieval tasks.
key_contributions: Introduction of JSA-RAG method for training RAG models
Demonstration of improved performance in open-domain question answering and knowledge-grounded dialogs
Analysis showing low-variance gradient estimates in JSA-RAG

title: Leveraging Large Language Models for Accurate Sign Language Translation in Low-Resource Scenarios
summary:
Translating natural languages into sign languages is a highly complex and
underexplored task. Despite growing interest in accessibility and inclusivity,
the development of robust translation systems remains hindered by the limited
availability of parallel corpora which align natural language with sign
language data. Existing methods often struggle to generalize in these
data-scarce environments, as the few datasets available are typically
domain-specific, lack standardization, or fail to capture the full linguistic
richness of sign languages. To address this limitation, we propose Advanced Use
of LLMs for Sign Language Translation (AulSign), a novel method that leverages
Large Language Models via dynamic prompting and in-context learning with sample
selection and subsequent sign association. Despite their impressive abilities
in processing text, LLMs lack intrinsic knowledge of sign languages; therefore,
they are unable to natively perform this kind of translation. To overcome this
limitation, we associate the signs with compact descriptions in natural
language and instruct the model to use them. We evaluate our method on both
English and Italian languages using SignBank+, a recognized benchmark in the
field, as well as the Italian LaCAM CNR-ISTC dataset. We demonstrate superior
performance compared to state-of-the-art models in low-data scenario. Our
findings demonstrate the effectiveness of AulSign, with the potential to
enhance accessibility and inclusivity in communication technologies for
underrepresented linguistic communities.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes AulSign, a novel method for translating natural languages into sign languages using LLMs, addressing issues with existing data-scarce translation methods and demonstrating superior performance in low-data scenarios.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the complex task of translating natural languages into sign languages, focusing on challenges such as the lack of parallel corpora and the struggles of existing methods to generalize.
AI.method: AulSign leverages Large Language Models through dynamic prompting and in-context learning, associating signs with compact natural language descriptions to enhance translation capabilities.
AI.result: The method was evaluated on English and Italian using the SignBank+ benchmark and LaCAM CNR-ISTC dataset, showing superior performance compared to state-of-the-art models in low-data scenarios.
AI.conclusion: AulSign enhances accessibility and inclusivity in communication technologies for underrepresented communities, demonstrating effective sign language translation.
key_contributions: Introduction of AulSign for sign language translation using LLMs
Utilization of dynamic prompting and in-context learning
Performance evaluation against existing models in low-data environments

title: Exploring the Interplay between Musical Preferences and Personality through the Lens of Language
summary:
Music serves as a powerful reflection of individual identity, often aligning
with deeper psychological traits. Prior research has established correlations
between musical preferences and personality traits, while separate studies have
demonstrated that personality is detectable through linguistic analysis. Our
study bridges these two research domains by investigating whether individuals'
musical preferences are recognizable in their spontaneous language through the
lens of the Big Five personality traits (Openness, Conscientiousness,
Extroversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism). Using a carefully curated
dataset of over 500,000 text samples from nearly 5,000 authors with reliably
identified musical preferences, we build advanced models to assess personality
characteristics. Our results reveal significant personality differences across
fans of five musical genres. We release resources for future research at the
intersection of computational linguistics, music psychology and personality
analysis.

AI.tldr: This study explores the relationship between musical preferences and personality traits, using language analysis to identify personality characteristics in text samples.
AI.motivation: To bridge the gap between musical preferences and personality detection through linguistic analysis, enhancing understanding of individual identity.
AI.method: Analyzed over 500,000 text samples from nearly 5,000 authors with known musical preferences, utilizing advanced models to assess their Big Five personality traits.
AI.result: Significant personality differences were found among fans of five musical genres, indicating that musical preferences can be linked to identifiable personality traits in language.
AI.conclusion: The research demonstrates a novel approach to understanding personality through musical preferences and provides resources for further studies in computational linguistics and psychology.
key_contributions: Integration of music psychology and personality analysis through language
Creation of advanced models linking music preference to personality traits
Release of a dataset for future research

title: Why Synthetic Isn't Real Yet: A Diagnostic Framework for Contact Center Dialogue Generation
summary:
Synthetic transcript generation is critical in contact center domains, where
privacy and data scarcity limit model training and evaluation. Unlike prior
synthetic dialogue generation work on open-domain or medical dialogues, contact
center conversations are goal-oriented, role-asymmetric, and behaviorally
complex, featuring disfluencies, ASR noise, and compliance-driven agent
actions. In deployments where transcripts are unavailable, standard pipelines
still yield derived call attributes such as Intent Summaries, Topic Flow, and
QA Evaluation Forms. We leverage these as supervision signals to guide
generation. To assess the quality of such outputs, we introduce a diagnostic
framework of 18 linguistically and behaviorally grounded metrics for comparing
real and synthetic transcripts. We benchmark four language-agnostic generation
strategies, from simple prompting to characteristic-aware multi-stage
approaches, alongside reference-free baselines. Results reveal persistent
challenges: no method excels across all traits, with notable deficits in
disfluency, sentiment, and behavioral realism. Our diagnostic tool exposes
these gaps, enabling fine-grained evaluation and stress testing of synthetic
dialogue across languages.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses synthetic transcript generation for contact centers, introducing a diagnostic framework for evaluating generated dialogues.
AI.motivation: Synthetic transcript generation is important for contact centers due to privacy issues and limited data availability, highlighting the need for suitable evaluation metrics.
AI.method: The authors develop a framework of 18 metrics for comparing real and synthetic transcripts, while exploring various language-agnostic generation strategies.
AI.result: The evaluation reveals that no generation method outperforms others across all metrics, particularly struggling with disfluency, sentiment, and behavioral realism.
AI.conclusion: The diagnostic tool enables detailed evaluation of synthetic dialogues, revealing existing challenges in transcript generation across languages.
key_contributions: Introduction of a diagnostic framework with 18 evaluation metrics for transcript quality
Benchmarking of multiple generation strategies
Identification of common shortcomings in synthetic dialogue generation
AI.limitations: The methods evaluated do not consistently address disfluency, sentiment, or behavioral realism in generated transcripts.

title: Better Language Model-Based Judging Reward Modeling through Scaling Comprehension Boundaries
summary:
The emergence of LM-based judging reward modeling, represented by generative
reward models, has successfully made reinforcement learning from AI feedback
(RLAIF) efficient and scalable. To further advance this paradigm, we propose a
core insight: this form of reward modeling shares fundamental formal
consistency with natural language inference (NLI), a core task in natural
language understanding. This reframed perspective points to a key path for
building superior reward models: scaling the model's comprehension boundaries.
Pursuing this path, exploratory experiments on NLI tasks demonstrate that the
slot prediction masked language models (MLMs) incorporating contextual
explanations achieve significantly better performance compared to mainstream
autoregressive models. Based on this key finding, we propose ESFP-RM, a
two-stage LM-based judging reward model that utilizes an explanation based slot
framework for prediction to fully leverage the advantages of MLMs. Extensive
experiments demonstrate that in both reinforcement learning from human feedback
(RLHF) and out-of-distribution (OOD) scenarios, the ESFP-RM framework delivers
more stable and generalizable reward signals compared to generative reward
models.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a new reward modeling framework (ESFP-RM) that enhances reinforcement learning from AI feedback by leveraging insights from natural language inference, demonstrating improved performance in reward signal stability and generalization.
AI.motivation: The need for efficient and scalable reinforcement learning from AI feedback using LM-based judging reward modeling.
AI.method: The paper introduces ESFP-RM, a two-stage LM-based judging reward model that uses an explanation-based slot framework for prediction, exploring its performance on natural language inference tasks.
AI.result: Experiments show that ESFP-RM outperforms traditional autoregressive models in stability and generalization of reward signals in both RLHF and OOD scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Improving the comprehension boundaries of reward models through insights from NLI leads to more effective reinforcement learning.
key_contributions: Introduction of ESFP-RM for improved reward modeling
Demonstration of superior performance over traditional models using MLMs
Insights connecting reward modeling with natural language inference.

title: MTalk-Bench: Evaluating Speech-to-Speech Models in Multi-Turn Dialogues via Arena-style and Rubrics Protocols
summary:
The rapid advancement of speech-to-speech (S2S) large language models (LLMs)
has significantly improved real-time spoken interaction. However, current
evaluation frameworks remain inadequate for assessing performance in complex,
multi-turn dialogues. To address this, we introduce MTalk-Bench, a multi-turn
S2S benchmark covering three core dimensions: Semantic Information,
Paralinguistic Information, and Ambient Sound. Each dimension includes nine
realistic scenarios, along with targeted tasks to assess specific capabilities
such as reasoning. Our dual-method evaluation framework combines Arena-style
evaluation (pairwise comparison) and Rubrics-based evaluation (absolute
scoring) for relative and absolute assessment. The benchmark includes both
model and human outputs, evaluated by human evaluators and LLMs. Experimental
results reveal two sets of findings. Overall performance of S2S LLMs: (1)
models excel at semantic information processing yet underperform on
paralinguistic information and ambient sounds perception; (2) models typically
regain coherence by increasing response length, sacrificing efficiency in
multi-turn dialogues; (3) modality-aware, task-specific designs outperform
brute scaling. Evaluation framework and reliability: (1) Arena and Rubrics
yield consistent, complementary rankings, but reliable distinctions emerge only
when performance gaps are large; (2) LLM-as-a-judge aligns with humans when
gaps are clear or criteria explicit, but exhibits position and length biases
and is reliable on nonverbal evaluation only with text annotations. These
results highlight current limitations in S2S evaluation and the need for more
robust, speech-aware assessment frameworks.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MTalk-Bench, a benchmark for evaluating speech-to-speech large language models across multi-turn dialogues, addressing deficiencies in current evaluation methods.
AI.motivation: To provide a comprehensive evaluation framework for speech-to-speech LLMs that accounts for the complexities of multi-turn dialogue interactions.
AI.method: The benchmark includes dimensions of Semantic Information, Paralinguistic Information, and Ambient Sound with associated realistic scenarios and evaluation tasks. It employs both Arena-style and Rubrics-based evaluation methods.
AI.result: Models perform well on semantic tasks but struggle with paralinguistic and ambient sound tasks, showing coherence at the expense of efficiency and revealing biases in the evaluation framework.
AI.conclusion: Current evaluation frameworks for multi-turn dialogues in S2S LLMs are inadequate and require development for better reliability and speech-aware assessments.
key_contributions: Introduction of MTalk-Bench as a comprehensive benchmark for S2S LLMs.
Identification of specific areas where models underperform, particularly in paralinguistic information and ambient sounds.
Development of a dual-method evaluation framework that combines pairwise and absolute scoring methods.
AI.limitations: The evaluation framework may not reliably distinguish performance differences unless there are significant gaps; biases exist in LLM evaluation.

title: Demographic Biases and Gaps in the Perception of Sexism in Large Language Models
comment:
This work was presented as a poster at the Latin American Meeting in
  Artificial Intelligence KHIPU 2025, Santiago, Chile, March 10th - 14th 2025,
  https://khipu.ai/khipu2025/poster-sessions-2025/
summary:
The use of Large Language Models (LLMs) has proven to be a tool that could
help in the automatic detection of sexism. Previous studies have shown that
these models contain biases that do not accurately reflect reality, especially
for minority groups. Despite various efforts to improve the detection of sexist
content, this task remains a significant challenge due to its subjective nature
and the biases present in automated models. We explore the capabilities of
different LLMs to detect sexism in social media text using the EXIST 2024 tweet
dataset. It includes annotations from six distinct profiles for each tweet,
allowing us to evaluate to what extent LLMs can mimic these groups' perceptions
in sexism detection. Additionally, we analyze the demographic biases present in
the models and conduct a statistical analysis to identify which demographic
characteristics (age, gender) contribute most effectively to this task. Our
results show that, while LLMs can to some extent detect sexism when considering
the overall opinion of populations, they do not accurately replicate the
diversity of perceptions among different demographic groups. This highlights
the need for better-calibrated models that account for the diversity of
perspectives across different populations.

AI.tldr: This study investigates the effectiveness of Large Language Models (LLMs) in detecting sexism in social media text and highlights their biases and limitations.
AI.motivation: To explore the capabilities and biases of LLMs in detecting sexism and to understand how demographic characteristics affect the performance of these models in this task.
AI.method: Evaluation of different LLMs on the EXIST 2024 tweet dataset, which includes annotations from six distinct profiles for each tweet, alongside a statistical analysis of demographic biases.
AI.result: LLMs can somewhat detect sexism based on overall population opinions, but they fail to capture the diverse perceptions of different demographic groups accurately.
AI.conclusion: The findings stress the importance of developing better-calibrated models that consider varying perspectives across demographics to improve sexism detection.
key_contributions: Investigation of LLM capabilities in sexism detection
Analysis of demographic biases in LLMs
Highlighting the need for diverse perspective consideration in model development
AI.limitations: The study reveals that LLMs do not replicate the diversity of perceptions among different demographic groups.

title: From BERT to LLMs: Comparing and Understanding Chinese Classifier Prediction in Language Models
summary:
Classifiers are an important and defining feature of the Chinese language,
and their correct prediction is key to numerous educational applications. Yet,
whether the most popular Large Language Models (LLMs) possess proper knowledge
the Chinese classifiers is an issue that has largely remain unexplored in the
Natural Language Processing (NLP) literature.
  To address such a question, we employ various masking strategies to evaluate
the LLMs' intrinsic ability, the contribution of different sentence elements,
and the working of the attention mechanisms during prediction. Besides, we
explore fine-tuning for LLMs to enhance the classifier performance.
  Our findings reveal that LLMs perform worse than BERT, even with fine-tuning.
The prediction, as expected, greatly benefits from the information about the
following noun, which also explains the advantage of models with a
bidirectional attention mechanism such as BERT.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates the ability of large language models (LLMs) in predicting Chinese classifiers, demonstrating that they perform poorly compared to BERT, even with fine-tuning.
AI.motivation: To explore the ability of LLMs to correctly predict Chinese classifiers, which is crucial for various educational applications and largely unexplored in NLP literature.
AI.method: The study employs various masking strategies to assess LLMs' intrinsic abilities, the contributions of sentence elements, and the functioning of attention mechanisms, alongside examining fine-tuning techniques.
AI.result: LLMs perform worse than BERT in predicting Chinese classifiers, with significant improvements observed when incorporating information about subsequent nouns, highlighting the benefits of bidirectional attention mechanisms.
AI.conclusion: The findings indicate that while fine-tuning can be applied, LLMs generally underperform compared to traditional models like BERT for this specific task.
key_contributions: Evaluation of LLMs' performance in predicting Chinese classifiers
Analysis of sentence element contributions and attention mechanisms
Insights on the impact of fine-tuning LLMs for classifier accuracy

title: MIRAGE: Scaling Test-Time Inference with Parallel Graph-Retrieval-Augmented Reasoning Chains
comment:
10 pages, 8 figures (including tables), plus appendix. Submitted to
  AAAI 2026
summary:
Large reasoning models (LRMs) have shown significant progress in test-time
scaling through chain-of-thought prompting. Current approaches like search-o1
integrate retrieval augmented generation (RAG) into multi-step reasoning
processes but rely on a single, linear reasoning chain while incorporating
unstructured textual information in a flat, context-agnostic manner. As a
result, these approaches can lead to error accumulation throughout the
reasoning chain, which significantly limits its effectiveness in medical
question-answering (QA) tasks where both accuracy and traceability are critical
requirements. To address these challenges, we propose MIRAGE (Multi-chain
Inference with Retrieval-Augmented Graph Exploration), a novel test-time
scalable reasoning framework that performs dynamic multi-chain inference over
structured medical knowledge graphs. Specifically, MIRAGE 1) decomposes complex
queries into entity-grounded sub-questions, 2) executes parallel inference
chains, 3) retrieves evidence adaptively via neighbor expansion and multi-hop
traversal, and 4) integrates answers using cross-chain verification to resolve
contradictions. Experiments on three medical QA benchmarks (GenMedGPT-5k,
CMCQA, and ExplainCPE) show that MIRAGE consistently outperforms GPT-4o,
Tree-of-Thought variants, and other retrieval-augmented baselines in both
automatic and human evaluations. Additionally, MIRAGE improves interpretability
by generating explicit reasoning chains that trace each factual claim to
concrete chains within the knowledge graph, making it well-suited for complex
medical reasoning scenarios. The code will be available for further research.

AI.tldr: MIRAGE is a novel framework for multi-chain reasoning in medical question-answering, improving accuracy and interpretability over previous methods.
AI.motivation: Enhance the effectiveness of reasoning models in medical QA tasks by overcoming limitations of existing linear reasoning chain approaches and improving traceability.
AI.method: MIRAGE decomposes complex queries into entity-grounded sub-questions, executes parallel inference chains, retrieves evidence via neighbor expansion and multi-hop traversal, and integrates answers through cross-chain verification.
AI.result: MIRAGE outperforms existing methods like GPT-4o and Tree-of-Thought variants on three medical QA benchmarks, enhancing both automatic and human evaluation metrics.
AI.conclusion: The framework demonstrates improved interpretability through explicit reasoning chains linked to a knowledge graph, making it valuable for complex medical scenarios.
key_contributions: Introduces a multi-chain inference approach for medical QA tasks
Enhances retrieval and evidence integration techniques
Improves interpretability of reasoning in medical contexts

title: Humans Perceive Wrong Narratives from AI Reasoning Texts
summary:
A new generation of AI models generates step-by-step reasoning text before
producing an answer. This text appears to offer a human-readable window into
their computation process, and is increasingly relied upon for transparency and
interpretability. However, it is unclear whether human understanding of this
text matches the model's actual computational process. In this paper, we
investigate a necessary condition for correspondence: the ability of humans to
identify which steps in a reasoning text causally influence later steps. We
evaluated humans on this ability by composing questions based on counterfactual
measurements and found a significant discrepancy: participant accuracy was only
29.3%, barely above chance (25%), and remained low (42%) even when evaluating
the majority vote on questions with high agreement. Our results reveal a
fundamental gap between how humans interpret reasoning texts and how models use
it, challenging its utility as a simple interpretability tool. We argue that
reasoning texts should be treated as an artifact to be investigated, not taken
at face value, and that understanding the non-human ways these models use
language is a critical research direction.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the gap between human understanding and AI models' reasoning texts, revealing low human accuracy in identifying causal influences, challenging the perceived interpretability of these texts.
AI.motivation: To explore the correspondence between human interpretation of AI-generated reasoning texts and the actual computational processes of the models, particularly for transparency and interpretability.
AI.method: Evaluated participants' ability to identify causal influences in reasoning texts using questions based on counterfactual measurements.
AI.result: Participants showed a significant discrepancy in accuracy, with only 29.3% identifying causal steps, remaining low at 42% for majority votes on highly agreed questions.
AI.conclusion: The findings highlight a fundamental gap in understanding reasoning texts, suggesting these should be treated as artifacts for investigation rather than reliable interpretability tools.
key_contributions: Identified low human accuracy in interpreting AI reasoning texts
Challenged the utility of reasoning texts as interpretability tools
Proposed a new direction for research on AI language use

title: Can AI Have a Personality? Prompt Engineering for AI Personality Simulation: A Chatbot Case Study in Gender-Affirming Voice Therapy Training
summary:
This thesis investigates whether large language models (LLMs) can be guided
to simulate a consistent personality through prompt engineering. The study
explores this concept within the context of a chatbot designed for
Speech-Language Pathology (SLP) student training, specifically focused on
gender-affirming voice therapy. The chatbot, named Monae Jackson, was created
to represent a 32-year-old transgender woman and engage in conversations
simulating client-therapist interactions. Findings suggest that with prompt
engineering, the chatbot maintained a recognizable and consistent persona and
had a distinct personality based on the Big Five Personality test. These
results support the idea that prompt engineering can be used to simulate stable
personality characteristics in AI chatbots.

AI.tldr: This thesis examines using prompt engineering to create a consistent personality in a chatbot for Speech-Language Pathology student training.
AI.motivation: To explore the potential of large language models in simulating stable personalities, specifically within therapeutic contexts.
AI.method: Developed a chatbot named Monae Jackson, representing a transgender woman, and conducted interactions that mimic client-therapist conversations using prompt engineering techniques.
AI.result: The chatbot successfully maintained a consistent persona with distinct personality traits based on the Big Five Personality test.
AI.conclusion: Prompt engineering can effectively create stable personality characteristics in AI chatbots, particularly beneficial in educational settings for SLP.
key_contributions: Developed a chatbot tailored for speech therapy training
Demonstrated the effectiveness of prompt engineering for personality simulation
Found correlations between chatbot personality and the Big Five Personality traits
AI.limitations: The study may be limited by the scope of the chatbot's interactions and the specific context of SLP training.

title: Does GPT-4 surpass human performance in linguistic pragmatics?
summary:
As Large Language Models (LLMs) become increasingly integrated into everyday
life as general purpose multimodal AI systems, their capabilities to simulate
human understanding are under examination. This study investigates LLMs ability
to interpret linguistic pragmatics, which involves context and implied
meanings. Using Grice communication principles, we evaluated both LLMs (GPT-2,
GPT-3, GPT-3.5, GPT-4, and Bard) and human subjects (N = 147) on dialogue-based
tasks. Human participants included 71 primarily Serbian students and 76 native
English speakers from the United States. Findings revealed that LLMs,
particularly GPT-4, outperformed humans. GPT4 achieved the highest score of
4.80, surpassing the best human score of 4.55. Other LLMs performed well: GPT
3.5 scored 4.10, Bard 3.75, and GPT-3 3.25. GPT-2 had the lowest score of 1.05.
The average LLM score was 3.39, exceeding the human cohorts averages of 2.80
(Serbian students) and 2.34 (U.S. participants). In the ranking of all 155
subjects (including LLMs and humans), GPT-4 secured the top position, while the
best human ranked second. These results highlight significant progress in LLMs
ability to simulate understanding of linguistic pragmatics. Future studies
should confirm these findings with more dialogue-based tasks and diverse
participants. This research has important implications for advancing
general-purpose AI models in various communication-centered tasks, including
potential application in humanoid robots in the future.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates LLMs' performance in interpreting linguistic pragmatics using Grice communication principles, finding that GPT-4 outperforms human participants in dialogue tasks.
AI.motivation: To examine the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) in understanding linguistic pragmatics and to assess their performance in comparison to human subjects.
AI.method: LLMs (GPT-2, GPT-3, GPT-3.5, GPT-4, and Bard) and 147 human participants were evaluated on dialogue-based tasks using Grice communication principles.
AI.result: GPT-4 scored 4.80, surpassing the best human score of 4.55, with the average LLM score of 3.39 exceeding human average scores (2.80 for Serbian students and 2.34 for U.S. participants).
AI.conclusion: LLMs, especially GPT-4, show significant progress in simulating understanding of linguistic pragmatics, with implications for AI models in communication tasks.
key_contributions: Demonstrated LLMs' ability to interpret linguistic pragmatics
Found that GPT-4 outperformed human participants in dialogue tasks
Provided a comparative analysis of various LLMs and human scores in this context.
AI.limitations: Future studies should confirm findings with more dialogue tasks and diverse participants.

title: Rethinking Cross-Subject Data Splitting for Brain-to-Text Decoding
summary:
Recent major milestones have successfully reconstructed natural language from
non-invasive brain signals (e.g. functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI)
and Electroencephalogram (EEG)) across subjects. However, we find current
dataset splitting strategies for cross-subject brain-to-text decoding are
wrong. Specifically, we first demonstrate that all current splitting methods
suffer from data leakage problem, which refers to the leakage of validation and
test data into training set, resulting in significant overfitting and
overestimation of decoding models. In this study, we develop a right
cross-subject data splitting criterion without data leakage for decoding fMRI
and EEG signal to text. Some SOTA brain-to-text decoding models are
re-evaluated correctly with the proposed criterion for further research.

AI.tldr: This study addresses data leakage in cross-subject brain-to-text decoding from brain signals.
AI.motivation: To improve the accuracy and reliability of brain-to-text decoding by eliminating data leakage in dataset splitting methods.
AI.method: Development of a new cross-subject data splitting criterion designed to prevent data leakage during the training of decoding models.
AI.result: The proposed criterion successfully reduces overfitting and overestimation in existing brain-to-text decoding models.
AI.conclusion: The study highlights the necessity of proper dataset splitting to ensure valid evaluations of decoding methods, paving the way for more reliable advancements in this research area.
key_contributions: Identification of data leakage issues in current dataset splitting strategies
Proposal of a new splitting criterion to prevent data leakage
Re-evaluation of state-of-the-art brain-to-text decoding models under the new criterion
AI.limitations: The study's applicability is confined to the types of brain signals analyzed (fMRI and EEG), and further validation with other modalities is needed.

title: Backdoor Attacks on Dense Retrieval via Public and Unintentional Triggers
summary:
Dense retrieval systems have been widely used in various NLP applications.
However, their vulnerabilities to potential attacks have been underexplored.
This paper investigates a novel attack scenario where the attackers aim to
mislead the retrieval system into retrieving the attacker-specified contents.
Those contents, injected into the retrieval corpus by attackers, can include
harmful text like hate speech or spam. Unlike prior methods that rely on model
weights and generate conspicuous, unnatural outputs, we propose a covert
backdoor attack triggered by grammar errors. Our approach ensures that the
attacked models can function normally for standard queries while covertly
triggering the retrieval of the attacker's contents in response to minor
linguistic mistakes. Specifically, dense retrievers are trained with
contrastive loss and hard negative sampling. Surprisingly, our findings
demonstrate that contrastive loss is notably sensitive to grammatical errors,
and hard negative sampling can exacerbate susceptibility to backdoor attacks.
Our proposed method achieves a high attack success rate with a minimal corpus
poisoning rate of only 0.048\%, while preserving normal retrieval performance.
This indicates that the method has negligible impact on user experience for
error-free queries. Furthermore, evaluations across three real-world defense
strategies reveal that the malicious passages embedded within the corpus remain
highly resistant to detection and filtering, underscoring the robustness and
subtlety of the proposed attack \footnote{Codes of this work are available at
https://github.com/ruyue0001/Backdoor_DPR.}.

AI.tldr: This paper explores a covert backdoor attack on dense retrieval systems that exploits grammar errors to mislead retrieval outcomes without degrading performance on standard queries.
AI.motivation: The increasing use of dense retrieval systems in NLP applications necessitates an understanding of their vulnerabilities, particularly to novel attack scenarios.
AI.method: A backdoor attack is implemented that targets dense retrieval models by leveraging grammatical mistakes, allowing attackers to retrieve specified harmful content while maintaining normal functionality for standard queries.
AI.result: The attack method demonstrated a high success rate with a corpus poisoning rate of just 0.048%, and evaluations indicated difficulty in detecting the malicious content embedded in the retrieval corpus.
AI.conclusion: The study reveals that conventional defenses struggle against this type of attack, highlighting a significant security vulnerability in dense retrieval systems.
key_contributions: Introduction of a novel covert backdoor attack leveraging grammatical errors.
Demonstrated minimal impact on user experience for standard queries while achieving a high attack success rate.
Evaluation of the method's effectiveness against common defense strategies.
AI.limitations: The study primarily focuses on the covert backdoor attack mechanisms without addressing broader implications or potential solutions.

title: Graph-oriented Instruction Tuning of Large Language Models for Generic Graph Mining
summary:
Graphs with abundant attributes are essential in modeling interconnected
entities and enhancing predictions across various real-world applications.
Traditional Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) often require re-training for
different graph tasks and datasets. Although the emergence of Large Language
Models (LLMs) has introduced new paradigms in natural language processing,
their potential for generic graph mining, training a single model to
simultaneously handle diverse tasks and datasets, remains under-explored. To
this end, our novel framework MuseGraph, seamlessly integrates the strengths of
GNNs and LLMs into one foundation model for graph mining across tasks and
datasets. This framework first features a compact graph description to
encapsulate key graph information within language token limitations. Then, we
propose a diverse instruction generation mechanism with Chain-of-Thought
(CoT)-based instruction packages to distill the reasoning capabilities from
advanced LLMs like GPT-4. Finally, we design a graph-aware instruction tuning
strategy to facilitate mutual enhancement across multiple tasks and datasets
while preventing catastrophic forgetting of LLMs' generative abilities. Our
experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in five graph tasks
and ten datasets, showcasing the potential of our MuseGraph in enhancing the
accuracy of graph-oriented downstream tasks while improving the generation
abilities of LLMs.

AI.tldr: MuseGraph integrates GNNs and LLMs for efficient graph mining across diverse tasks and datasets.
AI.motivation: To leverage the strengths of Large Language Models to improve graph mining tasks without the need for retraining GNNs for each specific task or dataset.
AI.method: A framework that combines a compact graph description, a Chain-of-Thought instruction generation mechanism, and a graph-aware instruction tuning strategy to train a single model on multiple graph tasks.
AI.result: Significant improvements were observed in five graph tasks across ten datasets, enhancing both accuracy in graph tasks and LLM generative abilities.
AI.conclusion: MuseGraph presents a promising foundation model for simultaneous graph mining across various tasks and datasets, showcasing advantages over traditional approaches.
key_contributions: Integration of GNNs and LLMs into a single model for graph mining
Development of a Chain-of-Thought based instruction generation mechanism
Implementation of a graph-aware instruction tuning strategy

title: Large Language Models Meet NLP: A Survey
comment:
The article has been accepted by Frontiers of Computer Science (FCS),
  with the DOI: {10.1007/s11704-025-50472-3}
summary:
While large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT have shown impressive
capabilities in Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasks, a systematic
investigation of their potential in this field remains largely unexplored. This
study aims to address this gap by exploring the following questions: (1) How
are LLMs currently applied to NLP tasks in the literature? (2) Have traditional
NLP tasks already been solved with LLMs? (3) What is the future of the LLMs for
NLP? To answer these questions, we take the first step to provide a
comprehensive overview of LLMs in NLP. Specifically, we first introduce a
unified taxonomy including (1) parameter-frozen paradigm and (2)
parameter-tuning paradigm to offer a unified perspective for understanding the
current progress of LLMs in NLP. Furthermore, we summarize the new frontiers
and the corresponding challenges, aiming to inspire further groundbreaking
advancements. We hope this work offers valuable insights into the potential and
limitations of LLMs, while also serving as a practical guide for building
effective LLMs in NLP.

AI.tldr: This study investigates the applications and future prospects of Large Language Models (LLMs) in Natural Language Processing (NLP), providing a comprehensive overview and taxonomy.
AI.motivation: To address the unexplored potential of LLMs in NLP and provide a systematic investigation into their applications and future.
AI.method: The study offers a comprehensive overview of LLMs in NLP, introducing a unified taxonomy that includes parameter-frozen and parameter-tuning paradigms.
AI.result: The paper summarizes the current applications of LLMs in NLP, identifying solved traditional tasks and highlighting future challenges and opportunities.
AI.conclusion: The work serves as a practical guide for developing effective LLMs in NLP while clarifying their potential and limitations.
key_contributions: Introduction of a unified taxonomy for LLMs in NLP.
Comprehensive overview of LLM applications in NLP tasks.
Identification of future challenges and opportunities in LLM research.

title: ComplexTempQA:A 100m Dataset for Complex Temporal Question Answering
summary:
We introduce \textsc{ComplexTempQA},\footnote{Dataset and code available at:
https://github.com/DataScienceUIBK/ComplexTempQA} a large-scale dataset
consisting of over 100 million question-answer pairs designed to tackle the
challenges in temporal question answering. \textsc{ComplexTempQA} significantly
surpasses existing benchmarks in scale and scope. Utilizing Wikipedia and
Wikidata, the dataset covers questions spanning over two decades and offers an
unmatched scale. We introduce a new taxonomy that categorizes questions as
\textit{attributes}, \textit{comparisons}, and \textit{counting} questions,
revolving around events, entities, and time periods, respectively. A standout
feature of \textsc{ComplexTempQA} is the high complexity of its questions,
which demand reasoning capabilities for answering such as across-time
comparison, temporal aggregation, and multi-hop reasoning involving temporal
event ordering and entity recognition. Additionally, each question is
accompanied by detailed metadata, including specific time scopes, allowing for
comprehensive evaluation of temporal reasoning abilities of large language
models.

AI.tldr: Introduction of ComplexTempQA, a large-scale dataset for temporal question answering with over 100 million QA pairs.
AI.motivation: To tackle the challenges in temporal question answering, providing a comprehensive dataset that surpasses existing benchmarks.
AI.method: The dataset was created using Wikipedia and Wikidata, categorized into attributes, comparisons, and counting questions, requiring advanced reasoning capabilities.
AI.result: ComplexTempQA significantly exceeds existing datasets in terms of scale and complexity, supporting high-level reasoning for temporal queries.
AI.conclusion: ComplexTempQA provides valuable resources for assessing the temporal reasoning capabilities of large language models.
key_contributions: Launch of a new large-scale temporal question-answer dataset with over 100 million pairs.
Introduction of a question taxonomy for temporal reasoning.
Detailed metadata for comprehensive evaluation of temporal reasoning in LLMs.

title: Evaluating $n$-Gram Novelty of Language Models Using Rusty-DAWG
summary:
How novel are texts generated by language models (LMs) relative to their
training corpora? In this work, we investigate the extent to which modern LMs
generate $n$-grams from their training data, evaluating both (i) the
probability LMs assign to complete training $n$-grams and (ii) $n$-novelty, the
proportion of $n$-grams generated by an LM that did not appear in the training
data (for arbitrarily large $n$). To enable arbitrary-length $n$-gram search
over a corpus in constant time w.r.t. corpus size, we develop Rusty-DAWG, a
novel search tool inspired by indexing of genomic data. We compare the novelty
of LM-generated text to human-written text and explore factors that affect
generation novelty, focusing on the Pythia models. We find that, for $n > 4$,
LM-generated text is less novel than human-written text, though it is more
